qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Surviving spouses and beneficiaries of Maryland correctional officers killed in the line of duty since June 1, 2001, specifically addressing the case of Officer Gregory Collins.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to apply to only one individual; consequently, it has no discernible effect on State pension liabilities or employer contributions. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is the primary administrative body responsible for the operation and management of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS). It is explicitly tasked by the bill to receive requests and award special death benefits to eligible beneficiaries within the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the benefits provided to the surviving families of its employees (Correctional Officers). The department is responsible for providing performance-of-duty evidence and verification required for benefit eligibility.

As the central personnel agency for Maryland, DBM manages state employee benefits and policies. It also oversees budget execution for the executive branch, including the fiscal resources required for pension system adjustments.

The Comptroller, as the state's chief financial officer, oversees the distribution of state funds and serves as a key member of the fiscal boards that manage state expenditures, including pension benefit payments.

The State Treasurer's Office is responsible for the management and protection of state funds. The Treasurer also holds a key position on the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System, which is responsible for awarding the benefits.

The OAG serves as the chief legal representative for all state agencies and boards, providing legal counsel to the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System regarding the interpretation and application of this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the definition of 'massage therapy' by removing the exclusion of 'treatment' of illness, disease, or injury from its scope. It also extends the deadline for the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners to issue initial registrations for massage practitioners from October 1, 2023, to October 1, 2024. Furthermore, it repeals a provision that explicitly stated health insurance carriers and nonprofit health service plans were not required to reimburse licensed massage therapists or registered massage practitioners for services rendered.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed massage therapists, registered massage practitioners, health insurance carriers, nonprofit health service plans, and massage therapy patients.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners can implement the bill's changes with existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances. The impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners, which is a regulatory board under the Maryland Department of Health. It alters the definition of massage therapy and modifies the registration and licensing timelines that the Board must administer.

The bill repeals Section 6-403 of the Health Occupations Article, which specifically exempted health insurers and health maintenance organizations from being required to reimburse massage therapists. This change directly affects the insurance regulations and oversight managed by the MIA.

Licensure for massage therapists requires graduation from an institution of postsecondary education approved by the Maryland Higher Education Commission. The bill's changes to licensure and registration requirements maintain this link to educational standards.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the State Board of Massage Therapy Examiners, regarding the interpretation of statutory changes to scope of practice and reimbursement laws.
As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM monitors the fiscal impact of legislation on state agencies; the fiscal note for this bill indicates implementation within existing resources.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and the various boards and commissions impacted by this legislation, and the Governor signed the bill into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transfers the administration of the Baltimore City Young Readers Program and the Young Readers Matching Grant Program from the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services to the Maryland State Library Agency. It requires the State Librarian to manage the programs, expands the Young Readers Matching Grant Program to allow public libraries to apply for grants, and increases the mandated annual funding for the matching grant program. The programs' primary goal is to distribute high-quality books to children in Maryland, with a priority on those living in low-income zip codes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Library Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland children (specifically in Baltimore City and low-income areas), public libraries, and nonprofit early reader organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $100,000 annually beginning in FY 2025, reflecting the increase in the mandated appropriation for the Young Readers Matching Grant Program from $250,000 to $350,000. The bill also mandates a $200,000 annual appropriation for the Baltimore City Young Readers Program. The Maryland State Library Agency will incur administrative costs, estimated at approximately $42,300 in FY 2024, to hire a half-time administrative officer to manage the programs. Local government revenues and expenditures increase for any county or public library that receives a matching grant.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill officially transfers the Baltimore City Young Readers Program and the Young Readers Matching Grant Program to the Maryland State Library Agency. The State Librarian and the State Library Board are tasked with administering these programs, distributing grants to public libraries, and reporting on their effectiveness.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The programs being transferred (previously housed in the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services, which this agency succeeded) are being removed from this agency's jurisdiction and budget.

The bill increases mandated annual appropriations for the Young Readers Matching Grant Program and involves the transfer of funds and administrative responsibilities between agencies, which requires DBM's fiscal oversight and budget execution.

The Governor is required to include specific mandated appropriations for these programs in the annual budget bill and oversaw the initial implementation of the Baltimore City Young Readers Program through the Executive Department.

The Governor's Office for Children originally implemented the program in 2016, and the bill's focus on distributing books to children in low-income zip codes aligns directly with this office's mission to reduce child poverty and improve child well-being.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies regarding the statutory transfer of programs and the implementation of new reporting and grant administration requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland's registers of wills to accept documents (excluding original wills) filed electronically through a system established by the register in accordance with Maryland Rules. Additionally, it prohibits registers from refusing to accept documents based on the method used for signing, effectively facilitating the use of electronic signatures in estate administration.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Registers of Wills
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals administering estates, attorneys, the general public filing probate documents, and the staff of the Registers of Wills offices across the 24 Maryland jurisdictions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund revenues are expected to increase by a minimal amount starting in fiscal 2024 due to reduced administrative costs associated with paper filings. For illustrative purposes, the Howard County register estimates statewide paper-filing administrative costs are at least $40,000 annually. State expenditures are not affected because the registers are already budgeting for the development of their web-based electronic filing system. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Register of Wills is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill's requirements, which include establishing an electronic filing system and accepting documents with electronic signatures for estate matters.

Registers of Wills serve as clerks to the Orphans' Courts, and the Administrative Office of the Courts provides support to the judicial branch and manages the procedural Maryland Rules governing the filing of documents.

The Comptroller manages state revenues; the fiscal note indicates that the bill will result in a minimal increase in General Fund revenue because the surplus fees and inheritance taxes collected by the Registers are deposited into the general fund.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Judiciary and state agencies, and may be called upon to provide legal interpretations of the new statutory requirements for electronic filing and signature validity.
The Governor signed the bill into law and oversees the executive department responsible for policy coordination and enforcement of state laws regarding government modernization.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the reporting requirements for the Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) Program by requiring the Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (GOSBA) to include an attestation in its annual report that all required state units are represented. To ensure accuracy, GOSBA must conduct a triennial audit of the Executive Branch to identify all entities qualifying as units, while the Office of State Procurement in the Department of General Services must maintain a list of those units. The bill also changes the reporting structure so that individual units report to GOSBA, which then provides a consolidated summary to the Joint Committee on Fair Practices and State Personnel Oversight.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (GOSBA) and the Office of State Procurement in the Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State Executive Branch units and certified minority business enterprises (MBEs)
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. The Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (GOSBA) can perform the required audits and reporting tasks using existing budgeted resources. There is no effect on state revenues.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates this office as the primary entity responsible for receiving annual MBE reports from all state units, conducting triennial audits of the Executive Branch to identify reporting units, and submitting a comprehensive annual report with a formal attestation of completeness to the Board of Public Works and the General Assembly.

The bill specifically requires the Office of State Procurement within this department to maintain the official list of units required to report MBE data and to collaborate with the Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs to adopt regulations for identifying non-compliant contractors.

The bill requires this office to be consulted in the adoption of regulations regarding contractors who fail to meet MBE goals and tasks it with handling the debarment of prime contractors referred for persistent failure to meet these goals.
The Board receives the mandatory annual MBE report and must be consulted during the development of regulations concerning contractor non-compliance and debarment criteria.

As the state's MBE certification agency (per the fiscal note), MDOT is one of the primary recipients of the annual reports from all state units. Additionally, its modal administrations are major procurement units subject to the reporting and compliance requirements.

The bill affects executive branch governance and the reporting duties of agencies under the Governor's authority. Furthermore, the Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs is a coordinating office within the Executive Department.

As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller is responsible for reviewing the annual reports and participating in the consultation process for new procurement regulations specified in the bill.

As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Treasurer is responsible for reviewing the annual reports and participating in the consultation process for new procurement regulations specified in the bill.

As an Executive Branch unit with significant procurement activity, the department is required to submit annual reports on its MBE contract participation and is subject to the periodic audit and attestation requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This department is an Executive Branch unit with high MBE participation rates that must comply with the reporting mandates and is subject to oversight via the new attestation and audit processes.
As an Executive Branch unit, this department is required to provide annual reports on its MBE contract participation to the Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs.
As an Executive Branch unit, this department must comply with annual MBE reporting requirements and is subject to the new audit oversight designed to ensure procurement compliance.
As a central procurement authority for IT goods and services, this department is a reporting 'unit' and is affected by the regulatory criteria regarding contractor performance goals.
As a state educational entity with procurement authority, the system is required to report its MBE participation data and is included in the statewide total calculations managed under this bill.
As an independent state university and 'unit' for procurement purposes, it must comply with the annual reporting of MBE contract data to the Special Secretary.
As an independent state college and procurement 'unit,' it is required to report its annual MBE participation statistics as part of the statewide program.
The department is an Executive Branch unit subject to the reporting requirements and fiscal oversight procedures established by the bill.
As a principal executive agency, it is a reporting unit that must track and disclose its use of certified minority business enterprises in procurement contracts.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the authority of the County Commissioners of St. Mary's County to impose a transfer tax on certain instruments of writing, such as real estate deeds, until October 1, 2028.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Commissioners of St. Mary's County
qa_results.stakeholders: Property buyers and sellers in St. Mary's County and the St. Mary's County government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances. St. Mary’s County transfer tax revenues of approximately $8,000,000 annually are maintained through fiscal 2028, with $2,000,000 expected in fiscal 2029 reflecting three months of collections before the sunset date. These revenues support the county capital improvement fund.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: House Bill 247 specifically concerns the authority to impose a transfer tax on instruments recorded with the Clerk of the Circuit Court for St. Mary’s County. The Administrative Office of the Courts provides the operational, legal, and financial support for the clerks who are responsible for the recording and tax collection processes mentioned in the bill.
The Governor's Office is responsible for the final review and signing of legislation into law, including this act extending local taxing authority for St. Mary's County.

As the state's chief financial officer and principal tax collector, the Comptroller has a general oversight interest in the regulation and extension of tax laws and authorities across Maryland's local jurisdictions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County to issue a Class B-ECF/DS (Education Conference Facility/Dining Service) beer, wine, and liquor license for Towson University. The license allows for the sale and on-premises consumption of alcoholic beverages at university-related events catered by the campus dining services contractor at multiple designated locations on campus.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Towson University, Baltimore County government, and attendees of university-related events.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state finances. Baltimore County revenues are projected to increase by $2,500 in FY 2024 (consisting of a $500 application fee and a $2,000 license fee) and by $2,000 annually thereafter for the license renewal. Any additional enforcement costs for the county are expected to be handled with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts constituent institutions of the University System of Maryland, specifically Towson University and the University of Maryland, Baltimore County (UMBC). It authorizes Towson University to obtain a Class B-ECF/DS license and stipulates that profits from alcohol sales must be deposited into the university's auxiliary services account.

The Comptroller's Office is the primary state agency responsible for the regulation of the alcohol industry in Maryland. As the bill creates and modifies specific licensing authorities within the Alcoholic Beverages Article of the Maryland Code, it falls under the general regulatory scope of the Comptroller.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows property owners in Baltimore City to request that real property tax exemptions for nonprofit or religious organizations be applied retroactively for up to three years. For a request to be granted, the applicant must show good cause for the delay in filing, and the exemption is subject to approval by the Baltimore City Solicitor and the Baltimore City Department of Finance. If granted, the State and Baltimore City must refund any excess property taxes paid during those years. The Baltimore City Department of Finance is also required to submit annual reports on these exemptions to the Governor and the General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Department of Assessments and Taxation, Baltimore City Solicitor, and Baltimore City Department of Finance
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit and religious organizations in Baltimore City, Baltimore City government, and the State of Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Annuity Bond Fund revenues are estimated to decrease by approximately $14,200 annually from FY 2023 through FY 2027. Baltimore City property tax revenues are projected to decrease by approximately $285,000 annually over the same period. These decreases are due to the requirement for the State and city to pay refunds for retroactive exemptions. State expenditures are not expected to be affected, and Baltimore City is anticipated to manage reporting requirements with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: PTAAB is the primary administrative body responsible for hearing appeals regarding property tax exemptions and assessment disputes. They would be the direct appellate authority for any disputes arising from the granting or denial of the retroactive exemptions authorized by this bill.

The Maryland Tax Court is the highest level of administrative review for tax-related disputes and hears appeals from the final decisions of both taxing authorities and the Property Tax Assessment Appeals Board regarding exemptions.

The bill requires the Baltimore City Department of Finance to submit annual reports directly to the Governor regarding the number of retroactive exemption requests received and the amounts refunded through 2027.

As the state's chief financial officer and tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for monitoring state revenues and ensuring fiscal compliance with state tax laws, including those impacting real property tax collections and refunds.

The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the Annuity Bond Fund, which is managed by the Treasurer's Office. The fund's revenues, which support state debt service, are expected to decrease as a result of the state's share of property tax refunds.

DBM is responsible for estimating revenues and supervising budget execution. The annual decrease in state property tax revenue for the Annuity Bond Fund is relevant to the department's fiscal planning and revenue forecasting duties.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of executive branch agencies. It would be responsible for auditing the state agencies involved in processing these retroactive exemptions and refunds to ensure they are handled according to the new law.

The bill provides tax relief to charitable and religious organizations. This office facilitates partnerships with such groups and would likely be involved in advising these organizations about the new availability of retroactive exemptions.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including those responsible for tax assessment and collection, regarding the interpretation and implementation of these new retroactive exemption provisions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill repeals the geographical prohibition on issuing Class A-7 beer, wine, and liquor licenses in the 43rd legislative district of Baltimore City and removes the previous deadline of July 1, 2022, for the issuance of these licenses. It allows holders of valid Class B-D-7 licenses issued on or before July 1, 2018, to apply to exchange them for Class A-7 licenses, subject to approval by the Baltimore City Council.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Current and prospective alcoholic beverages license holders in Baltimore City, specifically those in the 43rd legislative district and Class B-D-7 license holders.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no State fiscal impact. Baltimore City revenues are expected to increase minimally beginning in FY 2024 through application fees ($600) and annual license fees ($1,500). For each Class B-D-7 license exchanged for a Class A-7 license, the city receives an additional $180 in annual fee revenue (the difference between $1,500 and $1,320) plus the application fee. Enforcement is expected to be managed with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's principal tax collector and regulator of the alcohol industry, the Comptroller's office oversees state-level compliance and revenue collection from alcoholic beverages licenses, even for local classes like the Class A-7 license in Baltimore City.
The Governor's Office is responsible for overseeing the executive branch and signing legislation into law. Governor Moore signed this specific bill into law on May 16, 2023.

Morgan State University is a state agency located in Baltimore City's 43rd legislative district. The bill specifically repeals a prohibition on issuing Class A-7 licenses in the 43rd district, which directly impacts the community and commercial environment surrounding the university.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and state agencies regarding the implementation and interpretation of alcoholic beverages laws and the modification of license restrictions.

DBM is responsible for the state's fiscal planning and revenue estimation. While the fiscal note indicates no state-level fiscal impact, DBM monitors legislation for potential downstream impacts on state revenues.
The Secretary of State is the custodian of the state's official records, including the signed laws and executive orders related to the passage of this legislation.
The Maryland State Archives serves as the central depository for all government records of permanent value, including the finalized laws and legislative history of the Alcoholic Beverages Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to establish a permit exemption for on-farm composting facilities that utilize 10,000 square feet or less for active food scrap composting and meet specific feedstock and record-keeping requirements. It also mandates that new composting facilities comply with nutrient management or soil conservation plans and requires MDE to submit a report on the impact of these facilities by December 1, 2028.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland farm owners and operators, agricultural businesses, and providers of food scrap feedstocks.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of the Environment can implement the bill and its reporting requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state revenues and no material impact on local governments. Small business farm operators may benefit from reduced regulatory burdens.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the Department of the Environment to adopt regulations for permit exemptions, oversee notice requirements for farm operators, and submit a report to the General Assembly regarding the impact of on-farm composting facilities.

The bill requires on-farm composting facilities to be operated in accordance with nutrient management plans and soil conservation and water quality plans, which are primary regulatory and service areas for the Department of Agriculture.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of the Environment and the Department of Agriculture in their implementation of these regulations and receives mandated reports on the program's outcomes.
The bill affects the regulatory environment for farms, which are central to the Rural Maryland Council's mission of supporting the economic viability and quality of life in Maryland's rural counties.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable development, farmland preservation, and protecting the Chesapeake Bay, all of which are directly addressed by promoting on-farm composting and food waste diversion.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO supports the profitability and sustainability of Maryland's agricultural industries; the expansion of on-farm composting opportunities provides a new avenue for farmers to manage waste and produce soil amendments economically.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies residency requirements for alcoholic beverages license applicants in Caroline and Queen Anne's counties. It mandates that at least one applicant for a license must be a resident of the State of Maryland at the time of application and for the duration of the license's validity, replacing more restrictive local residency requirements for partnerships, corporations, clubs, and limited liability companies.
qa_results.responsible_party: Local alcoholic beverages licensing boards for Caroline County and Queen Anne's County
qa_results.stakeholders: Applicants for alcoholic beverage licenses in Caroline and Queen Anne's counties, including partnerships, corporations, clubs, and limited liability companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state finances. For local governments, the bill is not anticipated to materially affect the operations or finances of Caroline or Queen Anne’s counties. Small business impact is considered minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary state-level regulator of the alcoholic beverages industry. The bill modifies local licensing requirements that interact with standard application forms and regulatory structures overseen by the Comptroller's office.
The Governor's Office is responsible for signing the bill into law and oversees the executive branch departments involved in regulating commerce and alcoholic beverages.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Sign Language Interpreters Act establishes a licensing and regulatory system for sign language interpreters under a newly created State Board of Sign Language Interpreters within the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing. Beginning January 1, 2025, individuals must be licensed to provide sign language interpretation services in the state, with the board responsible for setting standards, conducting investigations, and managing a searchable database of practitioners.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Sign Language Interpreters within the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
qa_results.stakeholders: Sign language interpreters, deaf and hard of hearing individuals (including deafblind and late-deafened residents), interpreting agencies, and service providers in medical, legal, behavioral health, and educational settings.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill includes a mandated general fund appropriation of $100,000 in FY 2025. Total State expenditures increase by $253,800 in FY 2024 for one-time Judiciary programming costs and ODHH personnel, rising to $374,000 in FY 2025. Special fund revenues from licensing fees are projected to be $90,000 in FY 2025 and increase to $224,000 by FY 2028. Local circuit courts may experience operational delays or increased costs if the pool of available interpreters is reduced.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the State Board of Sign Language Interpreters within this office, requires the Director of ODHH to administer the new Sign Language Interpreters Fund, and mandates that the office provide staff to support the board.

The Governor appoints all seven members of the new board, exercises authority over the board's functions, and is mandated to include a specific appropriation in the FY 2025 budget for the board's implementation.

The bill requires the Maryland Judiciary to provide detailed annual reports on the use and availability of sign language interpreters in courts. The fiscal note indicates the AOC will incur significant costs for programming changes to track this data and notes operational impacts on court proceedings.

This office, within the Executive Department, is responsible for vetting and recommending the seven members to be appointed by the Governor to the newly created State Board of Sign Language Interpreters.
The bill creates the Sign Language Interpreters Fund, which the State Treasurer is responsible for holding separately and investing.
The Comptroller is responsible for distributing collected license fees to the newly established Sign Language Interpreters Fund and for accounting for the fund.
DBM is the principal fiscal agency responsible for overseeing the mandated $100,000 appropriation and managing the state personnel resources (3.5 new positions) required to staff the new board.

The bill requires that disciplinary hearings against licensees be conducted in accordance with the Administrative Procedure Act, which involves adjudication by independent Administrative Law Judges at OAH.

The bill defines 'school setting' to include career training programs for secondary education students regulated by MSDE, and the new licensing requirements will impact educational services provided in public and nonpublic schools.
The fiscal note specifically identifies that MSD may be affected if the new licensing requirements limit the availability of sign language interpreters for student instruction and support.

The bill defines and sets specific standards for interpreters in medical and behavioral health settings, directly affecting healthcare facilities, urgent care centers, and psychiatric treatment providers overseen by MDH.
The OAG serves as the legal counsel to all state boards and will be involved in providing legal advice to the new board and representing it in disciplinary proceedings.

As the principal agency for coordinating services for Marylanders with disabilities, this department is impacted by changes in communication access policies and standards for deaf and hard of hearing individuals.
The bill's definition of 'legal setting' includes law enforcement investigations, meaning MSP will be required to use licensed sign language interpreters for such activities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: OPD relies on sign language interpreters for legal representation and attorney-client conferences; the new licensing system and potential impacts on interpreter availability will affect its operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department's law enforcement and legal functions are impacted by the requirement to use licensed sign language interpreters in legal settings.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Buy Clean Maryland Act requires the Department of General Services (DGS) to establish maximum acceptable global warming potential standards for cement and concrete mixtures used in state-funded capital projects. Producers of these materials are required to submit environmental product declarations (EPDs) to the DGS, and contractors must provide facility-specific declarations before installing materials on eligible projects. The bill also establishes a temporary grant program, the Environmental Product Declaration Assistance Fund, to help producers develop and standardize these environmental declarations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of General Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Cement and concrete producers, construction contractors, state agencies involved in capital projects, and community colleges
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $200,000 in FY 2024 to capitalize the Environmental Product Declaration Assistance Fund. Additional general fund expenditures for DGS include $50,000 in FY 2025 for consulting and $217,900 in FY 2026 for staffing, with costs increasing annually thereafter. Local community colleges may see increased construction costs for state-funded capital projects. While individual project costs may rise, the bill is not expected to affect total state capital spending as project budgets are fixed annually.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of General Services is the primary agency responsible for implementing the Act, including establishing maximum global warming potential (GWP) limits, analyzing environmental product declarations, reviewing limits every three years, managing the waiver process, and submitting annual implementation reports.

The bill explicitly requires the Department of General Services to consult with the Department of Transportation when establishing the maximum acceptable global warming potential for cement and concrete mixtures used in eligible projects.

The bill establishes the Environmental Product Declaration Assistance Fund and specifically mandates that the Department of Commerce administer the fund and award grants to producers of eligible materials.

As a state agency that manages significant capital projects funded by the state, the University System of Maryland must comply with the new procurement standards and specify eligible materials in solicitations for high-performance building projects.

As a state agency that independently manages its own capital projects, Morgan State University will be required to comply with the Act's procurement standards for any state-funded high-performance building construction.
As an independent state agency, the college is subject to the procurement requirements of the Act for its state-funded capital projects involving high-performance buildings.
DBM oversees the state's capital budget and high-performance building waiver processes; the bill's fiscal note also identifies a need for additional personnel resources that DBM must manage.

The bill defines 'Greenhouse Gas' by referencing the Environment Article, and the Department of the Environment provides the underlying expertise on global warming potential and emissions standards referenced in the legislation.
The bill's requirements apply to community college capital projects that receive state funds, which are coordinated and overseen by the Higher Education Commission.

The Board of Public Works oversees and approves significant state procurement contracts and capital projects; the bill's requirements for global warming potential will become a mandatory factor in the contracts they review.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As a department with a large capital footprint and state-funded construction projects, it must implement the bill's procurement and material specification requirements in its contract solicitations.
The department manages public lands and facilities; any state-funded construction of high-performance buildings on its properties must comply with the Act's material standards.

The Maryland Department of Health manages various state facilities and hospitals; new capital projects for these facilities that meet the high-performance building threshold will be subject to the bill's requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes police departments to send electronic notifications to secured parties (such as lienholders) regarding abandoned vehicles taken into custody, provided that the police department, the towing company, and the secured party agree to this method in writing. It also updates existing law to include unacknowledged or undeliverable electronic notices as a condition for providing alternative public notice in a circuit court.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland police departments
qa_results.stakeholders: Secured parties (lienholders), Maryland police departments, and towing companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local finances. However, minor efficiencies and minimal cost savings may be realized by police departments through the use of electronic notifications instead of certified mail.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary state law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police is responsible for taking abandoned vehicles into custody on state property and highways, and must follow the notification procedures and electronic agreement protocols established by this bill.
The bill relies on the records of the Administration (MVA) to identify secured parties and establishes the notification requirements based on those records.

The bill amends the Transportation Article and directly impacts the Motor Vehicle Administration, a modal unit of MDOT, as well as the State Highway Administration which manages roadside abandoned vehicles.

The bill requires that if electronic or certified mail notice is unacknowledged or undeliverable, notice must be posted in the circuit court of the county where the vehicle was found. The AOC provides operational support for these courts.
The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies like the Maryland State Police and MDOT regarding the legal validity of written or electronic agreements for notification.

The Maryland Insurance Administration was identified as an information source for this bill, as secured parties (lienholders) often include insurance entities or are impacted by insurance-related total loss processes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes senior activity centers in St. Mary's County to conduct gaming events, bunco games, and card games. It sets limits on prize money, which may not exceed $50 per winner per session, and participation fees, which may not exceed $25 per session. All net proceeds from these games must be used to support future programming at the senior activity centers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Senior activity centers in St. Mary's County
qa_results.stakeholders: Senior citizens and their spouses in St. Mary's County
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact, and the local fiscal impact on St. Mary's County is negligible. While senior centers may generate some revenue from participation fees, these proceeds must be used exclusively to support future center programming.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary regulatory body for gaming in Maryland, this agency is responsible for overseeing the integrity of gaming operations. The fiscal note specifically analyzes the potential impact of this bill on State lottery and casino revenues.

The bill specifically concerns activities at 'senior activity centers,' which are community facilities providing services to older adults. The Department of Aging oversees the statewide network and programs that support these centers and their residents.

Under current law referenced in the fiscal note, the State Police are authorized to examine the records of qualified organizations conducting gaming events in St. Mary's County to ensure legal compliance.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and signed the bill into law; it coordinates policy initiatives related to local community services and state revenue sources like gaming.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Maryland Child Abduction Prevention Act authorizes a court in a child custody or visitation proceeding to order abduction prevention measures if there is a credible risk that a child may be abducted. The bill defines risk factors for abduction, establishes procedures for parties to petition the court for protection, outlines the requirements for abduction prevention orders (such as travel restrictions and passport surrender), and allows courts to issue ex parte warrants for law enforcement to take physical custody of a child to prevent imminent abduction.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and law enforcement agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Children under the age of 18 and parents or guardians involved in child custody or visitation proceedings.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Maryland State or local finances. There may be an operational impact on the Judiciary and circuit courts due to requirements for expedited hearings following the execution of an ex parte warrant. Additionally, a court may award a respondent reasonable attorney's fees and costs if a petitioner seeks a warrant in bad faith or for harassment.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Maryland Child Abduction Prevention Act, which creates new judicial procedures, petition requirements, and ex parte warrant processes that the Judicial Branch must implement and manage, including expedited next-business-day hearings.

The Act explicitly authorizes courts to direct law enforcement to take physical custody of children immediately via ex parte warrants, including authorization to enter private property and use forcible entry, directly impacting state law enforcement operations.

DHS is the primary state agency for child welfare and protection; the bill mandates that courts consider histories of child abuse or neglect and previous child custody determinations when assessing abduction risk.

The Secretary of State manages address confidentiality for domestic violence victims and coordinates international affairs; the bill focuses heavily on domestic violence history and risks associated with international child abduction.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office coordinates public safety strategies and advises the Governor on criminal justice policy, which encompasses the prevention of child abduction and the management of warrants related to child safety.

The OAG serves as legal counsel to state agencies, including the Maryland State Police and DHS, and will be responsible for providing guidance on the enforcement and legal implications of the Maryland Child Abduction Prevention Act.

This office is dedicated to the well-being and support of Maryland's children; the bill's focus on preventing child abduction and addressing child poverty/safety aligns with the office's advocacy and policy mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor to include a $12 million appropriation in the fiscal year 2025 budget for the 9-8-8 Trust Fund. The fund is used to support the 9-8-8 suicide prevention and mental health crisis hotline and to develop a statewide continuum of behavioral health crisis response services, including crisis call centers, mobile crisis teams, and stabilization centers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals experiencing mental health crises, local jurisdictions providing crisis response services, and acute behavioral health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures and special fund revenues increase by $12 million in FY 2025 due to the mandated appropriation. Special fund expenditures increase starting in FY 2025 for crisis services and personnel, including an estimated $94,023 for a new administrator to manage the fund. Local government revenues and expenditures may increase significantly if they receive funding to provide behavioral health crisis response services.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for administering the 9-8-8 Trust Fund and overseeing the behavioral health crisis services it supports, including the crisis hotline and mobile crisis teams.

DBM is the principal agency for budget development and execution. This bill establishes a $12 million mandated appropriation for FY 2025, which DBM must include and supervise within the state budget process.
The bill specifically mandates the Governor to include a $12 million appropriation to the 9-8-8 Trust Fund in the annual budget bill for fiscal year 2025.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the 9-8-8 Trust Fund, which is established as a special, nonlapsing fund.
The bill explicitly requires the State Treasurer to hold and invest the 9-8-8 Trust Fund separately, with interest earnings credited back to the fund.
The bill specifically states that the 9-8-8 Trust Fund is subject to audit by the Office of Legislative Audits.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the licensing and educational requirements for environmental health specialists (EHS). It modifies the specific credit hour and laboratory course requirements for applicants with baccalaureate or master's degrees, reduces the number of pathways for licensure by repealing one experience-based option, allows the Board of Environmental Health Specialists to use third-party examination providers, and expands the grounds for disciplinary action to include misfeasance and malfeasance.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Environmental Health Specialists
qa_results.stakeholders: Environmental health specialists, applicants for EHS licensure, environmental health specialist-in-training (EHSIT) participants, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's changes are largely technical and are not expected to have a material impact on State or local finances. The State Board of Environmental Health Specialists can implement the changes within existing resources, and the bill does not mandate any new funding or generate significant new revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Board of Environmental Health Specialists is a licensing board housed within the Department of Health. This bill directly alters the licensure requirements, examination processes, and disciplinary grounds that the Department and its Board are responsible for administering.

Environmental Health Specialists perform inspections and investigations to ensure compliance with laws regarding water supply, wastewater, air quality, and solid waste—core regulatory areas of the Department of the Environment. Changes to the qualification and conduct of these specialists impact the enforcement of the Department's mission.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Board of Environmental Health Specialists and represents the state in civil appeals. This bill modifies disciplinary grounds and judicial review procedures, which directly affects the OAG's legal advisory and litigation functions for the Board.

The bill specifies and alters the procedures for judicial review of final decisions made by the Board. This directly impacts the Maryland Judicial Branch, which the Administrative Office of the Courts supports, by clarifying how such cases enter the court system.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes and codifies specific per-resident funding levels for county public library systems in Maryland. It sets a schedule of increasing per capita funding amounts through fiscal year 2027, at which point the funding is set at $19.10 per resident for that year and each year thereafter.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: County public library systems and Maryland residents
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact because it codifies funding levels for local library systems that were already established by Chapters 496 and 497 of 2022. State aid for local libraries totaled $44.7 million in fiscal 2022, excluding retirement-related expenses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Library Agency is the primary state entity responsible for the coordination, leadership, and funding of the 24 public library systems across Maryland, making this bill's funding mandates central to its mission.
DBM is responsible for developing the state's annual budget and ensuring that statutory funding formulas, such as the per-resident library aid established in this bill, are accurately executed.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and is responsible for proposing the annual state budget, which must incorporate the mandated library funding levels defined in this legislation.

As this bill amends the Education Article of the Maryland Code and involves the funding of public libraries—a key component of the state's educational landscape—MSDE maintains a high-level policy interest in the fiscal health of library systems.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows holders of a Class B-BWL (clubhouse/lodge) license in Montgomery County who are issued a Class 7 micro-brewery license to be exempt from the general restriction that limits micro-brewery license holders to holding a financial interest in only one other retail alcoholic beverages license.
qa_results.responsible_party: Montgomery County Board of License Commissioners and the Maryland Alcohol and Tobacco Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Montgomery County Revenue Authority, holders of Class B-BWL (clubhouse/lodge) licenses, and multiuse facilities in Montgomery County such as golf courses and clubhouses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect state governmental operations or finances. It is not anticipated to materially affect Montgomery County operations or finances, and any impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the state's principal regulator of the alcohol industry. The bill specifically references the Comptroller's role in issuing manufacturer's licenses, such as the Class 7 micro-brewery license, and modifies the regulatory framework regarding interactions between manufacturing entities and retailers.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies, including those involved in the regulation of alcoholic beverages, and ensures compliance with the changes made to the Alcoholic Beverages Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees all state agencies, including the licensing and regulatory bodies affected by this legislation, and is responsible for signing the bill into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes clinical nurse specialists to prescribe drugs and durable medical equipment under regulations adopted by the State Board of Nursing. It defines the practice of a clinical nurse specialist to include ordering diagnostic tests, prescribing medications, and managing patient therapies, while also designating them as authorized prescribers under the Maryland Pharmacy Act.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Board of Nursing
qa_results.stakeholders: Clinical nurse specialists, registered nurses, physicians, and patients requiring prescription drugs or durable medical equipment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Expanding the scope of practice for clinical nurse specialists does not substantively change state governmental operations or finances. The Maryland Board of Nursing can implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. There is no local fiscal impact and minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Board of Nursing (MBON) is an entity within the Department of Health. The bill mandates that MBON adopt regulations for the certification and prescriptive authority of clinical nurse specialists, representing a primary regulatory responsibility for the department.

This division of the Maryland Department of Health regulates the prescribing and dispensing of controlled dangerous substances. With clinical nurse specialists gaining prescriptive authority, this office will be responsible for issuing and managing their Controlled Dangerous Substance (CDS) permits.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Board of Nursing and the Department of Health. The agency will be responsible for the legal review and approval of the regulations that the bill authorizes the Board of Nursing to adopt.

By designating clinical nurse specialists as 'authorized prescribers,' the bill affects the insurance market and reimbursement policies regulated by the MIA, as insurance carriers may need to update their systems to recognize CNS-issued prescriptions.

The OAH adjudicates contested cases for the Board of Nursing. An expansion in the scope of nursing practice (prescribing drugs and medical equipment) may lead to a higher volume of administrative hearings related to regulatory compliance or professional discipline.

The commission plans for state health system needs and works to improve healthcare access. The authorization for clinical nurse specialists to prescribe drugs and durable medical equipment aligns with the agency's mission to enhance the efficiency and accessibility of healthcare delivery.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Health and coordinates major health policy initiatives, such as the expanded scope of practice for clinical nurse specialists established by this legislation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reinstates the authority of the Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board (PDAB) to set upper payment limits on prescription drugs that create affordability challenges. These limits apply to drugs purchased or paid for by state and local government entities, including the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), state hospitals, and government employee health plans. The bill outlines a process for PDAB to draft a plan of action, obtain approval from the Legislative Policy Committee or the Governor and Attorney General, and establishes an appeals process for aggrieved parties.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Prescription Drug Affordability Board (PDAB)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland state and local government units, the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid), state and county correctional facilities, state hospitals, health clinics at state institutions of higher education, and individuals covered by state, county, or municipal employee health benefit plans.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local expenditures are expected to decrease to the extent that upper payment limits are implemented and result in lower prescription drug prices for government-funded programs and health plans. The bill does not affect state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor is granted specific statutory authority to approve the Prescription Drug Affordability Board's plan of action for setting upper payment limits if the Legislative Policy Committee does not approve it.

The Attorney General is granted specific statutory authority to approve the Prescription Drug Affordability Board's plan of action for setting upper payment limits if the Legislative Policy Committee does not approve it.

The bill directly impacts the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and State hospitals, both of which are under the jurisdiction of the Department of Health and are targets for upper payment limits on prescription drugs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically authorizes the setting of upper payment limits for prescription drug products purchased by State correctional facilities, which are managed by this department.

As the agency responsible for managing state employee health benefit plans, the department would be significantly impacted by the setting of upper payment limits for prescription drugs covered under those plans.
The bill explicitly includes health clinics at State institutions of higher education as entities for which the Board may set upper payment limits for prescription drug products.
As a State institution of higher education, Morgan State University's health clinics are specifically identified as entities for which upper payment limits may be applied.
As a State institution of higher education, the college's health clinics are specifically identified as entities for which upper payment limits may be applied.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Prescription Drug Affordability Board's Stakeholder Council is required to collaborate on the drafting of the plan of action and consult on the final report regarding expanded authority.
The bill provides for judicial review of final decisions made by the Board, which involves the state's judicial branch and court operations.
The Board must report on the implications of expanding upper payment limits to all payor reimbursements in the state, which directly concerns the private insurance market regulated by the MIA.
The agency is listed as an information source in the fiscal note and provides the framework for administrative appeals mentioned in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) to provide coverage for medically necessary gender-affirming treatment starting January 1, 2024. It mandates that such treatment be assessed using nondiscriminatory criteria consistent with clinical standards and prohibits the denial of coverage based on gender identity or the classification of treatment as cosmetic. The bill also requires managed care organizations and the Maryland Department of Health to submit annual reports on geographic access to these services and include provider information in their directories.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Medicaid recipients (specifically transgender, nonbinary, intersex, two-spirit, and other gender-diverse individuals), managed care organizations, and healthcare providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Medicaid expenditures are expected to increase by an indeterminate but likely significant amount beginning in FY 2024. For illustrative purposes, the Maryland Department of Health estimates that if 125 individuals receive all new services, expenditures could increase by $7.6 million (approximately 68% federal funds and 32% general funds). Federal matching funds are expected to cover 90% for fertility preservation and approximately 64% for other services. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Maryland Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid). The bill directly mandates that MDH provide coverage for gender-affirming treatment, establish clinical and nondiscriminatory criteria for assessment, review adverse benefit determinations, and produce annual reports on geographic access and provider availability.

The bill is expected to increase Medicaid expenditures by a significant amount beginning in fiscal 2024. As the principal fiscal agency, the Department of Budget and Management is responsible for overseeing the budget execution and long-term fiscal planning associated with this expansion of healthcare services.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to the Department of Health. The OAG will likely be involved in advising the department on the implementation of the bill's nondiscrimination mandates, the legal criteria for assessing gender-affirming treatments, and the protocols for reviewing adverse benefit determinations.

The bill introduces specific requirements for issuing adverse benefit determinations regarding gender-affirming treatment. As the agency responsible for hearing contested cases for the Maryland Department of Health, the Office of Administrative Hearings may adjudicate appeals from Medicaid recipients who challenge denials of these services.

The Maryland Health Care Commission is responsible for planning health system needs and improving access to health care. The bill's requirement for the Department of Health to compile reports on geographic access to gender-affirming treatment and maintain detailed provider directories aligns with the commission's mission to ensure equitable access to care.

The bill explicitly requires the provision of gender-affirming treatment in a nondiscriminatory manner based on gender identity. The Commission on Civil Rights is the state agency tasked with enforcing anti-discrimination laws related to gender identity in public accommodations, which includes the delivery of healthcare services.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires owners and operators of certain grocery stores and restaurants to install and maintain an automated external defibrillator (AED) in a prominent area accessible to employees and customers. It mandates that these facilities register their AEDs with the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems (MIEMSS), establishes maintenance and inspection guidelines, and provides civil liability immunity for businesses and individuals who use or fail to use an AED in good faith during a cardiac emergency.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and operators of grocery stores and restaurants, employees, customers, and the Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures from the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF) increase by at least $41,400 in FY 2024 for MIEMSS to hire a part-time administrator to oversee registration and reporting requirements, with costs rising to $53,100 by FY 2028. There is no impact on state revenues. Local health department expenditures may increase minimally if required to assist with inspections. Impacted businesses will incur costs for purchasing AED units (estimated between $500 and $1,700 each) and potential training costs.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates MIEMSS as the primary regulatory body responsible for managing the AED registration system, jointly adopting regulations for inspections and maintenance, and reporting on the program's effectiveness to the General Assembly.
MDH is specifically tasked with jointly adopting regulations with MIEMSS to establish guidelines for AED inspections, maintenance, and assisting facility owners in compliance.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments implementing the mandate and coordinates policy initiatives like the Joe Sheya Act.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDH and MIEMSS during the regulatory process and would defend the state regarding the bill's new civil immunity provisions.
As the state's primary economic development agency, Commerce has a notable interest in new mandates impacting the operational costs of grocery and restaurant businesses.
The bill's grant of specific civil immunity to grocery stores and restaurants directly impacts the liability landscape and insurance risk profiles for these industries.
DBM oversees the Maryland Emergency Medical System Operations Fund (MEMSOF), which the fiscal note indicates will require increased expenditures to implement this program.
MFCA manages regional food industry facilities whose tenants, particularly in the produce and seafood markets, may be subject to the new AED requirements.
The agency protects workers and regulates industries; the mandate introduces a new safety requirement for employees at large-scale restaurants and grocery stores.
The judicial branch will be responsible for interpreting and applying the bill's civil immunity standards in litigation related to cardiac emergencies at these facilities.
OLA will conduct fiscal compliance audits of MIEMSS and MDH to ensure the new AED registration and inspection programs are operating efficiently and within law.
MHCC is involved in health system planning and improving access to care; AED placement is a component of community-based emergency health resource planning.
The bill applies based on annual gross income thresholds ($1M for restaurants, $10M for groceries), which are financial metrics managed and audited by the Comptroller.
The bill amends the Education Article regarding the Public Access Automated External Defibrillator Program, which is generally administered under the EMS Board.
MDEM coordinates statewide preparedness; AEDs are essential tools in incident response, supporting the resilience of public spaces against cardiac events.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill involves the EMS Board and regional AED committees which are composed of appointed public servants and experts who set standards for the program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note identifies a meaningful impact on small business grocery stores and restaurants that must now fund AED procurement and maintenance.
MEDCO supports business prosperity; this bill adds a permanent operational compliance requirement for high-revenue retail and dining establishments.
RMC advocates for healthcare access in rural areas where AED availability in common gathering places like restaurants can be a critical life-saving resource.
OAH would adjudicate any contested administrative cases resulting from the enforcement of AED regulations or inspections by MDH and MIEMSS.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Maryland Forestry Education Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund to provide education, training, and resources to forest landowners, district forestry boards, local governments, and forestry businesses. The fund is designed to promote sustainable forest management, ecological service markets, and innovative best management practices in forestry through training programs, conferences, and small grants.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Forestry Foundation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland forest landowners, district forestry boards, local governments, and forestry industry businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $250,000 annually in fiscal 2025 and 2026 due to the mandated appropriation. Special fund revenues and expenditures for the Maryland Forestry Education Fund increase by the same amount. Local government revenues and expenditures may increase if they receive grants from the fund, and they may benefit from additional forestry training and outreach.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Maryland Forestry Education Fund within the Natural Resources Article and directly impacts District Forestry Boards, which are established and appointed by the Department of Natural Resources to promote private forestry and conservation.
The bill explicitly mandates that the State Treasurer shall hold the Maryland Forestry Education Fund separately and invest its money in the same manner as other State money.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Maryland Forestry Education Fund.
The bill mandates that the Governor include a specific appropriation of $250,000 in the annual budget bill for fiscal years 2025 and 2026 to support the fund.
As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for implementing the mandated budget appropriations and managing the fiscal impact on the General Fund as noted in the fiscal note.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's primary purpose is to enhance the capacity and outreach of District Forestry Boards, which are statutory advisory bodies created to address specific forestry management issues.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like the Department of Natural Resources and would be responsible for advising on the implementation of the new subtitle and regulatory framework created by the bill.

The Council addresses challenges in Maryland's rural counties by supporting agriculture and natural resource stewardship; the bill's focus on forestry education and landowner resources aligns with the Council's mission to improve the quality of life in rural areas.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill aims to improve access to dental services in Maryland by expanding the Maryland Dent-Care Program to include dental hygienists and setting specific higher education loan assistance grant amounts. It requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to create and distribute plain language dental health materials, annually evaluate Medicaid dental reimbursement rates, and conduct several studies regarding provider participation and reimbursement for community health workers. Additionally, the State Board of Dental Examiners must maintain a searchable list of mobile and portable dental providers, and county boards of education and child care facilities are required to notify parents of the importance of dental screenings for children at certain ages.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health, Maryland Higher Education Commission, and State Board of Dental Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Dentists, dental hygienists, Maryland Medical Assistance Program recipients, and parents or guardians of children in public schools or child care facilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $86,400 in FY 2024 for one-time costs related to plain language materials and IT system updates. Medicaid expenditures (50% state general funds, 50% federal funds) increase by $100,000 in FY 2024 and $20,000 in FY 2025 to support studies. Federal fund revenues increase by $50,000 in FY 2024 and $10,000 in FY 2025 as matching funds for the Medicaid studies. Expansion of the Dent-Care program and mandated award amounts will likely increase general fund expenditures in future years by an indeterminate but significant amount depending on the number of grants awarded.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill's core mandates, including evaluating Medicaid dental reimbursement rates, conducting multiple studies on provider participation and community health workers, and creating plain-language dental health materials. Additionally, its Office of Oral Health assists in the Dent-Care Program.

The commission's Office of Student Financial Assistance (OSFA) is responsible for administering the Maryland Dent-Care Program, which this bill significantly expands to include dental hygienists and for which it establishes new grant amount floors and duration requirements.

The bill mandates requirements for county boards of education and child care facilities—both of which are overseen by the Department of Education—to provide notices to parents and guardians regarding the clinical need for dental screenings at specific age intervals.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to convene a specific stakeholder workgroup to study the establishment of a grant or loan program for dental providers in underserved areas.

As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is impacted by the bill's fiscal requirements, including general fund expenditures for updating financial aid systems (MDCAPS) and funding the required departmental studies.

As the chief legal officer for the State, the OAG will provide legal counsel to MDH, MHEC, and MSDE regarding the implementation of new regulatory requirements for dental screenings, loan assistance grants, and the publication of provider lists.

The bill's focus on improving access to healthcare and studying provider participation patterns aligns with the commission's mission to plan for the state's health system needs and improve access to care.

The bill requires a study on possible incentives to encourage dental provider participation in Medicaid, including tax incentives, which falls under the Comptroller's oversight as the state's chief tax collector.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the educational requirements for the licensure of clinical and graduate alcohol and drug counselors. It specifies that required degrees must be in a professional counseling field from an accredited institution, replacing the former requirement for a health and human services counseling degree from a regionally accredited institution. It also removes specific coursework requirements for graduate counselors from the statute and repeals an alternative educational pathway for clinical counselors to align requirements with similar professions.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Professional Counselors
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals seeking licensure as clinical or graduate alcohol and drug counselors
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as the changes are procedural and do not directly affect governmental revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) houses the State Board of Professional Counselors, which is the primary regulatory body responsible for implementing the changes to licensure requirements for clinical and graduate alcohol and drug counselors.

The Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC) oversees the academic programs at the state's colleges and universities; changes to licensure education requirements directly impact how these programs are structured and recognized.

Institutions within the University System of Maryland (USM) offer graduate-level counseling programs that must align with the bill's revised definitions of 'professional counseling' fields and accreditation standards.

As a state-operated university with graduate programs, Morgan State University is impacted by shifts in licensure standards that dictate the eligibility of its graduates for professional practice in counseling.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to the State Board of Professional Counselors to ensure that updated licensure regulations and the repeal of previous educational pathways are legally compliant.

The Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH) would be responsible for adjudicating any appeals from individuals denied licensure under the new educational and professional field criteria established by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill exempts family child care homes, large family child care homes, and child care centers from Maryland State registration and licensing requirements if they serve only dependent children of military personnel and are either located on federal property (such as a military base) or are certified by the U.S. Department of Defense or the U.S. Coast Guard.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Military personnel, dependent children of military personnel, and child care providers located on military bases or certified by the U.S. Department of Defense or U.S. Coast Guard
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State finances or operations, and there is no impact on local government. There is a potential meaningful impact on small business child care providers who meet the exemption criteria, as they may benefit from reduced administrative burdens and the elimination of duplicative State and federal registration requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education is the primary agency responsible for the registration and licensing of child care providers; this bill creates a specific exemption from their regulatory oversight for certain military-serving programs.
The Adjutant General heads the Maryland Military Department and advises on issues affecting military personnel and installations, which are the primary subjects of these licensing exemptions.
This agency supports active-duty service members and their families; the bill's changes to child care licensing directly affect the services available to military families in Maryland.
