The SRA manages the disability retirement process for state law enforcement and correctional officers, providing the administrative findings necessary for credit eligibility.
The Tax Court serves as the highest level of administrative review for tax-related disputes, including appeals concerning property tax credits.
The MDTA operates its own police force, whose officers would be impacted by the changes to domicile requirements for disabled law enforcement tax credits.
The OAH adjudicates administrative disputes which may include contested cases related to disability findings or eligibility for state-regulated benefits.
PTAAB is the agency responsible for hearing local appeals regarding property tax credits, including disputes over the eligibility criteria modified by this bill.
The bill requires an individual to be found 'permanently and totally disabled' by an authorized administrative body; the Commission is the primary agency for making such determinations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires Maryland municipalities to submit electronic copies of their certified election results to the State Board of Elections (SBE) within 30 days of certification. The SBE must establish and maintain an electronic portal on its website for municipalities to submit these results and is required to publish the results online, organized by election year and the name of the municipality.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland municipalities, municipal election candidates, and Maryland voters
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local government finances. Both the State Board of Elections and Maryland municipalities are expected to handle the reporting and publication requirements with existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the State Board of Elections to establish and maintain an electronic portal on its website and to publish municipal election results organized by year and municipality.

As the agency responsible for the state's IT strategy and infrastructure support for Executive Branch agencies, DoIT would be involved in the technical development, hosting, and security of the mandated electronic portal.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the State Board of Elections, and would likely advise on the implementation of these new statutory requirements and any intergovernmental agreements with municipalities.
The Governor's Office oversees executive branch agencies and would ensure the State Board of Elections has the resources and alignment to fulfill this new legislative mandate.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Labor to enforce prevailing wage requirements for contractors and subcontractors working on underground gas or electric infrastructure projects for investor-owned utilities. It establishes that the Commissioner of Labor and Industry is responsible for determining the prevailing wage rates and outlines procedures for contractors to request wage determinations. The bill also provides a grace period for civil penalties for contractors who come into compliance by March 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Investor-owned gas and electric companies, contractors and subcontractors performing underground utility work, and employees of those contractors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Labor can handle the bill's enforcement requirements with existing budgeted resources. There is no material effect on State revenues, and the bill does not directly affect local government finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Maryland Department of Labor (MDL) and its Commissioner of Labor and Industry to enforce prevailing wage requirements for investor-owned utility projects, determine wage rates, conduct hand surveys, and provide guidance to contractors.

The bill regulates investor-owned gas and electric companies which are under the jurisdiction of the PSC. It also clarifies enforcement authority for these utilities, shifting it from previous contractual mechanisms to the Department of Labor.

The OAG serves as the legal counsel for both the Maryland Department of Labor and the Public Service Commission, and would be involved in legal interpretations or litigation related to the enforcement of the prevailing wage laws.
As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM oversees the budget and personnel resources of the Department of Labor, which is tasked with the bill's enforcement.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, including the Department of Labor and the Public Service Commission, and the Governor signed this specific act into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes the annual deadline by which the Maryland Department of Agriculture must submit its report to the General Assembly regarding the use of medically important antimicrobial drugs in cattle, swine, and poultry from February 1 to July 1.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed veterinarians, owners of cattle, swine, and poultry farm operations, and the Maryland General Assembly.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as the change is procedural in nature and does not affect governmental finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Agriculture is the primary agency responsible for collecting data on antimicrobial drug use from veterinarians and federal sources and submitting the required annual report to the General Assembly. This bill directly changes the department's statutory reporting deadline from February 1 to July 1.

The Governor's Office oversees the Department of Agriculture and the executive branch's compliance with statutory reporting requirements. The Governor is also responsible for signing the bill into law.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Department of Agriculture regarding its statutory obligations, including the legal requirements for data collection and reporting procedures.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes an art establishment beer and wine license in the City of Annapolis, allowing the Board of License Commissioners to issue the license to nonprofit organizations primarily engaged in art display, art instruction, or live performances. The license permits the on-premises retail sale and service of beer and wine for an annual fee of $1,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: City of Annapolis Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit art organizations (such as galleries, theaters, and art instruction centers) in the City of Annapolis, artists, and patrons.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State finances are not affected. Local revenues for the City of Annapolis may decrease to the extent that nonprofit organizations obtain this $1,000 annual license instead of multiple single-use event licenses. City of Annapolis expenditures are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is responsible for regulating the alcohol industry in Maryland, and this bill creates a new category of alcoholic beverage license within the state's Alcoholic Beverages Article.

The bill establishes a license specifically for 'art establishments' (nonprofit organizations engaged in art display, instruction, or performance). The Department of Commerce is responsible for overseeing and promoting the arts in Maryland.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the General Assembly and the Governor regarding the legality and implementation of changes to the Annotated Code of Maryland, including the Alcoholic Beverages Article.

The Secretary of State manages the registration and oversight of charitable (nonprofit) organizations, which are the entities eligible for the new license. Additionally, the office is the custodian of the state's official records, including new laws.
As the state's chief executive, the Governor reviewed and signed this bill into law.
The Maryland State Archives is responsible for preserving the state's official legislative records, including this act of the General Assembly.

qa_results.bill_summary: HB 524 establishes the Camden Yards Football and Baseball Sports Facility Supplemental Financing Funds to manage debt service through reallocated lottery revenues. It also creates the Bus Rapid Transit Fund for system grants, adds two members to the Maryland Stadium Authority, and defines the Prince George’s County Blue Line Corridor.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Stadium Authority and Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland Stadium Authority, professional sports teams (Baltimore Ravens and Baltimore Orioles), Maryland Department of Transportation, Montgomery County, Prince George's County, and Maryland transit users.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: In FY 2024, State general fund revenues increase by $14.2 million due to a decrease in lottery distributions for bus rapid transit grants; special fund revenues and expenditures for MDOT and local revenues for Montgomery County decrease by the same amount. The bill reallocates up to $90 million in annual lottery revenues among stadium financing funds and mandates up to $27 million annually for the Bus Rapid Transit Fund, with Montgomery County receiving a minimum distribution of $20 million if eligible.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Stadium Authority is the primary subject of the bill, which establishes the Camden Yards Football and Baseball Sports Facility Supplemental Financing Funds and alters the board's membership.
The bill establishes the Bus Rapid Transit Fund and requires the Department of Transportation to administer the fund and award grants to eligible local jurisdictions.
The Comptroller is responsible for distributing State Lottery Fund revenue to the newly created funds and accounting for the funds as the state's chief financial officer.
The State Treasurer is required to hold the new special funds separately and is responsible for investing the money within those funds.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved and appoints the majority of the members to the Maryland Stadium Authority board.
The Board of Public Works oversees and approves significant state expenditures and bond issuances related to the Maryland Stadium Authority's projects.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill alters the distribution of the State Lottery Fund, which is operated and regulated by this agency.
The bill increases the number of Governor-appointed members on the Maryland Stadium Authority board, requiring this office to recruit and vet additional candidates.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Stadium Authority and MDOT and will likely review the legal frameworks for the new funds and bond issuances.
The OLA will be responsible for conducting fiscal compliance audits of the new funds and the agencies managing them to ensure financial accountability.
As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM is involved in the long-term fiscal planning and budget execution related to the reallocation of lottery revenues and fund creation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Outdoor Preschool License Pilot Program within the Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) to license and oversee outdoor, nature-based early learning and child care programs. The program, which runs for four school years starting in 2024, aims to expand access to affordable, high-quality early childhood education and research the benefits of outdoor classrooms. MSDE is tasked with selecting initial participants, convening an advisory group, and reporting findings to the Governor and General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE)
qa_results.stakeholders: Children, families, outdoor and nature-based early learning practitioners, and existing licensed child care centers or family child care homes seeking to expand into nature-based early learning.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) can implement the pilot program and comply with related requirements using existing resources. There is no estimated impact on state or local revenues. The bill may have a meaningful fiscal impact on small businesses that participate in the pilot program.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary implementing agency, MSDE is responsible for administering the pilot program, convening the advisory group, promulgating all licensing regulations, selecting participating programs, and submitting progress reports to the Governor and General Assembly.

The bill requires MSDE to give priority to existing outdoor programs currently licensed as camps by the Maryland Department of Health. Additionally, MDH expertise may be relevant for the health and safety regulations mandated by the bill, such as bathroom use, hand washing, and food storage in outdoor environments.

The bill explicitly requires that the regulations adopted for the pilot program include provisions for accommodations for children with disabilities, aligning with the department's mission to ensure inclusive services.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and MSDE; the department is specifically required to submit interim and final reports on the pilot program's implementation and findings to the Governor.
The OAG serves as legal counsel to MSDE and will be responsible for reviewing the new rules and regulations for the licensing and operation of outdoor preschools to ensure legal sufficiency.

This pilot program aims to expand access to high-quality early learning and child care, which directly supports the office's mission to promote child well-being and reduce barriers to education and services.

As a solution incubator for the Governor's top priorities, including child-focused initiatives and economic mobility, the team may be involved in evaluating the evidence-based strategies and outcomes of this novel pilot program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill transfers the functions, personnel, and duties of the Child Support Unit of the Office of the State’s Attorney for St. Mary’s County to the Child Support Administration of the Maryland Department of Human Services, ensuring that employees are transferred into the State Personnel Management System without loss of salary, seniority, or benefits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Human Services Child Support Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Employees of the St. Mary's County Child Support Unit, the St. Mary's County government, and the Maryland Department of Human Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $236,300 in FY 2024 (representing the State's share of enforcement costs), and general fund revenues decrease by $24,200 in FY 2024 and $32,300 annually thereafter due to the loss of local administrative fees. Federal fund revenues and expenditures increase by $38,400 in FY 2024. St. Mary’s County expenditures decrease by approximately $249,200 in FY 2024 and at least $332,300 annually thereafter as the county is relieved of child support operation costs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the parent agency of the Child Support Administration (CSA), the Department of Human Services is the primary recipient of the functions, duties, and personnel being transferred from St. Mary's County.
DBM is specifically tasked with establishing the new Position Identification Numbers (PINs) for the transferred staff and managing their integration into the State Personnel Management System.
The agency is responsible for conducting the actuarial valuation and managing the transfer of pension assets and interest from the municipal pool to the state pool for the transferred employees.
The bill authorizes the Office of the Attorney General to appoint transferred personnel, such as Assistant State's Attorneys, to continue their work as state employees.
The Administrative Office of the Courts supports the circuit courts which, under the Family Law Article, may initiate the request for the transfer of support enforcement responsibility.
The Treasurer's Office manages state funds and the Treasurer holds a key position on the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System, which oversees the pension asset transfer.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments involved in the transfer, and the Governor signed the bill which was supported by a contingent appropriation in the executive budget.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller's office is responsible for paying state employees and managing the shifts in revenue resulting from the cessation of county administrative fees.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows certain members of the Correctional Officers' Retirement System (CORS) who were previously in the State Employees' Retirement or Pension Systems to receive retirement credit for unused sick leave. It also requires the State Retirement and Pension System to automatically transfer previous service credits for these individuals to CORS, though affected employees have the option to opt out of the transfer.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State employees in the Correctional Officers' Retirement System who were transferred from other pension systems, including specific roles within the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services and the Department of Juvenile Services.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State pension liabilities and contributions across all funds are expected to increase minimally beginning in fiscal 2025. A precise estimate is not feasible because unused sick leave totals are only calculated at retirement and individual choices regarding service transfers vary. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency (SRA) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill, as it must manage the transfer of service credits between systems and calculate unused sick leave for members. The bill specifically directs the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System, which the SRA supports, to execute these transfers.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly affects employees of the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services (DPSCS), including case management specialists, parole and probation agents, and counselors who were transferred from the Employees’ Pension System to the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

The bill directly impacts Department of Juvenile Services (DJS) employees, specifically community detention officers, resident advisors, and group life managers, by allowing them to combine unused sick leave and transfer service credit into the Correctional Officers’ Retirement System.

As the principal personnel and fiscal agency, DBM is affected by changes to state employee retirement benefits and the resulting increase in state pension liabilities and contributions described in the fiscal note.

The State Treasurer serves as a key official overseeing the state's financial agencies, including the Maryland State Retirement Agency, and sits on the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System which is tasked with managing these service transfers.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Retirement Agency and the Board of Trustees to ensure the statutory transfers and sick leave calculations comply with state and federal law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the distribution of video lottery terminal local impact grants within Baltimore City by increasing the share of funds allocated to the Park Heights Master Plan from 75% to 85% for fiscal years 2024 through 2032. It also modifies the appointment process for the Pimlico Community Development Authority, requiring the Mayor of Baltimore City to obtain the advice and consent of the State Senate for certain appointments.
qa_results.responsible_party: Mayor of Baltimore City and the Pimlico Community Development Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents, business owners, and service providers in Baltimore City, particularly within the Park Heights Corridor and neighborhoods near the Pimlico Race Course.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State revenues or expenditures. Locally, while the total amount of local impact grants for Baltimore City remains unchanged, the bill reallocates approximately $363,500 in fiscal 2024 (increasing to $424,200 by fiscal 2028) toward projects consistent with the Park Heights Master Plan and away from other specified neighborhoods in the city.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly alters the membership appointment process for the Authority and changes the statutory formula for the distribution of local impact grants that the Authority oversees for neighborhoods surrounding Pimlico Race Course.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is the primary regulator for all video lottery terminal (VLT) operations in Maryland and oversees the revenue streams and statutory distributions, including local impact grants, established under the State Government Article amended by this bill.

The Comptroller is the state's chief financial officer and is explicitly named in the bill to receive reports regarding the advisability of continuing these specific fund distributions after fiscal year 2032.
The Governor signed this legislation into law and oversees the executive branch departments responsible for gaming regulation and the administration of state-mandated authorities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland election procedures by requiring local boards of elections to send mail-in ballots to voters at least 43 days before an election if requested early, allowing the processing of absentee ballots to begin eight business days before the start of early voting, and establishing a process for voters to fix (cure) missing signatures on ballot envelopes through digital or traditional means. It also requires the reporting of election results by precinct to include early, absentee, and provisional votes and moves the 2024 statewide primary election date to the second Tuesday in May.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Board of Elections and local boards of elections
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland voters, local election boards, and candidates in the 2024 primary election
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $84,100 in FY 2024, and by ongoing amounts reaching $115,700 by FY 2028, primarily to hire an IT programmer to develop a system for voters to cure signature omissions on mail-in ballots. Local government expenditures increase for additional personnel needed for earlier canvassing and for equipment such as flash drives and scanners; these costs are expected to be shared 50/50 between the State and local boards.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives, including major election law changes. The Governor also signed this bill into law and is responsible for proposing the budget that would include the new positions mentioned in the fiscal note.
The fiscal note identifies a need for at least one additional IT programmer position to implement the bill's technical requirements. DBM is the principal agency for personnel and budget management.

The bill requires the creation of an accessible online portal and the ability for voters to supply digital signatures via text and email. DoIT oversees statewide IT strategy and digital service infrastructure.

The Archives is the central depository for government records of permanent value. Changes to the format and reporting requirements of election results (precinct-level data for early, absentee, and provisional votes) affect the records the Archives preserves.

The State Board of Elections is the primary agency responsible for the administration of the bill. It must adopt regulations for the new ballot curing process, manage the statewide voter registration system mentioned in the bill, and oversee the local boards' implementation of the new canvassing timelines.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the State Board of Elections and would be responsible for advising on the implementation of new canvassing and ballot curing regulations to ensure compliance with state and federal law.

The OSP investigates and prosecutes criminal offenses related to the electoral process. The bill's changes to ballot processing rules and the management of multiple ballots from a single individual are relevant to the agency's enforcement mission regarding election integrity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS) by excluding certain lump sum retroactive salary increases from the definition of 'earnable compensation'. It requires the SRPS Board of Trustees to pay out accumulated contributions to the beneficiaries or estates of nonvested former members who die before withdrawing them. Additionally, it provides an explicit list of high-level state positions, such as department secretaries and various agency heads, that qualify for immediate vesting rights.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Members and former members of the Maryland State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), beneficiaries of deceased nonvested members, and specific state executive officials including department secretaries and agency directors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no discernible effect on State pension liabilities or contribution rates. The provision regarding deceased nonvested members aligns the law with current administrative practice, and the list for immediate vesting is clarifying in nature. Excluding certain retroactive lump sum payments from 'earnable compensation' may result in a negligible reduction in pension liabilities. There is no impact on local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the administration of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), this bill directly impacts their operations by redefining 'earnable compensation', setting requirements for the payment of contributions to deceased nonvested members' estates, and clarifying vesting rules for high-level officials.

As the principal personnel agency for the state, DBM oversees employee benefits and policies. Changes to the definition of 'earnable compensation' and vesting rights for state officials directly interact with the personnel and benefits management functions of this department.

The bill contains a specific provision (Section 3a) exempting certain lump sum payments made by the Maryland Department of Transportation between July 1, 2022, and July 1, 2023, from the new 'earnable compensation' definition, provided contributions were already made.
The bill clarifies immediate vesting rights for various cabinet-level secretaries and heads of offices that serve at the Governor's pleasure or are appointed by the Governor.
The bill specifically identifies the Adjutant General of the Military Department as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Board of Contract Appeals
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Chair of the State Board of Contract Appeals as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Chair of the Public Service Commission as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Chair of the Workers' Compensation Commission as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Chief Administrative Law Judge of the Office of Administrative Hearings as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Director of the Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Director of the Maryland Energy Administration as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Director of the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Director of the Office of Homeland Security as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the Director of the Office of Performance Improvement as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Director of the State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Executive Director of the Governor’s Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services (managed by this office) as an official who receives immediate vesting rights.

The bill identifies the Executive Director of the Governor's Office of Community and Crime as an official who receives immediate vesting rights; this relates to the community engagement leadership role of GOCI.
The bill specifically identifies the Insurance Commissioner of the Maryland Insurance Administration as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Special Secretary of the Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the State Archivist as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.
The bill specifically identifies the State Prosecutor as an official who receives immediate vesting rights upon taking office.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the maximum dollar thresholds for defining small procurements in State contracting. The general threshold for small procurements is raised from $50,000 to $100,000, while specialized thresholds for construction and maintenance contracts within the Department of General Services, the Maryland Department of Transportation, and the Department of Natural Resources are increased from $100,000 to $200,000.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Board of Public Works and primary procurement units, including the Department of General Services, the Maryland Department of Transportation, and the Department of Natural Resources.
qa_results.stakeholders: State procurement agencies, contractors, small businesses, and minority-owned businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no material effect on State finances, although State agencies may see improved administrative efficiency by using simplified procurement methods for more contracts. There is no local fiscal impact and a minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Board to review labor and material costs every three years and recommend appropriate adjustments in the small procurement ceiling to the General Assembly.
DGS is explicitly mentioned in the bill for an increased small procurement threshold for construction contracts, from $100,000 to $200,000.
MDOT is explicitly mentioned in the bill for an increased small procurement threshold for construction contracts, from $100,000 to $200,000.
The bill explicitly raises the small procurement threshold for DNR capital projects or maintenance contracts from $100,000 to $200,000.
The bill explicitly increases the small procurement threshold for the agency's expenditures on medical evaluations and related physician testimony from $50,000 to $100,000.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Changes to small procurement definitions directly impact the Small Business Reserve (SBR) and Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) programs overseen by this office.
As a primary procurement unit and the state's fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for the regulations and oversight of the administrative efficiencies described in the bill.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller is responsible for the periodic review and recommendation of procurement threshold adjustments.
As a member of the Board of Public Works, the Treasurer participates in the mandated triennial review of procurement labor and material costs.
OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits and must ensure state agencies are operating within the newly established small procurement dollar limits.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Family Prosperity Act of 2023 permanently extends and expands the Maryland earned income tax credit and the state child tax credit. It maintains the state refundable earned income credit at 45% of the federal amount, removes the $530 refund limit for individuals without qualifying children, and expands the $500 child tax credit to include residents with children under age 6 or children with disabilities whose federal adjusted gross income is $15,000 or less.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-to-moderate income Maryland residents, families with children under age 6, families with children with disabilities under age 17, and local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues decrease by an estimated $172.3 million in FY 2024 and $186.5 million by FY 2028 due to the expanded tax credits. General fund expenditures increase by approximately $37,000 in FY 2024 for the Comptroller's Office to hire a revenue examiner to process additional claims. Local income tax revenues are projected to decrease by $6.1 million annually starting in FY 2024.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for administering income tax credits, including the Maryland earned income credit and the State child tax credit. The fiscal note indicates the agency requires an additional revenue examiner to process and validate the increased volume of claims resulting from the expanded eligibility and removal of credit limits.

This team is specifically charged with addressing the Governor's top priorities of reducing child poverty and enhancing economic mobility. This bill is a cornerstone administrative policy designed to achieve those exact outcomes through targeted tax relief for low-income families.

As an Administration bill (By Request - Administration), the Governor's Office led the policy development and coordination for this legislation. It directly implements the executive branch's priority to provide economic support to Maryland families.

DBM oversees the state's fiscal health and revenue estimation. This legislation has a significant impact on General Fund revenues, estimated at over $170 million annually, which must be incorporated into the state's budget and long-term fiscal planning.

The mission of this office is to promote the well-being of children and families with a specific focus on reducing child poverty. The expansion of these tax credits is a direct legislative tool to accomplish the office's core mission.

DHS serves Maryland residents in economic need. The bill provides direct financial assistance via tax refunds to the same low-income population served by DHS, complementing the department's social service and economic assistance programs.

As the state's chief financial agency, the Treasurer is responsible for managing state funds. The substantial reduction in state income tax revenue impacts the cash flow and fiscal management duties of the office.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the executive branch and would be involved in reviewing the legal sufficiency of this priority administration legislation and advising on its implementation.

The bill maintains specific eligibility pathways for children with disabilities aged 6 through 16 to receive the state child tax credit, directly impacting the population the department is tasked with advocating for and serving.

The Maryland Tax Court adjudicates appeals from the decisions of the Comptroller. New eligibility definitions and expanded credit thresholds may lead to a higher volume of contested tax cases requiring the court's review.
The bill explicitly utilizes the definition of a 'child with a disability' as established under § 8-401 of the Education Article to determine tax credit eligibility for certain dependents.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill, known as the Access to Banking Act, establishes the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund as a state instrumentality. The fund is designed to improve financial services and access to capital in low- to moderate-income census tracts by investing in innovative financial products and underwriting technologies. To support the fund, the Commissioner of Financial Regulation is authorized to provide initial equity and matching investments, while banking institutions and credit unions are offered assessment offset credits for maintaining or opening branches in underserved areas.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Commissioner of Financial Regulation
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland-chartered banking institutions, credit unions, and small businesses and residents located in low- to moderate-income census tracts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund expenditures are estimated to increase by approximately $2.8 million in FY 2024, covering an initial $2.5 million investment, administrative startup costs, and matching funds. Special fund revenues are expected to decrease by an estimated $171,000 in FY 2024, growing to $310,000 by FY 2028, due to the implementation of assessment offset credits for financial institutions. The bill does not have a fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor's Office of the Commissioner of Financial Regulation (OCFR) is the primary agency responsible for establishing, governing, and investing in the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund. The Commissioner oversees the assessments, provides offset credits, and manages the fund's regulatory framework.

The State Treasurer is designated as the custodian of the Banking Institution and Credit Union Regulation Fund, which provides the initial $2.5 million equity capital investment and $250,000 in administrative funding for the new venture fund.

The bill requires that costs and expenses for regulating banking institutions and credit unions be included in the State budget and allows for expenditures via budget amendments, which fall under DBM's oversight.

This is an Administration bill proposed by the Governor to address banking deserts and economic mobility. The Governor's Office coordinates the high-level policy initiatives that this bill implements.

The fund's purpose is to enhance access to capital and financial services for businesses in low- to moderate-income tracts, aligning with the Department of Commerce's mission to stimulate the economy and support small business expansion.

As the chief legal representative for state agencies, the OAG would be involved in provide legal counsel regarding the establishment of the Maryland Community Investment Venture Fund as a new state instrumentality.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically targets enhancing access to capital for businesses in low- to moderate-income tracts, which are often the focus of this office's mission to connect small and minority businesses to economic opportunities.

The bill focuses on community investment and revitalization in low- to moderate-income areas, which overlaps with DHCD's role in financing small business development and municipal infrastructure in under-invested communities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies several energy programs managed by the Maryland Energy Administration. It extends the Electric Vehicle Recharging Equipment Rebate Program through fiscal year 2026 and increases its annual funding cap to $2.5 million. It significantly expands the Medium-Duty and Heavy-Duty Zero-Emission Vehicle Grant Program by increasing the mandated annual appropriation to $10 million for fiscal years 2024 through 2027, raising the maximum grant amount to 75% of the incremental cost of a vehicle, and prioritizing commercial use and environmental justice communities. Furthermore, the bill increases the cap on administrative expenses for the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF) and redirects certain compliance fees toward transportation greenhouse gas reduction efforts and energy efficiency for low-income populations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Energy Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals, business entities, units of local government, commercial and industrial vehicle operators, and residents of low-income or environmental justice communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill increases special fund expenditures from the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF) by approximately $7.75 million in FY 2024, $7.5 million in FY 2025 and 2026, and $5 million in FY 2027. This includes a mandated annual appropriation of $10 million for the Medium-Duty and Heavy-Duty Zero-Emission Vehicle Grant Program starting in FY 2025. The bill also increases the administrative expense cap for the SEIF from $5 million to $7.5 million. Local governments may benefit from increased grant and rebate availability for electric vehicle infrastructure and heavy-duty vehicles.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MEA is the primary agency responsible for administering the programs modified by this bill, including the Electric Vehicle Recharging Equipment Rebate Program, the Medium-Duty and Heavy-Duty Zero-Emission Vehicle Grant Program, and the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF).

The bill utilizes funding from the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) allowances and references environmental justice definitions found in the Environment Article, which is overseen by MDE. The programs aim to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, a core part of MDE's mission.

This is an administration bill that aligns with the Governor's policy priorities regarding climate change and clean energy. The Governor's annual budget is also required to include specific mandated appropriations for the programs mentioned.
DBM is responsible for the state budget, which must now include a mandated $10 million annual appropriation for the Medium-Duty and Heavy-Duty Zero-Emission Vehicle Grant Program as per the bill.
The bill's focus on zero-emission vehicles and electric vehicle charging infrastructure directly impacts Maryland's transportation strategy and goals managed by MDOT and its modal administrations.
The bill modifies the use of Alternative Compliance Payments (ACPs) which are generated under the Renewable Energy Portfolio Standard (RPS), a regulatory framework managed by the Commission.

As the agency managing state-owned facilities and the state vehicle fleet, DGS is impacted by the availability of rebates and grants for electric vehicle infrastructure and zero-emission vehicles for state units.

DHS receives a significant portion of SEIF proceeds for energy assistance programs; modifications to SEIF administrative caps and revenue allocations directly affect the funding available for these services.

The bill provides grants for commercial and industrial zero-emission vehicles and equipment, which supports business development and the state's economic competitiveness in the green technology sector.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MEA and other state agencies regarding the implementation, regulation, and enforcement of the energy programs modified by the bill.
The Treasurer's Office manages and protects state funds, including the Strategic Energy Investment Fund (SEIF) which is the primary funding source for the bill's initiatives.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller oversees the collection of revenues and sits on the Board of Public Works, which may oversee major contracts or expenditures related to these programs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Office of Statewide Broadband (OSB) within the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) to conduct a study and make recommendations on incentives to expand broadband infrastructure to unserved or underserved communities in Maryland. The study must examine regulatory and financial incentives, strategies for deploying federal broadband infrastructure grants, and private investment models used in other states. OSB must submit its findings and recommendations to the Governor and the General Assembly by January 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of Statewide Broadband within the Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Broadband service providers and Maryland residents in unserved or underserved communities
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures for the Department of Housing and Community Development may increase by a limited amount in FY 2024 to hire consultants for the study, with costs estimated between $100,000 and $150,000. However, the department may be able to absorb these costs within existing resources. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Office of Statewide Broadband (OSB), which is tasked with conducting the study and submitting the report, is a unit within the Department of Housing and Community Development.

The bill requires the Office of Statewide Broadband to submit its findings and recommendations directly to the Governor, who oversees executive branch policy priorities such as infrastructure expansion.
As the agency responsible for the state's telecommunications strategy and infrastructure, the study on broadband expansion directly aligns with their core mission and expertise.

As the principal fiscal agency, DBM oversees budget execution and personnel for the Department of Housing and Community Development and would be involved in evaluating the fiscal impact of any recommended financial incentives.

The study evaluates financial incentives for broadband expansion; the Comptroller, as the state's chief financial officer, is involved in revenue collection and was originally tied to the tax-related provisions of this bill.
Broadband infrastructure is a key asset for economic development and business attraction, and the Department of Commerce previously oversaw the rural broadband funds now managed by OSB.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Housing and Community Development and would advise on the regulatory and legal frameworks for the incentives proposed in the study.
The council focuses on the unique infrastructure and economic challenges of rural counties, which are the primary unserved or underserved communities targeted for broadband expansion in this bill.

The bill specifically requires a study on how to best deploy federal broadband infrastructure grants, an area where the Governor's Grants Office provides central coordination and technical assistance.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes the Build Our Future Grant Pilot Program and Fund within the Maryland Department of Commerce. The program provides grants to private companies, nonprofits, local governments, and higher education institutions for infrastructure projects that support innovation in specific technology sectors, such as biotechnology, cybersecurity, and advanced manufacturing. Grantees must provide matching funds and demonstrate the ability to cover project costs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Private technology companies, nonprofit organizations, local governments, and Maryland colleges and universities involved in technology sectors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $10 million annually from fiscal 2024 through 2027, with special fund revenues and expenditures for the Build Our Future Grant Fund increasing by a corresponding amount. Local governments and public institutions of higher education will see increased revenues and expenditures if they receive grants and provide required matching funds.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Commerce is the primary agency responsible for administering the Build Our Future Grant Pilot Program and its associated fund, including awarding grants and reporting on economic impact.
The State Treasurer is required by the bill to hold the Build Our Future Grant Fund separately and to invest the money of the fund.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the Build Our Future Grant Fund as established by the bill.
DBM is responsible for the state's budget and personnel; the fiscal note indicates a significant $10 million annual general fund appropriation managed by DBM is necessary to support this program.
This is an Administration bill requested by the Governor, who also receives the periodic reports on the program's progress and economic impact.
Colleges and universities are eligible grant recipients under the program, and the commission oversees the policies and standards for these institutions.
As a system of public higher education institutions, its members are eligible recipients for infrastructure grants under the program.
As a public university, Morgan State is an eligible recipient for grants to support innovation infrastructure projects.
As a public college, St. Mary's is an eligible recipient for grant funding under the pilot program.
TEDCO's mission to foster technology-based businesses and commercialization overlaps significantly with the program's goal of supporting infrastructure for innovation technology sectors.
Cybersecurity and Artificial Intelligence are explicitly listed as eligible technology sectors for the infrastructure grants.
Agriculture is listed as one of the eligible technology sectors for infrastructure projects funded by the program.
The 'Energy and Sustainability' sector is eligible for grants, aligning with MEA's mission to promote renewable energy and efficiency.
'Blue technology' is listed as an eligible sector, which involves innovation in Maryland's waterways and marine resources managed by DNR.
Infrastructure projects in the 'Energy and Sustainability' sector may fall under MDE's environmental protection and regulatory domain.
The grants can be used for specialized workforce training and skill certification spaces, which are key components of the Department of Labor's mission.
The program supports specialized workforce training infrastructure, which aligns with the board's strategy for developing Maryland's talent pipeline.
The Board of Public Works oversees significant state expenditures and procurement contracts, which may include larger grant allocations from this fund.
DGS oversees the planning and construction of state-owned facilities; it may be involved if grants are used for infrastructure projects at public colleges or universities.
MEDCO's role in real estate development and financing for economic projects may be leveraged for infrastructure projects funded by these grants.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Agricultural & Resource-Based Industry Development Corp.
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MARBIDCO's support for agricultural and seafood industries overlaps with the 'Agriculture' and 'Blue technology' sectors identified in the bill.
The team incubates novel initiatives to address the Governor's priorities, which include the innovation economy goals established in this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office monitors socioeconomic procurement programs across state agencies, which may apply to the grant-funded infrastructure projects and procurement activities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the Maryland income tax subtraction modification for military retirement income received by individuals. For the 2023 taxable year, the first $25,000 of military retirement income is exempt from the state income tax, and for taxable years beginning after 2023, the exemption amount increases to the first $40,000 of military retirement income.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland military retirees and their families
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to decrease by $11.2 million in FY 2024, with the annual loss increasing to $13.1 million by FY 2028. Local income tax revenues are expected to decrease by approximately $7.3 million in FY 2024, growing to $8.6 million by FY 2028. The total revenue reduction in FY 2024 is estimated at $18.5 million.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's chief tax collector, the Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for implementing and managing the proposed income tax subtraction modifications and monitoring the resulting revenue impacts.
This is an Administration bill (Keep Our Heroes Home Act) representing a key policy initiative of the Governor to enhance economic mobility and retain veterans within the state's workforce.

As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for revenue estimation and budget supervision; the bill's significant impact on general fund revenues (over $11 million annually) directly affects state budget planning.

This agency is the primary advocate for Maryland's veterans; the bill provides a direct financial benefit to its core service population by expanding state-level tax exemptions for military retirement income.

Commerce is the primary economic development agency and evaluated the bill's impact on small businesses and Maryland's regional competitiveness in attracting and retaining a highly trained veteran workforce.
The Adjutant General oversees the Maryland National Guard; the bill explicitly includes retirement income from Guard service in the expanded tax subtraction modification.
Membership in the Maryland National Guard is explicitly defined in the bill as a qualifying category of service for the enhanced military retirement income tax subtraction.
The Treasurer manages state funds and serves on the Board of Revenue Estimates, which tracks the fiscal impacts of changes to the state's income tax revenue.
The Tax Court adjudicates appeals from the final decisions of the Comptroller regarding tax assessments and subtraction modifications, which may arise from the implementation of this bill.
MD Labor oversees workforce development; the bill supports their mission by incentivizing highly trained veterans to remain in the Maryland workforce through targeted tax relief.
The GWDB sets the statewide vision for the workforce system, and this bill aligns with their strategy to maintain a robust talent pipeline by retaining skilled military retirees.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Governor and the Comptroller's Office regarding the enforcement and constitutionality of state tax laws and modifications.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the number of resident judges of the Circuit Court for Baltimore County from 20 to 21.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Baltimore County and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $365,900 in FY 2024 for one additional judge, one courtroom clerk, and one law clerk. Future year expenditures increase annually, reaching an estimated $530,200 by FY 2028. Additionally, Baltimore County expenditures increase for operating expenses and salaries for an administrative assistant for the new judge.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Administrative Office of the Courts serves as the central support agency for the Maryland Judicial Branch, providing operational and financial support. It is responsible for managing the budget and staffing, including the law clerk and courtroom clerk positions, for the new circuit court judgeship established by this bill.

The Governor has the constitutional and statutory authority to appoint judges to fill vacancies in the circuit courts. This bill creates a new judicial seat in Baltimore County that the Governor must fill through the appointment process.

The Office of Appointments assists the Governor by recruiting and vetting candidates for judicial vacancies. The creation of an additional judgeship will require the office to manage the recommendation and vetting process for the newly created position.

This agency administers the pension system for judges and state employees. The addition of a new judge and two staff positions increases the number of active participants and the long-term pension liabilities managed by the agency.
The Comptroller's office is responsible for processing the payroll for state employees, including the salaries for the newly created judgeship and the associated support staff funded by the state.

As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM oversees the state budget and fiscal planning. The bill requires an increase in general fund expenditures for judicial salaries and benefits, which impacts the overall state budget execution.

The Treasurer's Office acts as the custodian of state funds and manages their distribution. The office is responsible for the disbursement of the state funds required for the salaries and operational costs of the new judicial positions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a comprehensive regulatory and licensing framework for the adult-use cannabis industry in Maryland. It renames the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission to the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission and creates the Maryland Cannabis Administration as an independent unit of State government responsible for oversight. The bill implements a 9% sales and use tax on adult-use cannabis, creates the Office of Social Equity to support individuals and communities historically impacted by cannabis prohibition, and establishes several funds for community reinvestment, business assistance, and public health.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Cannabis Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Adult-use and medical cannabis consumers, cannabis business owners and applicants (growers, processors, and dispensaries), social equity applicants, minority and women-owned businesses, and local Maryland jurisdictions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to increase starting in FY 2024 from 9% sales and use tax collections, with estimated revenues of $18 million in FY 2024 growing to over $64 million by FY 2027. Special fund revenues will increase from licensing fees and tax distributions into the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund and the Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund. State expenditures will increase to support the operations of the Maryland Cannabis Administration, tax collection by the Comptroller, and a $5 million mandated annual appropriation for the Social Equity Partnership Grant Program beginning in FY 2025.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Maryland Cannabis Administration as an independent unit of State government responsible for the regulation and oversight of the cannabis industry, making it the primary implementing agency.

The Comptroller is responsible for collecting the 9% sales and use tax on adult-use cannabis and administering the Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund and the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund.
The Department of Commerce administers the Cannabis Business Assistance Fund and establishes the Capital Access Program to provide financing and loans for social equity licensees.

The bill transfers medical cannabis regulation from the Natalie M. LaPrade Medical Cannabis Commission (under MDH) to the new administration and involves MDH in administering the Cannabis Public Health Fund.
MEDCO is tasked with identifying, acquiring, and constructing or refurbishing facilities to be used as incubator spaces for the Maryland Incubator Program.
The Governor appoints the Director of the Maryland Cannabis Administration, members of the Alcohol, Tobacco, and Cannabis Commission, and the Executive Director of the Office of Social Equity.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the new administration and consults on the identification of disproportionately impacted areas for fund distribution.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding and investing the various special funds established by the bill, including the CREF and the Medical Cannabis Compassionate Use Fund.
DGS assumes ownership of constructed incubator facilities and is responsible for contracting with non-profits to operate these spaces.
OLA is required to conduct periodic audits of the newly established special funds, including the Cannabis Regulation and Enforcement Fund and the Community Reinvestment and Repair Fund.
The Secretary of State Police serves as an ex officio member of the ATCC, and the Field Enforcement Division is authorized to enforce cannabis tax and licensing laws.
OAH is responsible for adjudicating contested cases related to license or registration denials and regulatory violations within the cannabis industry.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOSBA is responsible for establishing minority business enterprise (MBE) participation goals and procedures for procurement related to the cannabis industry.
The bill establishes legal protections and safe harbors for insurance companies and producers providing financial services to cannabis-related legitimate businesses.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS, through its central repository, performs state and national criminal history records checks required for all cannabis license applicants, owners, and agents.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Advisory Board on Medical and Adult-Use Cannabis to provide recommendations on guidelines and regulations for the industry.
MDA may enter into an MOU to test cannabis at existing State-owned laboratories and is involved in the definition and regulation of hemp versus cannabis.
The AOC provides information regarding cannabis possession charges used to define and identify disproportionately impacted areas.
The BPW oversees the certification agency for the MBE program and is consulted regarding remedial measures and disparity studies related to cannabis licensing.
DBM oversees the transfer of budgeted positions and unexpended appropriations from the previous commission to the new administration.
The MVA provides the valid identification required for age verification at dispensaries and is involved in highway safety initiatives related to cannabis impairment.
Commission members and the Executive Director must file financial disclosure statements with the State Ethics Commission to ensure compliance with conflict of interest laws.
The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in vetting and recommending candidates for the ATCC and the Advisory Board on Medical and Adult-Use Cannabis.
As a division of MDH, OCSA remains involved in the registration and inspection context for medical practitioners who certify patients for medical cannabis.
MDOT serves as the certification agency for the State's MBE program, which is applied to cannabis licensees, and manages motor vehicle laws regarding driving under the influence.
The bill provides grants for HBCUs and research registrations for institutions of higher education to conduct bona fide cannabis research projects.
Morgan State, as an HBCU, is eligible for grants and research partnerships under the bill's provisions for business development and academic study of cannabis.
MHEC coordinates with institutions of higher education that may seek registration as research entities for cannabis projects.
The agency manages the retirement and merit status of employees transferred from the Natalie M. LaPrade Medical Cannabis Commission to the new administration.
The Tax Court serves as the highest level of administrative review for disputes involving the collection of the new adult-use cannabis sales and use tax.
The Medical Cannabis Compassionate Use Fund provides reduced-cost cannabis access for individuals in the Veterans Affairs Maryland Health Care System.
DoIT provides IT support for the Comptroller's new revenue reporting systems for cannabis-related taxes.
The bill establishes distance requirements for dispensaries relative to schools and child care centers and mandates educational programs about cannabis for schools.
The administration must adopt labor standards for growers regarding disputes and conditions of employment, which falls under the broader scope of PERB’s collective bargaining administration.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the residency requirements for individuals applying for alcoholic beverages licenses in Carroll County on behalf of partnerships, corporations, clubs, or limited liability companies. It requires that at least one applicant be a resident of the State of Maryland, rather than the county, at the time of application and for the duration of the license's validity.
qa_results.responsible_party: Carroll County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Applicants for alcoholic beverages licenses in Carroll County, including partnerships, corporations, clubs, and limited liability companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact. The bill is not anticipated to materially affect Carroll County operations or finances, and the impact on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the state's principal regulator for the alcohol industry. The bill explicitly references § 4–108, which mandates the use of application forms required by the Comptroller for alcoholic beverages licenses in Carroll County.

The Governor's Office is responsible for signing legislation into law and overseeing the executive branch, including the appointment of members to state boards such as the Carroll County Board of License Commissioners.

The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in the recruitment and vetting of candidates for state boards and commissions, which includes the Carroll County Board of License Commissioners responsible for administering these licenses.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Governor, the General Assembly, and all state boards and commissions, including those regulating alcoholic beverages, on the interpretation and enforcement of state laws.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the seating requirements for Class B, Class BR, and Class C beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Carroll County by allowing up to 15 seats at bars or counters to be included in the calculation of the 50-individual minimum seating requirement for hotels, restaurants, and clubs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Carroll County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and operators of hotels, restaurants, and clubs in Carroll County who hold or apply for Class B, BR, or C alcoholic beverages licenses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances and is not expected to materially affect Carroll County operations or finances. The impact on small businesses is estimated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor's Office, as the head of the executive branch, is responsible for overseeing state laws and officially signed HB 559, which modifies the seating requirements for certain alcoholic beverage licenses in Carroll County.

The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary agency responsible for regulating the alcoholic beverage industry in the state and enforcing related laws, making the modification of licensing requirements for restaurants and hotels relevant to its regulatory oversight.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill removes the 40-day annual limit on the use of Class C multiple event beer, wine, and liquor licenses in Carroll County and establishes a new fee of $2,000 for licenses covering 41 or more events per year.
qa_results.responsible_party: Carroll County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Carroll County fire departments and arts centers on West Main Street in Westminster
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and is not expected to materially affect Carroll County finances or operations. It establishes a new license fee tier of $2,000 for 41 or more events per year, while the current fees for lower tiers remain unchanged.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary state agency responsible for regulating the alcoholic beverages industry. While this bill pertains specifically to Carroll County, it amends the statewide Alcoholic Beverages Article of the Maryland Code, which falls under the regulatory purview described in the agency's summary.

The Governor's Office is responsible for the final approval and signing of legislation. The Governor signed this bill into law on May 3, 2023, and oversees the executive branch's adherence to state laws including the Alcoholic Beverages Article.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill grants the Town of Mount Airy in Carroll and Frederick Counties urban renewal authority to address slum and blighted areas. It authorizes the town to acquire property through eminent domain for redevelopment, issue general obligation and revenue bonds, levy taxes to fund projects, and dispose of acquired property to private or public entities for rehabilitation.
qa_results.responsible_party: Town of Mount Airy
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and property owners in the Town of Mount Airy, specifically those in areas designated for urban renewal; private developers; and the local governments of Carroll and Frederick counties.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct impact on State expenditures but may result in a minimal increase in State tax revenues if property values or economic activity increase due to revitalization. Locally, the Town of Mount Airy's expenditures may increase for land acquisition and legal fees, while revenues may increase from the sale of properties and a larger property tax base. Carroll and Frederick counties may also experience a minimal increase in tax revenues from successful renewal projects.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DHCD is highly relevant as the state's primary agency for community revitalization, housing assistance, and municipal infrastructure projects. The bill's focus on urban renewal, slum clearance, and redevelopment in the Town of Mount Airy aligns with DHCD's core mission and its role in supporting local government revitalization initiatives.

The Maryland Department of Planning provides technical assistance to local governments on land use and sustainable growth. The bill requires urban renewal plans to conform to the town's master plan, which falls under the advisory and data analysis scope of this agency.

The bill involves the use of eminent domain and judicial orders for property entry (A1-103(6)), which are handled through the Circuit Courts. The fiscal note explicitly identifies the Judiciary as an information source for this legislation.

As the state's primary economic development agency, Commerce is interested in urban renewal projects that stimulate the economy, attract businesses, and enhance local competitiveness, as mentioned in the fiscal note's analysis of economic activity.

The fiscal note indicates a potential increase in state tax revenues (income and sales tax) if the urban renewal projects successfully lead to revitalization and new residents. The Comptroller is responsible for collecting these state revenues.

Urban renewal projects often involve the installation, construction, or relocation of streets and highways. MDOT is relevant if these projects intersect with state-numbered highways or broader regional transportation planning.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and the General Assembly. They may be involved in reviewing the constitutional authority (Article III, Section 61) granted by the bill or defending the state's interests in related legal matters.
Urban renewal and the elimination of blight typically lead to significant changes in property valuations. Property owners may appeal new assessments resulting from these projects to the local PTAAB.
The Governor signed the bill into law and oversees the executive branch's coordination of policy initiatives, including those related to constitutional urban renewal authority.
The Archives is the depository for official state records, including municipal charter changes and the Compilation of Municipal Charters, which is the primary law being amended by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill authorizes holders of a Class 9 limited distillery license in Maryland to obtain a Class 8 liquor wholesaler’s license, enabling them to self-distribute up to 27,500 gallons of their own distilled products annually to retail licensees and permit holders. It also allows these distilleries to sell and deliver manufactured products in bulk to authorized entities inside and outside the State.
qa_results.responsible_party: Alcohol and Tobacco Commission (ATC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Class 9 limited distillery license holders, retail liquor license holders, Maryland liquor wholesalers, and the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are expected to increase minimally beginning in FY 2024, with an estimated $1,800 in the first year and $780 annually thereafter from license, application, and renewal fees. The Alcohol and Tobacco Commission can monitor the additional licenses with existing resources. Local government finances and operations are not materially affected. Small business distilleries may see increased revenues from self-distribution, while some wholesalers may see a negative impact on their revenue.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller's Office is explicitly identified in the bill text (Section 2-308.1) as the authority responsible for approving applications for additional warehousing and distribution locations for Class 8 liquor wholesaler's licenses. Additionally, the provided agency summary states that the Comptroller regulates the alcohol industry in Maryland.

The bill facilitates the expansion of manufacturing and distribution capabilities for Class 9 limited distilleries, directly aligning with the Department of Commerce's mission to retain and expand existing companies and support Maryland's competitive economic position.

Class 9 limited distilleries are often associated with retail hospitality (Class B or D licenses) and serve as recreational and cultural attractions. Changes to their operational and distribution capabilities affect the state's tourism economy, which this office oversees.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note specifically identifies a 'meaningful' impact on small businesses. This office is responsible for connecting small businesses to economic opportunities and monitoring the state's small business landscape.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides counsel to the executive branch and regulatory agencies (such as the Comptroller) regarding the implementation and enforcement of the new licensing and trade practice regulations established by this bill.
DBM is responsible for estimating state revenues and fiscal planning. The bill is projected to have a minimal but direct increase on general fund revenues through new license and application fees.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to allow entities participating in the Overdose Response Program to choose the formulation and dosage of FDA-approved opioid overdose reversal drugs they receive, subject to state budget limitations. It also empowers the Attorney General to create committees within the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council to comply with specific court orders or settlement agreements and mandates that all opioid-related settlement funds be appropriated and distributed according to their respective legal agreements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Entities participating in the Overdose Response Program (such as hospitals and community providers), individuals at risk of opioid overdose, and Maryland political subdivisions entitled to opioid settlement funds.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures for the Maryland Department of Health may increase minimally if entities request more expensive formulations or dosages of overdose reversal drugs. Administrative changes to the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council and fund distribution procedures can be handled with existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Attorney General is specifically authorized to enter into opioid-related settlement agreements, direct the formation of committees within the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council, and establish procedures for those committees. The agency also identifies the controlling versions of settlement agreements.

The Secretary of Health is responsible for establishing and administering the grant program for distributing opioid restitution funds.
