Additionally, the department must manage the Overdose Response Program and allow entities to choose specific formulations or dosages of opioid overdose reversal drugs, subject to budget constraints.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the structure and operational procedures of the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council, which falls under this category. It establishes rules for the creation of committees mandated by court orders or settlement agreements.

The Governor's Office oversees the Opioid Operational Command Center (OOCC), which is explicitly tasked by the bill to provide the staff necessary to support the functions of the Opioid Restitution Fund Advisory Council.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary coordinating body for public safety and criminal justice policy, this office works closely with the Opioid Operational Command Center to manage and allocate funds related to opioid abatement and public safety initiatives.

The bill specifies that expenditures from the Opioid Restitution Fund and the purchase of specific drug dosages by the Department of Health are subject to the limitations of the State budget, which is overseen by DBM.
The State Treasurer acts as the custodian of the Opioid Restitution Fund, managing the receipt and distribution of state funds derived from opioid-related judgments and settlements.
As the state's chief financial officer and a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller oversees the collection and accounting of revenues deposited into the Opioid Restitution Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Access to Mental Health Advisory Committee within the Maryland Higher Education Commission to study and make recommendations regarding mental health services, policies, and barriers at Maryland institutions of higher education.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Students enrolled in Maryland institutions of higher education, including public four-year universities, community colleges, and nonpublic institutions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local expenditures for public institutions of higher education may increase minimally to provide staffing for the committee on a rotating basis. Costs are expected to be higher in fiscal 2024 due to initial reporting requirements. Committee member expense reimbursements are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Access to Mental Health Advisory Committee to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor annually on or before December 1.
The bill entitles committee members to reimbursement for expenses under standard State travel regulations as provided in the State budget, which is overseen and managed by DBM.

The committee is tasked with studying policies regarding mental health care, prevention, and treatment, which intersects with the Maryland Department of Health's role in overseeing behavioral health and healthcare policy across the state.

The bill establishes the Access to Mental Health Advisory Committee specifically within the Maryland Higher Education Commission (MHEC). The Secretary of Higher Education is a mandated member of the committee.
The bill establishes the committee within this agency and mandates the Secretary's participation.

The President of Morgan State University is a mandated member of the committee. Additionally, the university is required to provide staff for the committee on a rotating basis with other participating institutions.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides legal counsel to MHEC and public institutions of higher education regarding the implementation and operation of the newly established advisory committee.

The President of St. Mary's College of Maryland is a mandated member of the committee. The college is also required to provide staff for the committee on a rotating basis with other participating institutions.

The Chancellor of USM is a mandated member and responsible for appointing several committee members (directors of counseling centers and clinical psychologists). USM institutions are also required to provide staff for the committee on a rotating basis.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill creates a new advisory committee within the executive branch structure to conduct studies and make policy recommendations, fitting the definition of this collective entity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill redefines 'creditable service' for Maryland State retiree health benefits to include all service within the Executive, Legislative, or Judicial branches, whether the individual was enrolled in the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS) or the Optional Retirement Program (ORP). This allows employees who have moved between these systems to combine their service years to determine eligibility for health benefits and premium subsidies.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management
qa_results.stakeholders: Current and former Maryland State employees and retirees in the Executive, Legislative, and Judicial branches, particularly those with service credit in both the State Retirement and Pension System and the Optional Retirement Program.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal impact on State liabilities for Other Post Employment Benefits (OPEB). While it may increase the number of retirees eligible for health benefits or higher subsidies by allowing the combination of service credits from different retirement plans, the actual cost increase is expected to be negligible. Benefits are paid on a pay-as-you-go basis, so any fiscal impact would occur in future years. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the principal personnel agency, DBM is responsible for developing and administering the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. The bill directly impacts the eligibility rules for health benefits which this department oversees.

The bill redefines 'creditable service' for health benefits based on enrollment in the several systems of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), which this agency administers. It is responsible for the service records and retirement allowances that determine eligibility.
The bill specifically names the Maryland Transit Administration Retirement Plan and its former employees in the revised definition of 'creditable service' and eligibility for retiree health benefits.

USM is a major employer of individuals who utilize the Optional Retirement Program (ORP). The bill allows these employees to combine service between ORP and the State Retirement and Pension System for retiree health benefit eligibility.

As a state-independent university whose employees participate in the ORP and SRPS, the university is directly impacted by changes in how service time is calculated for its future retirees' health benefits.
As a state agency and public honors college, its faculty and staff participate in ORP or SRPS and are directly affected by the revised service credit rules for retiree health benefits.

The bill explicitly includes service in the Judicial Branch of government for the purpose of health benefit eligibility. The AOC provides operational and financial support for the judiciary branch affected by these changes.

The bill's legislative history indicates it was originally designed to address service credit issues for this commission's employees, and they remain included under the expanded 'Executive Branch' service definition.

MDOT is the parent department of the Maryland Transit Administration (MTA) and a large employer of state personnel. Its modal administrations' employees are subject to the retirement system changes outlined in the bill.
The bill explicitly references the State Police Retirement System in its updated definitions of 'State service' relevant to health benefit calculations.
The bill covers all employees in the Executive Branch, which the Governor's Office oversees, and amends laws regarding the retirement benefits of state personnel.
The Treasurer serves as a key member of the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System and the office manages state funds related to employee benefits.
The Comptroller's office is responsible for paying state employees and retirees, and has a general interest in changes to benefit eligibility that affect state payroll and fiscal planning.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill, known as the Farmers Feeding Families Act, permanently extends a Maryland state income tax credit for qualified farms that donate fresh farm products or certified organic produce to authorized organizations. It increases the tax credit value from 50% to 100% of the value of eligible food donations and from 75% to 100% for certified organic produce, while maintaining a $5,000 annual limit per farm (which may be increased to $10,000 by the Secretary of Agriculture).
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Agriculture
qa_results.stakeholders: Qualified Maryland farm businesses and organizations authorized to receive food donations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to decrease by up to $100,000 annually beginning in fiscal 2025 due to the permanent extension of the tax credit. Fiscal 2024 revenues may also decrease due to the bill's increase in the value of the tax credit. If credits are claimed against the corporate income tax, there will be minimal impacts on the Higher Education Investment Fund and the Transportation Trust Fund, as well as minimal decreases in local highway user revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Agriculture is the primary implementing agency responsible for establishing the wholesale value of donations, certifying tax credit certificate administrators, and reporting annually on the program's impact.

As the state's chief tax collector, the Comptroller is responsible for administering the income tax credit, receiving copies of all issued certificates, and collaborating with the Department of Agriculture on regulations and reporting.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments implementing the bill and receives mandatory annual reports from the Secretary of Agriculture regarding the use and impact of the tax credit program.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Department of Agriculture and the Comptroller's Office to assist in the development of required regulations and the legal interpretation of the tax credit alterations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Green Purchasing Committee (MGPC) to establish specifications for the procurement of compost, mulch, soil amendments, and aggregate made from recycled or organic materials, such as food waste, municipal solid waste, and construction debris. State agencies are required to include these specifications in their procurement solicitations, provided the products are competitively priced, of satisfactory quality, and readily available.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Green Purchasing Committee (MGPC) and the Department of General Services (DGS)
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State agencies, local government units responsible for public land maintenance, and producers or suppliers of organic and recycled materials.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Green Purchasing Committee can develop the required specifications with existing resources. The overall fiscal impact on State expenditures cannot be reliably estimated as it depends on the future price and availability of recycled materials relative to virgin materials. Local governments may see a minimal increase in revenue if the State increases purchases of products derived from municipal solid waste.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DGS is the primary implementing agency; the Secretary of General Services chairs the Maryland Green Purchasing Committee (MGPC), DGS provides staff support for the committee, and the agency is responsible for meeting specific composting and landscaping goals on State property.

MDOT is a major unit of State government that manages extensive public lands and highways; it is a significant purchaser of aggregate (gravel, sand, stone) and mulch for construction and maintenance activities impacted by the bill's specifications.

DNR manages over 500,000 acres of public lands and parks; the agency is a primary user of compost and mulch for land maintenance and was specifically consulted regarding the risks and utility of recycled organic materials on State lands.

MES provides operational and technical services for waste management, recycling, and composting; it manages dredged material and organic waste streams that serve as the raw materials for the products specified in the bill.
MDE regulates the materials used in these products, including municipal solid waste, sludge, and food waste, and coordinates with other agencies on environmental protection and recycling standards.
MDA regulates soil amendments and fertilizers and supports the economic viability of agricultural products, including those derived from organic waste materials mentioned in the bill.
The State Treasurer is a statutory member of the Maryland Green Purchasing Committee, which is tasked with establishing and publishing the procurement specifications required by the bill.
As a State entity with multiple large campuses, USM is responsible for significant grounds maintenance and must include the new specifications in its procurement of landscaping materials.
As a State agency with a large urban campus, MSU must comply with the bill's requirements for purchasing compost, mulch, and aggregate for land maintenance.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS manages numerous correctional facilities with substantial grounds; as a unit responsible for land maintenance, it must follow the bill's procurement specifications.
DVMF manages state veteran cemeteries and the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, requiring ongoing grounds maintenance and procurement of soil amendments and mulch.
MSA manages major sports complexes and public facilities that require intensive landscaping and land maintenance, making the bill's procurement specifications relevant to their operations.
MDP promotes sustainable growth and resource management; it coordinates the Smart, Green & Growing initiative which aligns with the bill's focus on using recycled and organic materials.
DJS operates residential facilities that require grounds maintenance and the procurement of materials covered by the bill's specifications.
DHCD manages community revitalization and infrastructure projects that may involve the procurement of aggregate or soil amendments for landscaping.
MSD manages two campuses requiring grounds maintenance and the procurement of landscaping materials impacted by the bill.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable development and environmental protection, goals directly supported by the bill's requirement for using recycled and organic materials in state procurement.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners to exchange certain Class B-D-7 beer, wine, and liquor licenses for Class A-7 licenses in specific geographic areas and removes previous geographic and temporal restrictions on the issuance of Class A-7 licenses. It also updates the requirements for a marketplace license in the 41st legislative district by extending the timeline for establishments to open and allowing the sale of alcoholic beverages for off-premises consumption.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders in Baltimore City, marketplace developers and operators in the 41st district, and businesses in the 41st and 43rd legislative districts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances and does not materially affect Baltimore City operations or finances. While the bill involves annual license fees—$1,500 for Class A-7 licenses and $6,000 for marketplace licenses (plus additional fees for entertainment and outdoor service)—the overall fiscal impact is described as minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the principal state official responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and enforcing tax laws related to alcoholic beverages. Although this bill primarily concerns the actions of the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners, it amends the state's Alcoholic Beverages Article which falls under the Comptroller's regulatory and tax collection oversight.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and is responsible for signing or vetoing legislation. The Governor signed this bill into law, making it part of the state's administrative and legal framework for Baltimore City.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the Comptroller and boards authorized by state law. They may be involved in interpreting the changes to the Alcoholic Beverages Article or defending the state's regulatory framework in court if licensing decisions are challenged.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits a court from charging fees to a person or governmental unit for the purpose of recording and indexing a restitution order as a money judgment, regardless of which Maryland court originally issued the order.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary (Administrative Office of the Courts)
qa_results.stakeholders: Crime victims (individuals and governmental units) entitled to restitution and the Maryland court system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State fee revenues may decrease, but the impact is expected to be minimal and will not materially affect State operations or finances. There is no anticipated material impact on local government operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the central support agency for the Maryland Judicial Branch, the AOC is responsible for overseeing court operations, including the assessment of court costs and the recording of judgments. This bill directly prohibits the courts from assessing specific recording and indexing fees.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP coordinates public safety and victim services. Since restitution is a primary mechanism for victim compensation, the office has a policy interest in removing administrative fees that may act as a barrier for victims or governmental units recording restitution orders as money judgments.

The bill affects restitution orders issued by courts, which includes those involving child respondents in the juvenile justice system managed by DJS. DJS supervises youth who may be subject to these restitution orders.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS oversees the Division of Parole and Probation, which handles the supervision of adult offenders and the collection/monitoring of restitution payments. Changes to how these orders are recorded as civil judgments impact the overall restitution enforcement framework.

The OAG serves as the legal representative for state agencies (governmental units) that may be recipients of restitution. The bill benefits these state entities by exempting them from costs when recording restitution orders in any court in the state.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller is responsible for the collection of state revenues. While the fiscal impact is expected to be minimal, the bill's prohibition on certain court fees technically affects state revenue streams.

DBM is the principal fiscal agency for the state and oversees the execution of the state budget. It monitors changes to fee structures and revenues, even when the fiscal impact is anticipated to be non-material.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and policy initiatives. The Governor signed this legislation into law, reflecting an alignment with executive priorities regarding criminal justice and administrative efficiency.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Health and Human Services Transportation Improvement Act of 2023 establishes the State Coordinating Committee for Health and Human Services Transportation to coordinate transportation services for the elderly, individuals with disabilities, and others who are transportation-disadvantaged. The bill also removes the annual funding caps for the Maryland Senior Rides Program and the Job Access and Reverse Commute Program, requiring the Governor to provide funding for the latter in the annual state budget.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-to-moderate income seniors, individuals with disabilities, and transportation-disadvantaged residents needing access to employment and healthcare.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures from the Transportation Trust Fund increase by $180,000 in FY 2024 and $80,000 annually thereafter to hire consultants to support the new coordinating committee. While the bill repeals funding limits for the Maryland Senior Rides Program and the Job Access and Reverse Commute Program, it does not mandate specific appropriation amounts, leaving additional funding at the discretion of the Governor. Local government finances are not materially affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDOT is the primary agency responsible for the bill's implementation. The Secretary of Transportation chairs the newly established State Coordinating Committee for Health and Human Services Transportation, and the Maryland Transit Administration (a unit of MDOT) administers the Maryland Senior Rides and Job Access and Reverse Commute programs, both of which have their funding caps repealed by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This bill establishes a new permanent body, the State Coordinating Committee for Health and Human Services Transportation, to coordinate state efforts regarding a cooperative health and human services transportation system.

The Secretary of Aging is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee. Additionally, the bill repeals the grant cap for the Maryland Senior Rides Program, which directly facilitates transportation for the department's target population.
The Secretary of Health is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee, which is tasked with examining transportation needs for medical and health-related appointments.
The Secretary of Human Services is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee and the bill involves transportation services for populations often served by DHS.

The Secretary of Disabilities is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee. The committee's mandate specifically includes examining the needs of individuals with disabilities and those who are 'transportation-disadvantaged'.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee.
The Secretary of Planning is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee.
The Secretary of Veterans Affairs is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee.
The Secretary of Labor is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee, and the bill affects the Job Access and Reverse Commute Program, which connects residents to employment areas.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Director of the Office is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee.
The Executive Board Chair of the Council is a designated member of the State Coordinating Committee.

The Governor is responsible for appointing additional members to the Coordinating Committee, receiving its annual reports, and is mandated to provide funding for the Job Access and Reverse Commute Program in the state budget.

As the agency responsible for state budget development, DBM is impacted by the bill's removal of funding caps and the mandate for the Governor to include funding for specific transit programs in the annual budget.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows retirees of the State Police Retirement System, Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System, and Judges’ Retirement System who retired on or before December 31, 2012, to convert their reduced optional retirement allowance to an unreduced basic allowance if they later married a same-sex designated beneficiary. This conversion provides the surviving spouse with a full spousal benefit and includes retroactive adjustments and interest.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Retirees and surviving spouses of the State Police Retirement System (SPRS), Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS), and Judges’ Retirement System (JRS) who retired before 2013 and subsequently married a same-sex designated beneficiary.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have a minimal effect on State pension assets and no discernible effect on State or local pension contribution rates. Expenditures involve prospective restoration of unreduced allowances and retroactive lump-sum payments with 4% annual interest for a small number of eligible participants (estimated fewer than 109 accounts total). There is no effect on revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Retirement Agency is the primary agency responsible for the administration and management of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), including the State Police, Law Enforcement Officers, and Judges systems mentioned in the bill. The agency is specifically tasked with processing the conversion requests, verifying documentation, and calculating retroactive payments.

The Administrative Office of the Courts provides support for the Judicial Branch. Retirees of the Judges' Retirement System, which the AOC supports, are directly impacted by the bill's provisions regarding same-sex survivor benefits.

The Maryland State Police is the primary agency for members of the State Police Retirement System. Its retirees are specifically named as beneficiaries of the benefit corrections provided by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: A significant portion of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System (LEOPS) is comprised of individuals from the Division of Parole and Probation and other units within DPSCS. These retirees are directly impacted by the changes to surviving spouse benefits.
The Natural Resources Police are members of the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System (LEOPS). Retirees from this force are among those eligible for the benefit conversion described in the bill.
The MDTA maintains its own police force, whose members participate in the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System (LEOPS). Retirees from this agency are eligible for the benefit adjustments.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the Maryland State Retirement Agency. It would likely be involved in interpreting the application of this law and ensuring compliance with state and federal equity standards.

The Comptroller serves as a key member of the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System and also employs law enforcement officers in the Field Enforcement Bureau who are members of LEOPS.
The State Treasurer serves as a member of the Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System and oversees the management and distribution of state funds, including pension assets.

As the state's principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM is responsible for long-term fiscal planning and overseeing personnel policies, including those related to state employee retirement benefits.

The bill addresses a historical inequity in retirement benefits for same-sex couples, which falls within the Commission's mission to protect civil rights and prevent discrimination based on sexual orientation.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives. The bill requires gubernatorial approval and involves corrections to state law to align with broader executive policies on marriage and equity.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits discrimination in the sale or rental of a dwelling to an individual with a disability who has, obtains, or retains a service dog or a retired service dog. It exempts these individuals from lease provisions prohibiting dogs, prohibits additional rent or fees for the service dog, and allows retired service dogs to remain in the dwelling for the remainder of their lives, while holding the owner liable for any damages caused by the dog.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Commission on Civil Rights
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with disabilities who use service dogs, owners of retired service dogs, landlords, property managers, and home sellers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect Maryland State or local finances or operations. The impact on small businesses is estimated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Commission on Civil Rights (MCCR) is the primary agency responsible for enforcing the state's anti-discrimination laws in housing. This bill directly amends the human relations article that MCCR administers, specifically regarding housing discrimination against individuals with disabilities using service dogs.

As the principal state agency for coordinating services and improving life for residents with disabilities, this department is highly relevant because the bill expands and clarifies housing rights and protections specifically for individuals with disabilities who utilize service animals.

The Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH) is explicitly mentioned in the fiscal note as the body responsible for conducting administrative hearings for housing discrimination cases referred by the Maryland Commission on Civil Rights.

The bill references accessibility standards incorporated in regulations adopted by the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD). The agency is also responsible for ensuring safe, fair, and secure housing across Maryland.

The bill allows individuals claiming housing discrimination to file civil actions in circuit court. The AOC provides operational and legal support to the judicial branch which would adjudicate these cases.

The OAG serves as the chief legal officer for the state and provides counsel to state agencies like the Commission on Civil Rights. It also represents the state in civil appeals related to discrimination enforcement.

The Department of Aging protects the rights of older adults and people with disabilities, a demographic frequently utilizing service dogs for mobility or health support, and would likely be involved in advocacy or information dissemination regarding these housing rights.
Many veterans utilize service dogs for physical disabilities or PTSD. This bill directly affects the housing rights of the veteran community served by this department.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advocates for the rights of the Deaf and hard of hearing, many of whom utilize guide dogs or service dogs for access and safety. The bill's protections for service dogs in housing are directly relevant to this constituency.

As the administrative support for the Governor, this office oversees policy initiatives and the executive branch agencies (like MCCR and DHCD) responsible for implementing and enforcing these new housing protections.

qa_results.bill_summary: This emergency bill extends the termination date of the State Board of Nursing (MBON) to July 1, 2025. It temporarily transfers authority over the board's infrastructure operations to the Secretary of Health, requiring the Secretary to manage staff and compensation using general funds while prohibiting the use of board special funds for these administrative purposes until June 30, 2025. The bill also modifies licensure exceptions for nurses who fail exams, mandates the hiring of an external consultant for an independent board evaluation, and staggers the termination of current board members' terms.
qa_results.responsible_party: Secretary of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Registered Nurses (RNs), Licensed Practical Nurses (LPNs), nursing license applicants, the State Board of Nursing, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $8,000,000 in FY 2024 (as provided in the state budget contingent on this bill) and roughly $738,900 in FY 2023 to cover infrastructure costs. Board special fund expenditures decrease for infrastructure but increase by at least $150,000 to hire an external consultant. Special fund revenues continue, allowing the Board of Nursing Fund balance to potentially increase while general funds support operations through June 2025.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) as the Secretary of Health is granted temporary authority over the infrastructure operations of the State Board of Nursing, including employing staff and designating an Executive Director. MDH is also a required partner in developing the Board's action plan.

The Department of Budget and Management (DBM) must be consulted by the Secretary of Health regarding employee compensation for the Board of Nursing. Additionally, DBM is a named partner in the development of the Board's mandatory infrastructure action plan.

The Department of Information Technology (DoIT) is specifically named as a partner in developing the Board of Nursing's action plan, which includes a gap analysis of infrastructure and long-term sustainability needs.

The Governor receives annual reports from the Board, receives the specific report on processing times required by the bill, and holds the ultimate authority for appointments to the Board, the terms of which are specifically altered by this legislation.

This office assists the Governor in the recruitment and vetting of candidates for state boards. The bill terminates the terms of current Board of Nursing members on a staggered basis in 2023, requiring a significant appointment and reappointment process managed by this office.

The fiscal note indicates that the independent evaluation and report required by the bill may serve as the basis for additional recommendations by the Office of Program Evaluation and Government Accountability (OPEGA) within the Department of Legislative Services, which encompasses legislative audit and performance evaluation functions.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Aging (MDOA) to oversee long-term care and dementia care navigation programs and mandates that each local area agency on aging (AAA) establish such a program. The programs are designed to provide cognitive screenings, information and referrals for long-term care services, support for caregivers, and engagement activities for individuals exhibiting symptoms of dementia.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Aging
qa_results.stakeholders: Seniors, individuals with dementia or cognitive impairment, caregivers, Area Agencies on Aging (AAAs), and health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $79,733 in FY 2024 to hire a program manager to oversee the initiative. Starting in FY 2025, the bill mandates an annual appropriation of $2,400,000 to manage and fund the navigation programs locally. For Area Agencies on Aging that are units of local government, revenues and expenditures will increase beginning in FY 2025 as they receive and distribute the mandated funds.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Governor is required to include a mandated appropriation of $2.4 million in the annual budget starting in FY 2025 and will receive annual reports from the Department of Aging regarding the navigation programs.

The Comptroller, as the state's principal tax collector and financial officer, is responsible for the accounting and distribution of the mandated $2.4 million in funding to local Area Agencies on Aging.
The Treasurer's Office manages the state's funds and anticipates monetary needs, which includes overseeing the fiscal management of the $2.4 million mandated annual appropriation.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Department of Aging and the Department of Health to ensure the new long-term care and dementia care programs comply with state and federal laws.

The Department of Aging is the primary agency responsible for overseeing and training staff for the long-term care and dementia care navigation programs, disseminating best practices, and submitting annual performance reports.

The Department of Budget and Management must oversee the $2.4 million mandated appropriation, manage the creation of a new program manager position, and ensure long-term fiscal planning for the programs.

The department's mission to coordinate services for individuals with disabilities is relevant as dementia care navigation involves addressing the needs of residents with significant cognitive impairments.

The bill requires navigation programs to be guided by the Virginia I. Jones Alzheimer's Disease and Related Dementias Council, which is located within the Department of Health, and involves coordination of chronic disease services.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Virginia I. Jones Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias Council is an executive advisory body whose recommendations are mandated by the bill to guide the navigation programs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the reporting and termination dates for the Workgroup on Black, Latino, Asian American Pacific Islander, and Other Underrepresented Behavioral Health Professionals. Specifically, it moves the deadline for the workgroup to submit its findings and recommendations to July 1, 2024, and extends the workgroup's legal existence until June 30, 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Maryland Department of Health and the University System of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Black, Latino, Asian American Pacific Islander, and other underrepresented behavioral health professionals; students at Maryland institutions of higher education studying behavioral health; and residents in underserved communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has a minimal fiscal impact. State expenditures for staff support and member expense reimbursements for the Maryland Department of Health and the University System of Maryland are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health is a primary implementing agency for the bill; the Secretary of Health appoints several members and designates the chair, and the department is responsible for providing staff to the Workgroup.

The University System of Maryland (USM) is a primary implementing agency, providing joint staff for the Workgroup. Additionally, the presidents of three USM institutions (Bowie State, Coppin State, and UMES) are designated members.
The President of Morgan State University, or their designee, is a mandated member of the Workgroup established by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill extends the duration and reporting requirements for a specific Workgroup, which falls under this collective entity of state advisory and study bodies.
The Workgroup is tasked with assessing and making recommendations regarding students at institutions of higher education who are studying to become behavioral health professionals.
The Workgroup is required to submit its findings and final report to the Governor.
The department is responsible for state personnel and travel regulations; the fiscal note mentions that members are entitled to travel reimbursements which would be processed under DBM's oversight.
The Workgroup includes representatives who provide social services in the state, which is the primary mission of DHS.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Program and a corresponding special fund within the Maryland Department of Commerce. The program is designed to provide competitive grants ranging from $25,000 to $500,000 to small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises (SMEs) in Maryland. These funds are intended to help manufacturers adopt advanced 'Industry 4.0' technologies, such as robotics, artificial intelligence, cloud computing, and advanced sensors, as well as to support related infrastructure and employee training.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Commerce
qa_results.stakeholders: Small and medium-sized manufacturing enterprises (SMEs) in Maryland and their employees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by approximately $1.1 million annually from fiscal 2025 through 2028. This includes a mandated $1 million annual appropriation to the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Fund and roughly $123,000 for the Department of Commerce to hire one program manager to administer the program. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase by $1 million annually as the mandated funding is received and distributed as grants. The bill has no material impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include a specific appropriation of $1,000,000 in the annual budget bill for the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Fund for fiscal years 2025 through 2028.
The bill requires the Comptroller to account for the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Fund, a special nonlapsing fund established by the legislation.
The bill mandates that the State Treasurer hold the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Fund separately and invest its money in the same manner as other state funds.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Department of Commerce and would be involved in reviewing the regulations required by the bill and the memorandum of understanding for program administration.
As the agency responsible for budget development and execution, the Department of Budget and Management must manage the $1 million mandated annual appropriation for the new grant program.

The bill establishes the Industry 4.0 Technology Grant Program and Fund within the Department of Commerce, making it the primary agency responsible for administration, regulation, and grant distribution.
The bill allows the Department of Commerce to enter into a memorandum of understanding with a state-chartered corporation, such as MEDCO, to administer the grant program.
The bill allows the Department of Commerce to enter into a memorandum of understanding with a state-chartered corporation, such as TEDCO, to administer the grant program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program by expanding the types of financial assistance available to include loans and credit enhancements, rather than just grants. It allows developers to apply for assistance at the time a project is proposed instead of waiting until completion, expands eligibility to include projects in designated 'sustainable communities,' and removes previous restrictions that capped assistance at 35% of construction costs.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD)
qa_results.stakeholders: Affordable housing developers, individuals and business entities engaged in residential construction or rehabilitation, and owner-occupants in low-income census tracts and sustainable communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's changes do not directly affect State operations or finances. According to the Fiscal Note, funding for the Appraisal Gap from Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program has not been budgeted since the program’s enactment in 2021. There is no impact on local government finances or small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) is the primary agency responsible for administering the Appraisal Gap From Historic Redlining Financial Assistance Program, developing its regulations, and managing the distribution of financial assistance.

The bill expands the program to 'sustainable communities' and requires projects to comply with local development and land use plans, areas where the Department of Planning provides oversight, data, and policy guidance.

The Board of Public Works oversees significant state expenditures, and because the bill expands the forms of financial assistance to include loans, guarantees, and other credit enhancements, the board may be involved in approving specific disbursements or contracts.
As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for the state budget and would oversee the fiscal impact and funding allocations for this program within the DHCD budget.
The OAG provides legal counsel to DHCD and would be responsible for reviewing the new regulations required by the bill to ensure they comply with state law.
The team's mission to enhance economic mobility and address child poverty aligns with the bill's goal of closing the appraisal gap caused by historic redlining in underinvested communities.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable development and community revitalization, which directly overlaps with the bill's expansion of financial assistance for projects in sustainable communities.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates the policy priorities, such as housing equity and redlining, that this bill and program implementation support.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Human–Relevant Research Fund and a corresponding grant and loan program within the Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO) to promote research into human-relevant alternatives to using nonhuman animals in medical and product testing. It requires research facilities in the State that conduct animal testing and submit federal APHIS Form 7023 to pay an annual contribution to the Maryland Department of Health, with fees ranging from $5,000 to $75,000 based on the number of animals used, to support the fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Technology Development Corporation (TEDCO) and the Maryland Department of Health (MDH)
qa_results.stakeholders: Research facilities including public and private higher education institutions and small businesses that conduct animal testing or research.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Special fund revenues for the Human-Relevant Research Fund (HRRF) are estimated to increase by as much as $915,000 annually starting in FY 2024, with special fund expenditures increasing correspondingly for grants, loans, and TEDCO's administrative costs (estimated at $180,000). State higher education expenditures increase by $120,000 annually due to required payments from public institutions, and local government expenditures increase by $5,000 annually for the Community College of Baltimore County.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: TEDCO is the primary agency responsible for administering the Human-Relevant Research Fund and establishing the associated grant and loan program to support research into animal testing alternatives.

The Department is responsible for collecting the annual research contributions (fees) from facilities that conduct animal testing and research, and distributing those funds to the Human-Relevant Research Fund.

Several member institutions, including the University of Maryland (College Park and Baltimore campuses), Towson University, and Frostburg State University, are research facilities that utilize animal testing and will be required to pay significant annual contributions under this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates the Human-Relevant Research Review Board, an independent scientific body authorized to evaluate and rank research proposals and make funding recommendations to TEDCO.
The State Treasurer is responsible for holding the Human-Relevant Research Fund separately and investing the money in the fund in the same manner as other State money.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the newly established Human-Relevant Research Fund.
The Governor is authorized to include annual appropriations for the Human-Relevant Research Fund in the state budget and will receive annual progress reports from TEDCO and the Review Board.
DBM will oversee the fiscal implementation and potential budget appropriations for the Human-Relevant Research Fund and its administrative costs within TEDCO and MDH.

The OAG provides legal counsel to TEDCO and MDH and will likely be involved in drafting or reviewing the required memorandums of understanding regarding state ownership and intellectual property rights for funded research.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands eligibility for the Edward T. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program to include surviving spouses of U.S. Armed Forces members who died as a result of military service after December 7, 1941, or were declared a prisoner of war or missing in action as a result of the Vietnam conflict.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Higher Education Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Surviving spouses of U.S. Armed Forces members who died in service or were POW/MIA in the Vietnam conflict, and Maryland postsecondary institutions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill expands eligibility for a scholarship program with a $4.0 million mandated annual appropriation starting in fiscal 2024. State general fund expenditures and special fund revenues and expenditures are estimated to increase by $7,700 per additional award annually. If the mandated appropriation is exhausted, general fund expenditures will likely increase to cover all eligible students.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Commission is the primary agency responsible for the administration, funding allocation, and regulatory oversight of the Edward T. Conroy Memorial Scholarship Program, and must update its regulations to reflect the bill's expanded eligibility criteria.

This agency is responsible for assisting military families in securing educational benefits; the bill directly impacts the surviving spouses of service members by expanding their eligibility for state scholarships.

As a system of public higher education institutions, its member schools are responsible for identifying eligible students, verifying their status, and reporting enrollment data to the Higher Education Commission for funding allocation.
As an independent public university, it is responsible for identifying eligible students, verifying their status, and reporting data to the Higher Education Commission for scholarship funding.
As a public honors college, it is responsible for identifying eligible students, verifying their status, and reporting enrollment data to the Higher Education Commission for scholarship funding.
As the state's budget agency, it oversees the fiscal impact on the general fund, which is expected to increase due to the higher volume of scholarship awards necessitated by the bill.
The office provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the Higher Education Commission, which will be required for the implementation of new eligibility regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill allows a utility account holder who is a victim of abuse to terminate their future liability under a utility contract by providing written notice and specific documentation, such as a protective order or a report from a qualified third party. Utilities are required to allow the account holder to open a new account at a new location regardless of any existing account balance or arrearage from the former premises.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Utility account holders who are victims of abuse and utility companies including electric, gas, water, and sewage disposal companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Public Service Commission and local utilities can implement the bill's requirements using existing resources. There is no significant impact on State or local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission (PSC) is the primary regulatory body for the utilities affected by this bill, including electric, gas, water, and sewage disposal companies. The bill mandates changes to how these utilities manage contracts and accounts for victims of abuse, and the PSC is responsible for overseeing utility compliance.

The Office of the People's Counsel represents the interests of Maryland's residential utility consumers. This bill establishes significant new protections for a specific class of residential consumers (victims of abuse) regarding contract termination and account mobility.

The Department of Human Services (DHS) operates local departments whose social workers and caseworkers are designated as 'qualified third parties' capable of providing the documentation required for account termination. Furthermore, DHS administers energy assistance programs that directly interact with utility account balances and arrears.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office coordinates victim services and public safety policy for the Governor. The bill's provisions regarding protections for victims of domestic violence and abuse align with their mission and they were consulted during the fiscal and policy analysis.

The bill requires utilities to accept final peace orders or protective orders issued by the courts as documentation for contract termination. The Judiciary is responsible for the issuance and management of these records.

The bill identifies licensed physicians and psychologists, who are regulated by boards within the Department of Health, as 'qualified third parties' for providing abuse documentation. MDH also oversees public health and behavioral services for victims of abuse.
Reports from qualified third parties must be signed under the seal of a notary public. The Secretary of State is responsible for the registration and oversight of all notaries public in Maryland.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Public Service Commission and enforces consumer protection laws. They may be involved in interpreting the bill's requirements or addressing utility non-compliance.

The bill references law enforcement records and orders related to abuse as valid documentation. MSP is often involved in the service or enforcement of the peace and protective orders mentioned in the bill.

Disputes between consumers and utilities over the termination of accounts or the opening of new accounts under these specific legal protections could result in contested cases heard by Administrative Law Judges.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the frequency requirements for the physician credentialing reappointment process at licensed hospitals in Maryland. Instead of a mandatory reappointment every two years, hospitals must now conduct the process in accordance with the standards of their specific accreditation body.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed hospitals in Maryland, physicians employed by or with staff privileges at Maryland hospitals, and hospital accreditation bodies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's requirements can be handled using existing budgeted resources. There is no projected impact on local government operations or finances, and no impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Secretary of Health to establish regulations and minimum standards for hospital physician credentialing and reappointment. The Department of Health is the primary licensing and enforcement authority for hospitals in Maryland, including the power to delicense or fine hospitals for non-compliance with these standards.

As an independent regulatory agency within the Department of Health, the MHCC is responsible for planning for the state's health system needs and increasing hospital accountability. Modifications to hospital credentialing standards directly impact the commission's oversight of healthcare quality and access.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Department of Health and the Secretary. It will be involved in drafting the required regulations and representing the state in any enforcement actions or litigation resulting from hospital non-compliance with credentialing standards.

The OAH adjudicates contested cases involving state agencies. If the Department of Health imposes penalties such as delicensure or fines on a hospital for failing to maintain the required credentialing process, the hospital would have the right to an impartial hearing before an Administrative Law Judge at the OAH.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the hospital reappointment process to analyze claims filed against physicians. HCADRO manages mandatory arbitration and records for medical malpractice claims exceeding certain limits, making its data relevant to the documentation required in the credentialing process.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MIEMSS oversees and designates trauma and specialty centers. Hospital credentialing standards are a critical component of the hospital infrastructure and quality controls necessary for these designations.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and the Department of Health. The Governor approved the bill and the office coordinates general health policy initiatives reflected in such legislation.

As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM monitors the fiscal impact of legislation on agency resources. The fiscal note for this bill indicates that requirements can be handled using existing budgeted resources managed by DBM.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the Maryland Public Information Act (PIA) by including an individual's email address in the definition of personal information. It requires custodians of public records to deny public inspection of personal email addresses and telephone numbers for students, state and local government employees, notaries public, and licensed professionals, while allowing for the inspection of business-related contact information under certain conditions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Custodians of public records within Maryland State and local government agencies
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland students, State and local government employees, notaries public, and individuals licensed in regulated occupations or professions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local government finances. Any administrative changes related to processing Public Information Act requests are expected to be handled within existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly amends § 4–332 of the Public Information Act, which governs the inspection of records related to notaries public. The Secretary of State is the primary agency responsible for the registration and oversight of notaries public.

The bill amends § 4–313, which restricts the inspection of student personal information in school district records. The Department of Education oversees the state's public school systems and sets policies regarding student records.

The Commission is explicitly named in § 4–313 as an entity authorized to inspect student personal information (email, phone, address) but is subject to new prohibitions on commercial use and disclosure of that data.

The bill amends § 4–333 regarding the inspection of professional and occupational licensing records. The Department of Labor is the primary agency responsible for licensing various professions and industries in Maryland.

The Department of Health regulates and licenses health care professionals. The bill's changes to § 4–333 regarding the privacy and inspection of licensing records (specifically business vs. personal email addresses) directly impact their regulatory operations.

The MCA is responsible for licensing and compliance for the cannabis industry. The bill's amendments to the Public Information Act regarding licensing records will affect how they manage and disclose contact information for licensees.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides counsel on Public Information Act compliance and publishes the state's PIA manual. They are responsible for interpreting these new privacy requirements for all state agencies.

The bill's provision on employee record privacy (§ 4–331) is specifically subject to Section 21–504 of the State Personnel and Pensions Article, which governs the Retirement Agency's disclosure of retiree information to public employee organizations.

As a custodian of extensive student and employee records, the University System is directly impacted by the new restrictions on the inspection of student personal email addresses and employee personal information.

As an independent public university and state agency, Morgan State is a custodian of student and employee records that are subject to the bill's new privacy requirements for email addresses and phone numbers.
As a public college and state agency, Saint Mary's must comply with the bill's restrictions on the disclosure of student and employee personal email addresses and phone numbers.

The school provides public education and is a custodian of student records. It must comply with the bill's expanded protections for student personal email addresses and telephone numbers in school records.

As the central personnel agency for the state, DBM manages policies related to state employee resources. The bill's restrictions on inspecting state employee personal email addresses and phone numbers impact state personnel data management.

The Judiciary is subject to the Public Information Act and oversees the Clerks of the Circuit Court, who handle notary oaths and related records. The bill's changes to notary record access impact these administrative functions.

The Archives is the central depository for permanent government records. The expanded definition of 'personal information' to include email addresses will impact their redaction and access protocols for both modern and historical records.

The MLDS Center links and analyzes student and workforce data from several state agencies. The change in the legal definition of personal information for students and employees affects their data privacy and governance framework.

The MVA manages millions of records containing 'personal information' as defined by the PIA. The inclusion of email addresses in this definition requires updates to their data protection and disclosure procedures.

The bill includes a specific provision in § 4–313 allowing 'an organization or a force of the military' to inspect student personal information, which directly involves the Maryland Military Department's recruitment or administrative interests.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes full-time sworn deputy sheriffs and correctional deputies at the rank of sergeant and below in the Washington County Sheriff's Office to engage in collective bargaining with the Sheriff and County Administrator concerning wages and benefits. It establishes procedures for certifying labor organizations as exclusive representatives, prohibits strikes, and updates employment discharge criteria to focus on 'police misconduct.' Additionally, it clarifies that special deputy sheriffs in Washington County are not considered State or county employees for purposes of employment security or benefits.
qa_results.responsible_party: Washington County Sheriff, Washington County Administrator, and the Washington County Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Full-time sworn deputy sheriffs and correctional deputies at the rank of sergeant and below in Washington County, the Washington County Sheriff's Office, and the Washington County government.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances. Local expenditures for Washington County may increase minimally if the Sheriff challenges labor organization petitions, requiring shared costs for American Arbitration Association services. Future expenditures may also increase depending on negotiated collective bargaining agreements for wages and benefits, though such funding is subject to approval by the County Commissioners. Local revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill amends Section 2–335 of the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article, which governs the personnel and operational conditions of the Washington County Sheriff's Office. As Sheriffs are constitutional officers that function as part of the judicial system's enforcement arm, the Administrative Office of the Courts tracks such statutory changes impacting judicial branch personnel and court-related proceedings.

As the chief legal officer for state agencies and constitutional officers, the OAG provides counsel to Sheriffs and the General Assembly regarding the legal implications of employment status and collective bargaining. The bill explicitly defines the state vs. local employee status of certain deputies, which is a matter of legal interpretation within the OAG's purview.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office advises the Governor on public safety policy and coordinates law enforcement strategies. The bill's provisions regarding collective bargaining for law enforcement and the definition of 'police misconduct' for dismissal purposes are significant public safety policy matters.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill impacts 'correctional deputies' and specifically references the training standards of the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission (MPTSC), which is administratively housed within this department. Changes to the collective bargaining and conduct standards of correctional personnel and law enforcement overlap with the department's public safety mandate.

The bill authorizes collective bargaining over 'pension benefits.' Since many Maryland law enforcement officers and correctional deputies participate in state-administered pension systems, any negotiated changes in benefits could have administrative implications for this agency.

As the state's principal personnel agency, DBM is affected by the bill's clarification that special deputy sheriffs are not State employees for the purposes of employment security or employee benefits, as this defines the limits of state personnel liability.

As the primary state law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police provides support to and coordinates with local allied law enforcement agencies, such as the Washington County Sheriff's Office, and maintains a general policy interest in the professional standards and labor conditions of the state's law enforcement community.

The bill's definition of 'police misconduct' specifically includes the deprivation of rights protected by the Constitution or laws of the State or the United States, which relates to the Commission's mission to investigate and prevent civil rights violations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes a Class B-GSF (golf simulator facility) alcoholic beverages license in Frederick County. The license allows qualifying golf simulator facilities with at least five bays to sell beer, wine, and liquor for on-premises consumption, provided they meet specific annual gross sales requirements for alcohol, rental fees, and food.
qa_results.responsible_party: Frederick County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Golf simulator facility owners in Frederick County, patrons of these facilities, and the Frederick County Board of License Commissioners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state fiscal impact. Frederick County revenues will increase by approximately $2,250 for each new license issued (consisting of a $750 application fee and a $1,500 annual license fee) and $1,500 for each annual renewal. Enforcement activities are expected to be handled with existing county resources.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This collective entity includes the Board of License Commissioners for Frederick County, which is the primary body authorized by the bill to issue the new Class B-GSF licenses and review the required annual gross sales reports.

The Comptroller is the state's principal regulator of the alcohol industry. As the bill creates a new class of alcoholic beverages license and specific sales ratio requirements, it falls under the Comptroller's broader regulatory and tax collection oversight of the industry.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, including the appointment of officials to various state-authorized boards such as the Frederick County Board of License Commissioners, and the Governor signed this legislation into law.

The OAG serves as legal counsel to all state boards and commissions, including local boards of license commissioners. They would be responsible for providing legal guidance on the interpretation and enforcement of the new license requirements.

The bill has a notable small business impact by providing a new revenue stream for golf simulator facilities and potentially incentivizing the opening of new small businesses in this sector within Frederick County.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the auctioneer's fee that is allowed as an expense of a property tax sale in Garrett County from $8 to $10 for each property sold.
qa_results.responsible_party: Garrett County Government
qa_results.stakeholders: Auctioneers, property owners in Garrett County subject to tax sales, and tax sale purchasers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State finances and does not materially affect Garrett County finances. Auctioneer fees for tax sales are typically included in the sale price as a lien and paid by the purchaser.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: Tax sales in Maryland are judicial proceedings conducted under the supervision of the circuit courts. The Administrative Office of the Courts, which supports the judicial branch, was consulted in the fiscal analysis of this bill.

The Governor's Office is responsible for the final review and signing of legislation, as well as overseeing the executive branch's enforcement of state laws, including the Tax - Property Article amended by this bill.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies and the General Assembly regarding the constitutionality and interpretation of state laws, including changes to tax sale statutes.

As the state's chief financial officer and principal tax collector, the Comptroller maintains a general interest in all state tax statutes, although property tax sales are primarily managed at the local level.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates statutory references for Baltimore City's alcoholic beverages districts to align with the 2022 Legislative Districting Plan rather than the 2012 plan. It requires the Baltimore City Board of License Commissioners to exempt existing license holders from new restrictions if their activities were approved by February 1, 2022, and they have maintained continuous ownership since then.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license holders in Baltimore City, particularly those in the 40th, 41st, 43rd, 44th, 45th, and 46th legislative districts.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on state finances and a minimal impact on local finances. The changes are technical in nature and do not directly affect Baltimore City operations or revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the state's principal regulator of the alcohol industry. As this bill updates the geographic boundaries for alcoholic beverages districts in Baltimore City, it directly impacts the jurisdiction and enforcement activities of the Comptroller's regulatory and tax collection divisions.

The bill defines alcoholic beverages districts as coterminous with the 'Legislative Districting Plan of 2022.' The Board of Elections is the agency responsible for maintaining the districting plan and the voter data associated with those specific boundaries.

The Department of Planning provides the data analysis, technical assistance, and mapping support used to create and define the Legislative Districting Plan. This agency maintains the technical geographic records used to update the boundaries described in the bill.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies and the Board of License Commissioners for Baltimore City. The OAG would be involved in interpreting the legal implications of shifting the districts from the 2012 plan to the 2022 plan.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives. The Governor signed this emergency bill into law as part of the administration's oversight of state and local regulatory frameworks.

The Secretary of State is the official custodian of the state's laws and records, including the legislative references and districting plans that this bill updates within the Annotated Code of Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill changes the timing for the Talbot County Board of Education's annual election of its president and vice president. Instead of electing these officers at the first meeting of the calendar year, the board must now do so at its last meeting of the calendar year or at its December meeting.
qa_results.responsible_party: Talbot County Board of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Talbot County Board of Education and the Talbot County Public Schools community.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no State or local fiscal impact. The bill is procedural in nature and does not directly affect the finances of the State or Talbot County.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the state agency responsible for the oversight and leadership of Maryland's 24 local school systems. As this bill amends the Education Article regarding the internal governance and election timing for the Talbot County Board of Education, it directly concerns the regulatory framework of the public education system overseen by MSDE.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the continuing education requirements for real estate brokers, salespersons, and associate brokers by establishing specific course topics and clock-hour requirements for individuals issued an initial license, while maintaining existing standards for license renewals. New licensees must complete courses in contract writing, brokerage relationships, escrow funds, property management, professionalism, and real estate financing.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Real Estate Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Real estate brokers, salespersons, and associate brokers in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the State Real Estate Commission increase by approximately $42,600 in FY 2024 for IT programming changes ($25,000) and consulting costs ($17,600). Small ongoing consulting costs of approximately $2,200 to $2,500 are expected in subsequent years. There is no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor (MD Labor) houses the State Real Estate Commission, which is the primary body responsible for overseeing the licensing and regulation of real estate professionals. The fiscal note indicates that MD Labor will incur special fund expenditures for IT programming and consulting to implement the new continuing education tracking and course approval requirements mandated by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Real Estate Commission is the principal regulatory body established by the state to manage real estate licensing. This bill directly alters the Commission's statutory duties by requiring it to approve and regulate specific subject matter for continuing education courses for initial licensees, such as contract writing and escrow fund handling.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to all state boards and commissions, including the State Real Estate Commission and the Department of Labor. The OAG would likely be involved in reviewing the new continuing education requirements and assisting in the drafting or review of any related regulations to ensure they comply with the new law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Comptroller and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT) to collaborate to identify ways to improve access to and raise awareness of several property tax benefits, including homeowners', homestead, and renters' tax credits, as well as property tax exemptions for disabled veterans and surviving spouses. The agencies must submit a joint report to the General Assembly by December 1, 2023, outlining recommendations for simplifying application processes and identifying necessary funding for implementation.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller and the State Department of Assessments and Taxation (SDAT)
