qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the method and timing for calculating and remitting administrative fees paid by participating employers to the Board of Trustees of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS). It defines administrative fees based on actual administrative and operational expenses from the second prior fiscal year and requires the Board of Trustees to certify the amounts payable by local employers for the next fiscal year by October 1 each year.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System and the State Retirement Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Participating employers in the State Retirement and Pension System, including State units, local school boards, community colleges, participating governmental units, and public libraries.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is largely procedural in nature and has no material effect on State or local government finances. It changes the basis for calculating administrative fee reimbursements from projected budget amounts to actual expenses incurred in the second prior fiscal year and adjusts the certification and payment schedule.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency responsible for the operation and management of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), this bill directly impacts their administrative funding structure, fee calculation methods, and notification requirements to employers.

The Board of Trustees must certify the pro rata shares of administrative fees to the Secretary of Budget and Management, and the agency is responsible for overseeing the budget execution and personnel resources impacted by these fee changes.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to exercise the right of setoff against any money due to a local employer if they are delinquent in paying their certified share of administrative fees.
The bill mandates that the Governor include an appropriation in the annual budget bill for the administrative fees of the State Retirement and Pension System.
The bill specifically defines 'Library' and includes a provision stating that the State shall pay the pro rata share of administrative fees for each library established under the Education Article.

As the oversight agency for public education and libraries (which are defined by the Education Article), MSDE is relevant because teachers are major participants in the retirement system and libraries have specific fee provisions in this bill.

As a major State unit with a significant number of employees in the retirement system, USM is affected by the requirement that its pro rata share of administrative fees be charged against its specific budget.
As an independent State agency and employer, its budget will be directly charged for its pro rata share of the State Retirement and Pension System's administrative fees under this bill.
As an independent State institution, its budget is subject to the bill's provisions regarding the charging of pro rata administrative fees for system members it employs.
As a State unit within the Judicial Branch, its budget will be charged for its pro rata share of administrative fees for employees participating in the state retirement system.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the State Retirement and Pension System's (SRPS) amortization policy by establishing new, tiered timeframes for paying off unfunded liabilities or accounting for surpluses. Instead of a single deadline for all liabilities, new gains or losses will be amortized over specific closed periods based on their source, such as 15 years for experience gains/losses and 25 years for actuarial assumption changes, to prevent sharp fluctuations in required state contributions as the system's previous 2039 target date approaches.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Retirement and Pension System Board of Trustees
qa_results.stakeholders: State employees, retirees, and Maryland taxpayers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures may experience potential minimal increases in pension liabilities beginning in FY 2024, though these are not expected to significantly change State pension contributions. The bill is designed to reduce future volatility in contribution rates. There is no local fiscal impact, and state revenues are not affected.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary administrative body for the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), this agency is directly responsible for implementing the changes to the amortization of unfunded liabilities and surpluses as dictated by the bill.

As the agency responsible for state budget development and personnel benefits, DBM is directly impacted by changes in pension funding policies, which affect long-term fiscal planning and the state's annual contribution requirements.

The State Treasurer is a key financial officer who serves on the SRPS Board of Trustees and oversees the management and protection of state funds, which includes the fiscal health of the pension system.

The Comptroller serves as a key financial officer and a member of the SRPS Board of Trustees, sharing responsibility for the oversight of state revenues and the financial integrity of the pension system.
The Governor is responsible for proposing the annual state budget, which includes the state's required contributions to the retirement system based on the actuarial rates established under this bill.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Board of Trustees and the Maryland State Retirement Agency to ensure that changes to amortization periods and contribution rates comply with state law.

The OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies and would be responsible for verifying that the Maryland State Retirement Agency adheres to the new statutory requirements for amortizing liabilities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes autonomous vehicle converters to sell, transfer, lease, or resell vehicles that they have modified with automated driving systems, specifically for commercial or industrial use. It also clarifies that these converters are not required to be licensed as vehicle manufacturers, distributors, factory branches, or dealers under the Maryland Vehicle Law.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Transportation Motor Vehicle Administration (MVA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Autonomous vehicle converters, businesses utilizing commercial or industrial autonomous vehicles, and the Motor Vehicle Administration.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect Maryland State or local government operations or finances. Small businesses operating as autonomous vehicle converters may experience a meaningful positive impact through increased sales and revenues due to simplified business operations and reduced direct oversight by the Motor Vehicle Administration.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Transportation and signed this legislation into law, which creates a new regulatory framework for autonomous vehicle converters.

This bill establishes a new legal category for businesses involved in converting autonomous vehicles for commercial and industrial use, which is relevant to the Department's mission to support business growth and innovation in specialized industries.

The bill amends the Transportation Article and directly impacts the Motor Vehicle Administration (a modal administration of MDOT) by changing the regulatory and licensing requirements for vehicle sales and conversions.

The MVA is the primary agency responsible for regulating motor vehicle businesses, including manufacturers and dealers. This bill specifically excludes autonomous vehicle converters from traditional dealer and manufacturer licensing requirements and authorizes them to sell converted vehicles, directly impacting MVA's licensing and oversight duties.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDOT and MVA regarding the implementation and enforcement of vehicle laws and would be involved in interpreting these new statutory definitions and prohibitions.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Reproductive Health Protection Act provides legal protections for "legally protected health care," defined as reproductive health services, medications, and supplies related to pregnancy, contraception, assisted reproduction, and abortion lawful in Maryland. The bill prohibits Maryland courts, state agencies, and law enforcement from assisting out-of-state investigations or legal proceedings related to these services, restricts the Governor from surrendering individuals for such acts, and protects health care practitioners from disciplinary actions by health boards or adverse actions by medical professional liability insurers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary, Governor of Maryland, Maryland Health Occupations Boards, and the Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Health care practitioners, patients seeking reproductive health care, medical professional liability insurers, and State and local government agencies and employees
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's fiscal impact is negligible; it is procedural in nature and not expected to materially affect State or local government finances, revenues, or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly prohibits the Governor from surrendering a person to the executive authority of another state (extradition) for alleged violations related to legally protected health care that would not be a crime in Maryland. The office also oversees the executive branch's compliance with prohibitions on using state resources for such investigations.

The bill imposes new requirements and restrictions on judges and court clerks regarding foreign subpoenas, the compelling of testimony or evidence for out-of-state cases, and the filing of foreign judgments related to legally protected health care.

The bill adds significant provisions to the Insurance Article, prohibiting medical professional liability insurers from taking adverse actions against practitioners for providing reproductive health care. It also requires the Insurance Commissioner to make determinations regarding high-deductible health plan exemptions.

As the primary agency for health policy and regulation, the Department is impacted by the bill's protections for reproductive health services and its oversight of the health care practitioners and boards affected by the legislation.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies on implementing these protections and is specifically mentioned in the provisions regarding applications for ex parte orders to intercept communications (wiretapping), which the bill restricts in certain cases.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly prohibits health occupations boards, which are permanent regulatory bodies within the executive branch, from disciplining or taking adverse actions against practitioners for the provision of legally protected health care.

The bill amends the State Personnel and Pensions Article to define 'legally protected health care' and prohibits the use of state personnel and resources for out-of-state investigations. DBM oversees state personnel policy and budget execution.

As a primary law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police is affected by prohibitions on assisting interstate investigations and the new restrictions on obtaining ex parte orders for communication interception related to protected health care.

The State Prosecutor is one of the specific officials mentioned in the Wiretap and Electronic Surveillance Act provisions that the bill amends to prohibit interceptions for investigations related to legally protected health care.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Health Care Alternative Dispute Resolution Office
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office administers medical malpractice claims; the bill's provisions regarding medical professional liability insurance and the protection of practitioners providing reproductive health care may affect the types or handling of claims under its jurisdiction.

As a state agency that employs health care practitioners and manages medical research and services, USM is subject to the bill's prohibition on using state facilities, personnel, or resources to further out-of-state reproductive health investigations.

As a state agency, the university is prohibited from providing information or expending resources to assist out-of-state investigations seeking to penalize activity related to legally protected health care that is lawful in Maryland.

As a state agency, the college is prohibited from using its facilities, equipment, or personnel in furtherance of out-of-state investigations related to legally protected health care services provided in Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date of the Maryland Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) Program by one year, from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2025. It also extends the deadlines for several related requirements and reports, including the disparity study used to justify the program, and MBE participation mandates for offshore wind projects, video lottery terminals, and brokerage/investment services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor's Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs and the Maryland Department of Transportation (Certification Agency)
qa_results.stakeholders: Minority-owned and women-owned business enterprises, state procurement units, offshore wind project developers, video lottery operators, and investment management service providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. Extending the due dates for the disparity study and related analyses does not change the total cost of those studies, and the extension of program termination dates is considered technical and procedural in nature.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency responsible for implementing and monitoring the State's Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) Program, it is the primary entity impacted by the extension of the program's termination date, reporting requirements, and the development of new policies and guidelines for capital projects and investment services.

As the state's designated MBE certification agency, MDOT is responsible for conducting disparity studies and analyses mandated by the bill, including those related to offshore wind projects, public-private partnerships, and brokerage services.

The Board of Public Works oversees significant state procurements and designates the MBE certification agency. The bill explicitly mentions the Board's authority to adopt regulations regarding the disparity study and confidential information.

The bill requires the Office of the Attorney General to be consulted in the development of MBE policies, guidelines, and disparity study analyses to ensure compliance with constitutional and federal requirements.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives. The Special Secretary of the Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (housed within the Executive Department) has major implementation duties under this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill extends the termination date for Minority Business Enterprise Program application to video lottery terminal (VLT) licensees, which the agency regulates.

The Commission is involved in the approval of offshore wind renewable energy credits, and the bill extends MBE participation requirements and reporting deadlines related to these projects which the Commission oversees.
As a central procurement authority, DGS is directly impacted by the extension of the MBE Program's requirements for state-owned facility construction and other goods and services contracts.
As the state's principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM oversees budget execution and procurement policies that must comply with the extended MBE Program requirements.
The bill extends deadlines for studies regarding brokerage and investment management services used by the State Retirement and Pension System, which this agency administers.
The Comptroller serves as a key member of the Board of Public Works, which oversees the MBE program's execution and the certification agency.
The State Treasurer is a member of the Board of Public Works, which has oversight of the state's procurement contracts and the MBE program.
The University System of Maryland is a major state entity that must comply with the MBE program's participation goals for its procurement activities, as noted in the fiscal note.
As a state agency that performs significant procurement, Morgan State University is subject to the MBE program requirements extended by the bill.
Saint Mary's College of Maryland is subject to the MBE program requirements for its state-funded procurement and construction projects.
The Maryland Department of Health is a major executive branch agency that must utilize the MBE program for its procurement of health services and supplies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This department maintains high levels of MBE participation in its procurement contracts, which will be affected by the program's extension.
MSDE is an executive agency that must comply with the MBE program for its procurement activities.
MDE utilizes the MBE program for its environmental infrastructure and service contracts.
DHCD participates in the MBE program for its community revitalization and municipal infrastructure projects.
The Department of Labor is subject to the MBE participation goals extended by this legislation.
DJS is an executive agency that utilizes the MBE program for its facilities and support services.
DHS is a principal department required to implement MBE goals in its social service-related procurements.
DoIT manages statewide IT strategy and procurement, which are subject to the specific MBE goals and subgoals extended by the bill.
DNR is subject to MBE program requirements for its conservation and public land management contracts.
MDP utilizes the MBE program for its land use and cultural program procurements.
The Maryland State Police is an executive agency that must comply with the MBE program for its procurement of equipment and services.
MDA must comply with the MBE program for its regulatory and service-related procurement activities.
The Department of Commerce is subject to the MBE program requirements for its economic development and tourism-related contracts.
MHEC is an executive branch agency that must adhere to MBE participation goals in its operational procurements.
MDoA is an executive branch agency subject to the MBE program's procurement regulations.
The Military Department (led by the Adjutant General) is an executive branch unit that utilizes the MBE program for its facility maintenance and equipment needs.

qa_results.bill_summary: Known as The Josh Siems Act, this bill requires Maryland hospitals to include testing for fentanyl as part of a urine drug screening when such a screening is conducted to assist in diagnosing a patient's condition. Hospitals must report deidentified positive test results to the Maryland Department of Health through the State-designated health information exchange. The bill exempts hospitals that do not possess chemical analyzer equipment.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Hospital patients, hospitals, and the State-designated health information exchange (CRISP).
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State or local governmental operations or finances. No specific funding is allocated as the requirements are expected to be handled within existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that hospitals include fentanyl testing in urine drug screenings and report deidentified results to the Maryland Department of Health (MDH). As the primary regulator of hospitals and the entity responsible for public health policy and the administration of the state's health services, MDH is the central agency for implementation and data collection.

The bill requires reporting through the state-designated health information exchange (HIE). The Maryland Health Care Commission is responsible for designating and overseeing the HIE (currently CRISP), making it integral to the data-sharing infrastructure required by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency serves as the coordinating body for public safety and advises the Governor on criminal justice strategies, including the opioid epidemic. The fentanyl testing data reported to the state will inform their policies and strategies for reducing fatal overdoses.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDH and other state agencies. They may be required to advise on compliance with health privacy laws (HIPAA) and the deidentification of data reported by hospitals.

The bill specifically references state law regarding civil or criminal immunity for individuals seeking medical assistance (the Good Samaritan Law). As the central support agency for the judiciary, the AOC is relevant for interpreting how the mandatory testing results might interact with legal proceedings and immunity protections.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill protects the privacy of reproductive health information by prohibiting health information exchanges, electronic health networks, and health care providers from disclosing medical records related to abortion care and other sensitive health services to out-of-state entities without patient consent. It establishes the Protected Health Care Commission to advise the Secretary of Health on which services require protection, modifies the Public Information Act to protect the identities of individuals associated with abortion facilities, and clarifies that insurance coverage for abortion services must be provided without cost-sharing.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Health Care Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Patients seeking reproductive health services, health care providers, health information exchanges, electronic health networks, and health insurance carriers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures for the Maryland Health Care Commission increase by $100,000 in FY 2024 for contractual services to develop confidentiality policies and standards. Other implementation costs for the Maryland Department of Health and the Protected Health Care Commission are expected to be absorbed within existing resources. The bill may generate minimal general fund revenue from misdemeanor fines of up to $10,000 per day for violations. Local fiscal impact is expected to be negligible.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Protected Health Care Commission within the Department of Health (MDH). The Secretary of Health is responsible for determining diagnostic and medication codes for restricted disclosure and adopting emergency regulations to identify legally protected health care.

The bill expands the MHCC's purpose to include protecting the confidentiality of reproductive health information. MHCC must adopt regulations regarding data restricted on the State-designated exchange and submit quarterly implementation reports. The fiscal note also identifies a $100,000 special fund impact for the agency.

The bill amends the Insurance Article to require insurers, nonprofit health service plans, and HMOs to cover abortion care services without cost-sharing. The Maryland Insurance Commissioner is involved in determining exemptions for federal fund preservation and safe harbor provisions.

The Attorney General (or their designee) is a required member of the newly established Protected Health Care Commission. The OAG also provides legal counsel to the implementing agencies (MDH and MHCC) regarding the new privacy and disclosure restrictions.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a new permanent advisory body, the Protected Health Care Commission (PHCC), which consists of appointed public servants and experts tasked with recommending sensitive health services for protection.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates the policy initiatives related to reproductive health care. The bill also includes changes to the Public Information Act that affect the executive department's transparency and public record custodianship.
HSCRC is referenced as a coordinating entity for the State-designated health information exchange, which is subject to the bill's new data restriction requirements for legally protected health care.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency advises the Governor on public safety and criminal justice strategies. This bill involves policy regarding the investigation of in-state providers by out-of-state entities and mandates misdemeanor penalties for unauthorized disclosure of sensitive records.
The bill establishes a new criminal misdemeanor for knowingly violating disclosure prohibitions, which involves the judicial system for prosecution and adjudication.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's definition of 'health care provider' explicitly includes persons authorized under Section 13-516 of the Education Article (EMS personnel), making them subject to the new medical record disclosure restrictions.
As the principal fiscal agency, DBM oversees the budget execution for the $100,000 in contractual services required by the Maryland Health Care Commission to implement the bill.
As the primary law enforcement agency, the State Police may be involved in investigations related to the newly created misdemeanor for illegal disclosure of protected health records.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program for two years, moving the sunset date from June 30, 2024, to June 30, 2026. It authorizes the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange to provide up to $20 million in annual health insurance subsidies for young adults aged 18 to 40 and requires the Exchange to conduct a study on federal and state subsidies to be reported by December 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Health Benefit Exchange
qa_results.stakeholders: Young adults in Maryland aged 18 to 40, health insurance carriers, and the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures from the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund increase by an estimated $40 million total between FY 2024 and FY 2026 ($10 million in FY 2024, $20 million in FY 2025, and $10 million in FY 2026) to continue the subsidy program. General fund revenues are impacted only to the extent that unspent special funds, which would otherwise revert to the general fund, are instead used for subsidies. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Health Benefit Exchange is the primary agency responsible for establishing, implementing, and administering the State-Based Young Adult Health Insurance Subsidies Pilot Program. The bill extends the program's sunset and requires the Exchange to conduct a study and report to the General Assembly.

The Maryland Insurance Administration is required to consult with the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange on the program's subsidy eligibility, payment parameters, and the mandatory study regarding federal and state subsidies and the Section 1332 waiver.
The State Treasurer's Office is statutorily mandated to hold the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund separately and is responsible for investing the money within the Fund.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund, which receives revenue from premium tax distributions as specified in the bill.
The Department of Budget and Management oversees the state's fiscal planning and the budget amendment procedure through which the Fund's expenditures are authorized for the subsidy program.

The bill amends provisions related to the Maryland Health Benefit Exchange Fund, which provides essential funding for several Department of Health initiatives, including the Medical Assistance Program (Medicaid) and the Senior Prescription Drug Assistance Program.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies involved and is responsible for proposing the annual state budget, which must include the mandatory transfers and appropriations for the funds modified by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires health insurance carriers to cover follow-up diagnostic imaging for lung cancer for individuals recommended by the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force and limits the cost-sharing (copayments, coinsurance, or deductibles) for these services. Additionally, it requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to conduct an assessment of cancer screening outreach, education, and health disparities, including the availability of biomarker testing, and to establish a stakeholder workgroup to provide recommendations on reaching underserved communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and Maryland Insurance Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents with health insurance, health insurance carriers, healthcare providers, and communities underserved by the healthcare system.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Maryland Department of Health general fund expenditures increase by $28,900 in FY 2024 for contractual staff to conduct the required assessment and workgroup. The Maryland Insurance Administration will see a minimal increase in special fund revenues from rate and form filing fees. The fiscal impact on the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program and local governments that purchase fully insured medical plans is indeterminate.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Department of Health (MDH) to conduct a comprehensive assessment of current outreach, education, and health disparities in cancer screening, establish a stakeholder workgroup, and submit a report to the General Assembly.

The bill requires insurers and health maintenance organizations to provide coverage for certain lung cancer screenings and limits cost-sharing. The Maryland Insurance Administration (MIA) is responsible for regulating these carriers and reviewing rate and form filings to ensure compliance.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the establishment of a stakeholder workgroup to advise on the state of cancer screening and make recommendations for outreach to communities impacted by health disparities.
The fiscal note indicates that the bill's insurance mandates apply to qualified health plans offered through the Maryland Health Connection, impacting the plans overseen by the Exchange.
The fiscal note indicates an indeterminate fiscal impact on the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program, which is managed by DBM.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland Insurance Administration regarding the implementation of new laws and the drafting of required regulations.

The bill's assessment and workgroup focus on engaging underserved communities and religious organizations to address health disparities, aligning with GOCI's mission to connect ethnic and faith-based communities with government resources.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs (GOSBA) to develop a weighted scorecard to evaluate State government agencies on their performance in meeting participation goals for Minority Business Enterprises (MBEs) and Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprises (VSBEs). GOSBA must publish the grades achieved by each unit on its website annually and submit this information to the General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor’s Office of Small, Minority, and Women Business Affairs
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State government agencies, Minority Business Enterprises (MBEs), and Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprises (VSBEs)
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State revenues and GOSBA can implement the requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no local fiscal impact and the effect on small businesses is minimal.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency is the primary implementer of the bill, responsible for developing the scorecard, determining the grading scale, and publishing the results on its website.
The Secretary of Transportation is a statutory stakeholder in establishing the statewide MBE goals. The department also acts as the MBE certification agency and will be evaluated by the scorecard.
The Attorney General is a statutory stakeholder in establishing the biennial MBE participation goals that serve as the baseline for the scorecard evaluation.
As a central procurement authority and major state unit, DGS will be significantly impacted by the evaluation and grading of its performance in meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals.
DBM oversees agency performance and fiscal efficiency; it will be evaluated as a state unit and has a broad interest in the fiscal accountability established by the scorecard.
The Governor's Office (Executive Department) is the parent organization for GOSBA and will itself be evaluated as a state unit on the participation goal scorecard.
The Board oversee significant state procurements and previously held authority over the VSBE program; the scorecard measures outcomes related to contracts under its oversight.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As a state cabinet agency, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals as part of the new scorecard system.
As a state agency, its procurement performance will be evaluated and graded under the new scorecard system.
The Adjutant General oversees the Military Department, which is a state unit that will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting participation goals.
As a state regulatory board and unit of government, it will be evaluated and graded on its performance toward meeting MBE and VSBE participation goals.
As a state agency and public university, Morgan State's procurement performance will be evaluated and graded under the new scorecard system.
As the state's public higher education system, its constituent institutions will have their procurement performance evaluated and graded under the new scorecard system.
As an independent public honors college and unit of state government, its procurement performance will be evaluated and graded under the new scorecard system.
This department has an interest in the scorecard outcomes as they evaluate the effectiveness of the Veteran-Owned Small Business Enterprise program across state agencies.
This office utilizes performance metrics to oversee agency accountability and align activities with the Governor's priorities, which overlaps with the goals of the new procurement scorecard.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the procedures for State agencies to submit proposed and emergency regulations, work plans, and evaluation reports to the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review and the Department of Legislative Services. It requires the Division of State Documents to make at least the 15 most recent issues of the Maryland Register available for free online searching and mandates the development of an electronic filing system to submit and track regulations through the approval process.
qa_results.responsible_party: Administrator of the Division of State Documents and the Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State government units, the Joint Committee on Administrative, Executive, and Legislative Review, the Department of Legislative Services, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $124,200 in FY 2024 for a contractual employee and to supplement lost revenue. Special fund revenues for the Division of State Documents decrease by approximately $29,300 in FY 2024 and $39,000 annually thereafter because providing free online access to the Maryland Register is expected to reduce paid subscriptions. There may also be significant costs associated with fixing and finalizing the electronic filing system (ELF 2.0), though these costs are currently indeterminate. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Division of State Documents (DSD) is an office within the Secretary of State. The bill requires the Administrator of DSD to develop and maintain an electronic filing system for regulation tracking, manage the publication of the Maryland Register online for free searching, and coordinate the transmission and receipt of all state regulatory documents.

The bill requires the Department of Information Technology to consult with the Administrator of the Division of State Documents regarding the functionality and security of the new electronic filing system mandated for the submission and tracking of state regulations.

The Office of General Assembly Counsel, which operates under the Attorney General, is tasked with certifying whether proposed changes to regulatory text are nonsubstantive. The OAG also provides legal guidance to all executive units regarding compliance with these revised Administrative Procedure Act requirements.

As the state's principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM is responsible for the budget adjustments identified in the fiscal note, including a $124,200 general fund increase to support new DSD contractual staff and to backfill lost special fund revenue from Maryland Register subscriptions.

As the head of the executive branch, the Governor oversees the various units authorized to adopt regulations. The bill impacts the administrative procedures used by the Governor's subordinates to carry out state laws and requires the Governor to oversee the implementation of the new tracking and filing system.

As a major promulgating unit of state regulations, the department must comply with revised procedures for submitting proposed and emergency regulations, notifying stakeholders of text alterations, and utilizing the new electronic filing system.

As a unit authorized to adopt regulations for workforce development and professional licensing, the agency is impacted by new requirements regarding the 15-day submission window and the procedures for certifying nonsubstantive changes to proposed rules.

The agency regularly adopts extensive environmental regulations and will be required to follow the new protocols for electronic submission, tracking, and the reporting of work plans and evaluation reports to the AELR Committee.

As a major regulatory unit, MDOT must adapt its internal processes to meet the bill's requirements for submitting regulations via the new system and complying with extended review periods for administrative holds.

The department is a unit authorized to adopt regulations and must adhere to the new requirements for notifying the AELR Committee and DLS of substantive changes made to regulations after their initial submission.

The department acts as a unit authorized by law to adopt regulations and is therefore impacted by the operational changes to the regulatory submission process and the requirement to use the DSD's new electronic filing system.

MSDE is an executive unit that adopts regulations and must comply with the bill's new procedures for the submission of proposed regulations and the handling of emergency regulations via the electronic filing system.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department is a promulgating unit that must comply with the bill's revised procedures for filing regulations and notifying the Division of State Documents regarding its intention to adopt regulations following an administrative hold.

The department is a unit authorized to adopt regulations and is impacted by the new requirements for submitting work plans and evaluation reports through the procedures adopted by the Department of Legislative Services.
The department is a unit that adopts regulations and will be required to transition its regulatory submission and tracking activities to the new electronic filing system by October 2023.

As an independent administrative agency that adopts regulations for public utilities, the PSC must comply with the new 15-day submission timelines and the procedures for altering regulation text prior to publication in the Maryland Register.

The Board of Elections is an executive unit that adopts regulations for the administration of elections; it is subject to the new requirements for electronic filing and the revised procedures for certifying nonsubstantive changes.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency serves as a regulatory body that adopts regulations and must follow the updated Administrative Procedure Act requirements for submission to the AELR Committee and DLS.

The commission is an independent agency authorized to adopt regulations and is impacted by the procedural changes regarding the online availability of the Maryland Register and the tracking of regulatory holds.

The MIA is a unit authorized to adopt regulations for the insurance market and must comply with the bill's mandates for the electronic submission of proposed and emergency regulations and the reporting of work plans.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies Maryland's firearm laws by increasing penalties for illegal handgun possession, updating disqualifiers for possessing regulated firearms, and raising fees for handgun permits. It establishes stricter requirements for handgun permits, including more comprehensive in-person training on topics like conflict de-escalation, self-defense law, and suicide prevention. The bill also mandates the Department of State Police to notify registered firearm owners of changes to state laws and requires annual data reporting on firearm crimes and permit issuance statistics.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Handgun permit applicants and holders, Maryland firearm owners, state-certified firearms instructors, and individuals with specific legal or health-related firearm disqualifications.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to increase by approximately $5.3 million in FY 2024 due to increased handgun permit fees ($125 for initial applications and $75 for renewals). General fund expenditures are estimated to increase by at least $2.4 million in FY 2024 to support additional staffing and administrative requirements for the Department of State Police and the State Commission on Criminal Sentencing Policy. Local fiscal impacts on revenues and expenditures are expected to be minimal and related to changes in incarceration penalties.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency for the bill's implementation, the State Police are responsible for the entire handgun permit system, including processing applications, conducting background investigations, performing regular reviews of permit holders, and developing a new firearms safety training curriculum.

OAH is the primary entity for adjudicating appeals from individuals who are denied handgun permits or whose permits are revoked, and it is mandated to issue comprehensive annual reports on these cases.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency manages the Criminal Justice Information System Central Repository, which the State Police must use for mandatory reviews of permit holders; it also manages the correctional facilities that will house individuals convicted under the bill's expanded criminal penalties.

The OAG is required by the bill to consult with the State Police on the development of the new firearms training curriculum and serves as the legal counsel for the state agencies implementing these updated regulations.

The Department of Health must consult on the development of the handgun training curriculum, specifically regarding suicide prevention, and provides the essential mental health data used to determine permit disqualifications.
The judicial branch will handle criminal proceedings for firearms violations and judicial reviews of OAH decisions; the agency also coordinates with sentencing commissions on required data reporting.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Commission on Criminal Sentencing Policy, which falls under this category, is specifically mandated to report annually on charges, convictions, and sentences related to the firearms violations altered by this bill.
The Governor's Office receives several mandated annual reports regarding handgun permits and sentencing data and oversees the principal executive departments tasked with implementing the law.

The Department is responsible for managing the significant fiscal and personnel impact of the bill, which include the addition of 26 new positions at the Maryland State Police and other administrative costs identified in the fiscal note.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill grants the Town of Forest Heights in Prince George's County the authority to exercise urban renewal powers for blight clearance and redevelopment in areas zoned for commercial use. It authorizes the town to acquire property through eminent domain, levy taxes, and issue general obligation or revenue bonds to carry out these urban renewal projects.
qa_results.responsible_party: Town of Forest Heights
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and property owners in blighted commercial areas of the Town of Forest Heights; the Town of Forest Heights local government; and Prince George's County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State finances, though it could lead to a minimal increase in tax revenues. Locally, the Town of Forest Heights may see increased expenditures to acquire land and conduct projects, which may be offset by revenues from property sales and an expanded tax base. Prince George's County may also experience a minimal increase in property, income, and sales tax revenues if urban renewal projects are successful.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DHCD is the state's primary agency for community revitalization and municipal infrastructure support. The fiscal note indicates that DHCD was consulted on this bill, as they provide the types of funding and programs likely used to implement urban renewal in Forest Heights.

MDP provides technical planning assistance to local governments and ensures that local redevelopment plans conform to state sustainable growth policies. The bill specifically requires urban renewal plans to conform to the municipality's master plan, and MDP was a consulted agency for the bill's analysis.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies supporting municipal redevelopment and formally approved the bill into law, authorizing this constitutional delegation of power.
The bill grants the town the power of eminent domain and condemnation. The judicial branch, supported by the AOC, is responsible for adjudicating these proceedings and determining just compensation.

Urban renewal projects involve significant changes to local infrastructure, including the installation, reconstruction, or closing of streets and public utilities which may intersect with state-managed transportation systems.

As the agency responsible for state-numbered highways, the SHA would be impacted by urban renewal projects in Forest Heights that affect the design, traffic flow, or utilities of adjacent state roads.
The bill authorizes the municipality to levy new taxes and assessments. The Maryland Tax Court serves as the highest level of administrative review for disputes related to these local tax actions.

Redevelopment for blight clearance typically involves changes to property valuations and tax exemptions. PTAAB would handle the administrative appeals resulting from changed assessments in the urban renewal area.

MES provides technical and operational services to local governments for hazardous materials cleanup and solid waste management, which are often critical components of blight clearance and urban redevelopment projects.
The bill explicitly authorizes the town to seek federal grants for urban renewal. The GGO assists local governments in identifying and managing such federal funding opportunities.

The urban renewal authority's primary purpose is economic development and blight clearance. The Department of Commerce coordinates state-level economic development efforts that align with these local revitalization goals.
The fiscal note suggests that successful urban renewal may lead to a minimal increase in state tax revenues, which are collected and managed by the Comptroller's Office.
The OAG serves as the state's chief legal officer and would provide counsel regarding the constitutional authority (Article III, Section 61) under which this municipal power is granted.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Prince George's Gateway Development Authority to support the development and approval of a comprehensive neighborhood revitalization plan for a target area within Prince George's County, including the municipalities of Mount Rainier, Brentwood, Cottage City, Bladensburg, Colmar Manor, and North Brentwood.
qa_results.responsible_party: Prince George's Gateway Development Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents, businesses, and municipal governments within Mount Rainier, Brentwood, Cottage City, Bladensburg, Colmar Manor, and North Brentwood.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State or local revenues or expenditures as it does not mandate specific funding. It is assumed that authority members can provide staff and expense reimbursements with existing resources. Small businesses may be impacted by the future implementation of the revitalization plan.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Authority under the Economic Development Article, and the Secretary of Commerce (or their designee) is a mandated member of the Authority. The Authority's mission includes economic development within the target area.

The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a mandated member of the Authority. The Authority's primary purpose is to develop a comprehensive neighborhood revitalization plan, which directly aligns with the agency's mission to support housing and community revitalization.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill creates a new state-authorized body (the Authority) composed of appointed public servants and officials to conduct a specific study and provide recommendations for neighborhood revitalization, which fits the definition of this collective agency entity.

The agency is responsible for promoting sustainable growth and providing technical assistance for comprehensive land use planning. The creation of a neighborhood revitalization plan for multiple municipalities in Prince George's County falls within their area of expertise and policy guidance.
The Authority is required to report its comprehensive neighborhood revitalization strategy to the Governor by October 31, 2025. As an executive branch entity, it falls under the Governor's oversight.

The revitalization plan mandated by the bill must specifically include strategies to benefit transportation, including motor vehicles and pedestrians, which impacts the state's transportation network and planning.

The OAG provides legal counsel to all state agencies, boards, and commissions. The newly established Authority would require legal advice regarding its management of funds, staff, and regulatory compliance.

The bill stipulates that Authority members are entitled to reimbursement for expenses under Standard State Travel Regulations, and DBM manages the state's fiscal planning and personnel policies that govern such expenditures.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires new residential construction of single-family detached houses, duplexes, and townhouses to include infrastructure for electric vehicle charging, such as an EVSE-installed parking space, an EV-ready space, or an EV-capable space. It also mandates the Maryland Energy Administration to conduct a study on the costs and requirements for installing electric vehicle charging infrastructure at multifamily residential buildings and report its findings to the Governor and General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Energy Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential homebuilders, new homebuyers, residents of multifamily housing buildings, and local government permitting agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund expenditures increase by up to $250,000 in FY 2024 only for the Maryland Energy Administration to hire a consultant to complete the required study. Local governments can handle enforcement of the bill's requirements with existing resources. There is no impact on State or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Energy Administration (MEA) is the primary agency tasked by the bill to conduct a comprehensive study on the costs and payment options for electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure in multifamily residential buildings. The fiscal note indicates MEA will require up to $250,000 for a consultant to complete this study.

The bill explicitly requires the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to consult with MEA on the study, specifically regarding projections of the number of electric vehicles in the state through 2050 based on the adoption of California Advanced Clean Cars II regulations.

The bill establishes new standards within the Public Safety Article that amend construction requirements involving the International Building Code and International Residential Code. The Maryland Department of Labor typically oversees the Maryland Building Performance Standards and was consulted as an information source for the fiscal note.

As the agency responsible for ensuring access to safe and affordable housing, DHCD is impacted by new construction mandates that alter the costs and infrastructure requirements for residential developments, including multifamily housing.

The bill's requirements for EV infrastructure interface with utility service requests and electrical load management, which falls under the regulatory purview of the Public Service Commission. The PSC was also identified as an information source in the fiscal note.

DBM is the principal fiscal agency; the bill has a notable fiscal impact requiring a $250,000 special fund expenditure for the MEA study, which falls under DBM's budget supervision and execution responsibilities.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies implementing these policies, and the bill requires MEA to report the findings and recommendations of its study directly to the Governor by December 2023.

The bill utilizes definitions of 'vehicle' from the Transportation Article and relates to broader state efforts regarding zero-emission vehicle infrastructure, which aligns with MDOT's multi-modal transportation responsibilities.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Electric Vehicle Charging Reliability Act requires the Maryland Public Service Commission to expand its Electric Vehicle (EV) Pilot Program to permit electric companies to install charging stations in multifamily dwellings within underserved communities. The bill mandates that electric companies maintain at least a 97% uptime standard for their public EV charging networks, subject to reporting requirements and penalties for noncompliance, and requires utilities to maintain sufficient staff to monitor and repair these stations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Public Service Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Electric companies, residents of multifamily dwellings in underserved communities, electric vehicle owners, and Maryland electricity ratepayers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Public Service Commission can manage the bill's requirements using existing budgeted resources. There is no material impact on State or local government revenues or expenditures. However, electricity rates for all customers (including State and local governments) may increase slightly as investor-owned electric companies are allowed to recover the costs of installing and maintaining the charging infrastructure through their rates.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Service Commission is the primary implementing and regulatory agency for the bill; it is tasked with expanding the EV Pilot Program, establishing uptime standards, receiving and monitoring quarterly utility data, and imposing civil penalties for non-compliance.

The Office of the People's Counsel represents residential utility consumers; the bill is highly relevant as it affects utility service quality (uptime standards) and may lead to electricity rate increases for cost recovery related to infrastructure and staffing.

The Maryland Energy Administration promotes renewable energy and advises on energy policy; this bill directly regulates a significant portion of the state's electric vehicle charging infrastructure and strategy.

The bill mandates the expansion of EV infrastructure specifically into multifamily dwellings in underserved communities, areas that fall under the oversight and community revitalization efforts of this department.

As the agency responsible for the state's transportation network, the reliability and deployment of EV charging infrastructure is critical to the transition to electric vehicles and overall transportation planning.

The Maryland Department of the Environment is responsible for air quality and climate goals; widespread and reliable EV charging infrastructure is a core component of the state's strategy to reduce emissions.

The bill defines 'underserved communities' based on specific Census Bureau data metrics; the Department of Planning provides the demographic data analysis and land-use guidance necessary to identify these qualifying tracts.

The Office of Administrative Hearings adjudicates contested cases for state agencies; it would likely be the venue for utilities to appeal civil penalties or remedial actions imposed by the Public Service Commission under this subtitle.
The Governor's Office coordinates policy initiatives and oversees the executive branch; the bill relates to executive priorities regarding clean energy, environmental justice, and utility regulation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Task Force to study and recommend improvements to the governance, management, and financing of water and wastewater systems in the Baltimore region. The task force is charged with reviewing existing governance models, analyzing fiscal implications of alternative structures, and recommending a model that ensures safe, efficient, and affordable service for the region's 1.8 million residents.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Mayor of Baltimore City and the County Executive of Baltimore County
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and water/wastewater ratepayers in Baltimore City, Baltimore County, Anne Arundel County, Carroll County, Harford County, and Howard County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and Maryland Environmental Service (MES) can consult with the task force using existing resources. Baltimore County and Baltimore City are responsible for staffing the task force and covering expense reimbursements; these costs are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly establishes the Baltimore Regional Water Governance Task Force as a temporary body to conduct a special study and provide recommendations on regional water and wastewater governance.

The bill mandates that the Task Force consult with the Department of the Environment in developing its recommendations and report. MDE also oversees the 10-year water and sewerage plans that the Task Force's findings may impact.
The bill mandates that the Task Force consult with the Maryland Environmental Service, which provides technical and operational expertise in water and wastewater management.
The Governor appoints two members to the Task Force and is a recipient of the final report. The office oversees policy initiatives and intergovernmental relations relevant to regional infrastructure.
The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in fulfilling the statutory responsibility to appoint two members to the newly created Task Force.
The bill allows Task Force members to be reimbursed for expenses under the Standard State Travel Regulations, which are administered by DBM. DBM also monitors fiscal implications for state budgets.

Under current law, the PSC oversees water rate agreements between Baltimore City and Baltimore County. The Task Force's evaluation of alternative governance models directly pertains to the regulatory framework the PSC currently manages.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of Housing and Community Development to establish and maintain a website providing information on the rights and responsibilities of individuals living in common ownership communities, such as condominiums, cooperatives, and homeowners associations. The website must include links to local programs and annual updates on statewide legislation affecting these communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals living in common ownership communities (condominiums, cooperative housing corporations, and homeowners associations) and local common ownership community programs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $90,000 in FY 2024 for the Department of Housing and Community Development to develop the website. Future year expenditures will increase by an indeterminate amount (likely less than $90,000 annually) for maintenance and updates. There is no impact on revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD) and its implementation of new statutory mandates like the establishment of the common ownership community website.
The Comptroller's role as the state's tax collector and financial officer does not directly overlap with the housing-related consumer information or website requirements of this bill.

The Office of the Attorney General's Consumer Protection Division enforces state laws regarding common ownership communities; the mandated website's focus on rights and responsibilities makes the OAG a key resource and stakeholder for the content.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact, requiring $90,000 in general fund expenditures for FY 2024 to develop the website, falling under the fiscal oversight and budget execution responsibilities of this department.

The Department of Housing and Community Development is the primary agency responsible for establishing and maintaining the new website and ensuring it is updated annually with required legislative information and local program hyperlinks.
As the agency responsible for state IT strategy and digital services, DoIT would likely oversee or provide technical guidance for the creation and security of the new mandated website.
The Secretary of State is the official registrar for condominiums in Maryland, which are a primary component of the 'common ownership communities' addressed by this bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Indirect Potable Reuse Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to authorize and regulate the use of reclaimed water as a source for drinking water treatment facilities. The program allows MDE to issue potable reuse permits to public water systems that meet strict treatment and storage requirements, including the use of reverse osmosis, ultraviolet disinfection, and storage in environmental buffers for at least 180 days. The bill also includes reporting requirements to determine if the program should be made permanent.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Public water systems, local governments, Maryland residents using these systems, and small businesses providing water treatment services or equipment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures are estimated to increase by $25,000 in FY 2023 and approximately $139,900 in FY 2024, with annual costs reaching $158,900 by FY 2027 to support contractual engineers for program oversight. State revenues are not affected as the bill does not establish permit fees. Local government expenditures may increase significantly for those that voluntarily participate in the pilot program due to the costs of implementing the required reclaimed water treatment infrastructure.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency for environmental protection and water quality, MDE is responsible for establishing the Indirect Potable Reuse Pilot Program, issuing permits, and regulating the safety of reclaimed water for drinking.

MDH's Laboratories Administration is the primary facility for the state's water testing, specifically for PFAS chemicals, which is a key requirement of the water quality standards established in the bill.
MES provides technical and operational management for water and wastewater systems; it is likely to be a key partner or service provider for jurisdictions implementing the pilot program's technology.
DBM is responsible for the fiscal oversight and personnel management related to the increased state expenditures and the hiring of contractual engineers to manage the program.
The Governor's Office oversees executive branch initiatives and is the recipient of the mandated report regarding the pilot program's status and recommendations for permanent authorization.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like MDE in the development of new permitting processes and the enforcement of the regulatory framework created by the bill.
The Department of Planning provides data analysis and policy guidance for resource management and sustainable infrastructure, which includes the development of alternative drinking water sources.
This multi-agency initiative coordinates sustainable development and resource conservation efforts across state agencies, aligning with the pilot program's goal of reclaiming water.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the time period from 60 days to 180 days during which a person in interest (such as a spouse, parent, or adult child) may request that the medical examiner correct findings and conclusions regarding the cause and manner of death recorded on a death certificate, except in cases of homicide.
qa_results.responsible_party: Chief Medical Examiner (Maryland Department of Health)
qa_results.stakeholders: Spouses, adult children, parents, adult siblings, grandparents, or guardians of deceased individuals; Maryland Department of Health; Office of Administrative Hearings
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no material effect on state revenues. While extending the request period may increase the number of correction requests, the Maryland Department of Health and the Office of Administrative Hearings expect to handle the change using existing budgeted resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is the primary agency impacted as it houses the Office of the Chief Medical Examiner. The Secretary of Health is responsible for receiving appeals when a request for correction is denied and for issuing the final order based on administrative findings.

The bill explicitly requires the Secretary of Health to refer contested cases regarding autopsy finding corrections to the Office of Administrative Hearings (OAH). An Administrative Law Judge within OAH must conduct the hearing and submit findings of fact.

The bill provides that a person in interest may appeal a rejection of their request to a circuit court of competent jurisdiction. The Administrative Office of the Courts supports the judicial branch, which handles these appellate cases.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to the Maryland Department of Health and represents the state in circuit court appeals concerning autopsy corrections and administrative decisions.

The bill contains a specific provision stating that final decisions regarding autopsy findings do not create a presumption concerning insurance policies or claims. This clarifies the legal impact of amended death certificates on the insurance market regulated by the MIA.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS) in the Maryland State Department of Education and the Developmental Disabilities Administration (DDA) in the Maryland Department of Health to enter into a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to share medical and psychological records of mutual clients. The purpose of this data sharing is to expedite decisions regarding eligibility for services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS) and the Developmental Disabilities Administration (DDA)
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with disabilities who are mutual clients of both the Division of Rehabilitation Services and the Developmental Disabilities Administration.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. The Maryland Department of Health and the Maryland State Department of Education indicate that the requirements can be handled within existing resources, as the agencies are already in the process of revising an existing MOU to include data sharing provisions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically identifies the Division of Rehabilitation Services (DORS), which is located within the Maryland State Department of Education, as one of the two primary entities required to enter into and implement the data-sharing memorandum of understanding.

The bill specifically identifies the Developmental Disabilities Administration (DDA), which is an administration within the Maryland Department of Health, as one of the two primary entities required to enter into and implement the data-sharing memorandum of understanding.

As the principal state agency for coordinating services for residents with disabilities and ensuring programs are provided in the most integrated settings, this department has a high level of interest in the coordination and data sharing between DDA and DORS to improve service delivery.

The OAG provides legal counsel to all state agencies, including MSDE and MDH, and would likely be involved in drafting or reviewing the legal terms of the required memorandum of understanding and data-sharing agreement.

As the agency responsible for state data governance and information technology strategy, DoIT may oversee the technical standards and security protocols for the data-sharing agreement mandated by the bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The office advocates for accessibility and addresses policy gaps for deaf and hard of hearing individuals, many of whom are mutual clients of DDA and DORS and would be directly impacted by expedited eligibility decisions.

The bill includes 'school documentation' in the scope of data to be shared. As a state agency providing education to students with disabilities, their records may be part of the shared documentation to facilitate transitions to DORS or DDA services.

The Governor signed the bill into law, and existing statute requires the State Board of Education to report annually to the Governor on the administration of rehabilitation services, which would include the implementation of this MOU.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC) to enter into contracts with the District of Columbia or the District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority to provide water, sewer, and drainage services to certain 'border properties' in Prince George's County. These properties must be located near the D.C. boundary, within a half-mile of a mass transit rail station and a regional transit district or neighborhood center, and lack right-of-way frontage in Maryland to connect to services directly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Washington Suburban Sanitary Commission (WSSC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Property owners and developers of transit-oriented development projects in Prince George's County near the District of Columbia border, and the District of Columbia Water and Sewer Authority.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local finances. While it establishes a framework for WSSC to contract with D.C. entities for service provision, billing, and maintenance at specific properties, the Department of Legislative Services indicates these actions will not significantly impact WSSC's operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's criteria for impacted 'border properties' specifically require proximity to mass transit rail stations operated by the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority (WMATA) and status as an expedited transit-oriented development (TOD) project, both of which fall under the strategic and operational oversight of MDOT.

The bill explicitly references the collection of the Bay Restoration Fee under Section 9-1605.2 of the Environment Article and involves the regulation and oversight of water, sewer, and drainage infrastructure and their environmental health impacts.

The legislation targets land use within regional transit districts and neighborhood centers in Prince George's County, directly involving the agency's mission to promote sustainable growth and manage transit-oriented development policy.

The bill mandates that contracts between the WSSC and District entities include procedures for notifying customers of health and safety advisories regarding their water and sewer service, a matter related to the department's public health protection duties.

The bill facilitates utility infrastructure for multifamily housing and development projects within designated transit districts and neighborhood centers, supporting the department's role in community revitalization and affordable housing.

By enabling utility connections for specific border properties that currently lack frontage on Prince George's County rights-of-way, the bill facilitates transit-oriented economic development and business attraction in the region.

The bill amends the Public Utilities Article of the Maryland Code and establishes specific requirements for utility service contracts, rate-setting procedures, and billing responsibilities for water and sewer services.

This multi-agency initiative coordinates the efforts of the departments of Planning, Environment, and Transportation to promote sustainable land use and transit-oriented development, both of which are central to the bill's objectives.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Environmental and Natural Resources Crimes Unit within the Office of the Attorney General.
