The Treasurer's Office manages the distribution of state funds and would oversee the accounts from which these general fund expenditures are paid.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill funds a reentry employment program, which aligns with the department's core mission of rehabilitating justice-involved individuals and reducing recidivism.
The bill relates to employment incentives and workforce development for a specific population, which falls under the broad policy and regulatory scope of the Department of Labor.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the membership of the Maryland Aviation Commission from 9 to 13 voting members and requires the commission to consider environmental, health, and community impacts when making decisions. It mandates that certain members be recommended by the Anne Arundel and Howard county delegations, requires new member orientation sessions, and subjects the commission to enhanced Open Meetings Act requirements, including live video streaming of meetings.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Aviation Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of communities near state-owned airports (specifically in Anne Arundel and Howard counties), airport employees and their representatives, the air carrier industry, airport concessionaires, and local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures from the Transportation Trust Fund may increase minimally to comply with enhanced Open Meetings Act requirements, such as live video streaming of public meetings. Most requirements of the bill can be handled using existing budgeted resources. There is no projected impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Secretary of Transportation serves as the Chairman of the Maryland Aviation Commission (MAC). The Commission is responsible for directing the department's development and implementation of airport management policies and approving major capital projects.

The Maryland Aviation Commission (MAC) establishes the policies that guide the MAA's operations and its ability to improve and promote BWI Marshall Airport. This bill specifically mandates that the Commission, which governs MAA policies, must work to mitigate negative health and livability impacts of the aviation industry.

The Governor is responsible for appointing 12 of the 13 voting members of the Maryland Aviation Commission. This bill modifies the number of appointees, the composition of the commission, and the specific criteria/recommendations the Governor must follow.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the composition, duties, meeting procedures, and reporting requirements of the Maryland Aviation Commission, which is a permanent executive commission within the state government.

This office assists the Governor in the recruitment and vetting of candidates for state boards and commissions. The bill changes the appointment process for the Maryland Aviation Commission, including a new requirement for recommendations from specific county Senate delegations.
The Secretary of Commerce is designated by law as a nonvoting ex officio member of the Maryland Aviation Commission.
The bill requires that the Maryland Aviation Commission's annual estimate of expenditures be subject to review by the Department of Budget and Management.

The bill subjects the Maryland Aviation Commission to enhanced Open Meetings Act requirements, including live video streaming and specific digital record-keeping. As the agency overseeing the state's IT infrastructure and strategy, DoIT provides the technical framework and support for such compliance.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill clarifies the calculation for the annual General Fund appropriation mandate for the Maryland State Arts Council starting in fiscal year 2025. It specifically defines how funds from the State admissions and amusement tax are treated when calculating growth adjustments for the Council's budget.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Arts Council
qa_results.stakeholders: Arts organizations, local arts agencies, individual artists, public school students, and Maryland residents who participate in cultural arts programs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to have no effect on State expenditures or revenues, as it aligns statutory language with the current interpretation used by the Department of Budget and Management for calculating the Council's funding mandate. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include a specific minimum General Fund appropriation for the Maryland State Arts Council in the annual budget bill, calculated according to a specific growth formula.

The Comptroller is responsible for distributing the State admissions and amusement tax revenue from electronic bingo and tip jars, which is a core component of the Maryland State Arts Council's funding calculation clarified by this bill.

As the principal agency for budget development, DBM is responsible for calculating and executing the mandated appropriation for the Maryland State Arts Council, and the fiscal note explicitly discusses DBM's interpretation of the current funding formula.
The Maryland State Arts Council is part of the Department of Commerce. This bill directly determines the primary funding levels and mandate calculations for this sub-agency.
The bill explicitly states that the Legislative Auditor has the authority to conduct reviews or audits of any recipient of a grant from the Maryland State Arts Council.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Task Force to Study Crime Classification to research and recommend a methodology for classifying and categorizing all existing criminal and civil offenses under Maryland State law.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Office of the Attorney General is responsible for providing staff for the task force.
qa_results.stakeholders: Legal professionals, law enforcement, the judiciary, crime victims, and the general public of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $177,400 in FY 2024 for the Office of the Attorney General to hire contractual staff to support the task force. Expense reimbursements for task force members are expected to be minimal and absorbable within existing resources. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates that the Office of the Attorney General provide staff for the Task Force and names the Attorney General as a member. The fiscal note indicates a significant fiscal impact of at least $177,400 for OAG to hire contractual staff to support the task force's responsibilities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Task Force to Study Crime Classification, which is a temporary body created by the General Assembly to address a specific government issue. This aligns with the definition and function of this collective entity.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Public Defender is a named member of the Task Force. The study on crime classification and categorization is highly relevant to the agency's primary mission of providing legal representation and protecting individual rights in criminal proceedings.
The bill requires the Task Force to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor, who is responsible for overseeing the executive branch and coordinating the state's policy initiatives.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) to hire an independent consultant to conduct a statewide recycling needs assessment and report findings by July 2024. It also establishes a Producer Responsibility Advisory Council to make recommendations for the implementation of a producer responsibility program for packaging materials and requires the MDE to approve a single producer responsibility organization to represent producers.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment
qa_results.stakeholders: Packaging material producers, local governments, recycling and organics recycling processors, and Maryland residents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $532,100 in FY 2024 and $12,100 in FY 2025 to cover the cost of a part-time natural resources planner and a $500,000 independent consultant contract. Although the bill includes provisions for producer registration fees, the fiscal note estimates that state revenues will not be affected. Local governments are expected to consult with the independent consultant using existing resources, resulting in no direct fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and its Office of Recycling are the primary agencies responsible for implementing the bill, including hiring a consultant for the recycling needs assessment, approving the producer responsibility organization, and staffing the advisory council.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Producer Responsibility Plan Advisory Council, which falls under this category of advisory bodies created to provide expertise and recommendations on specific government policy issues.
The bill explicitly requires the Office of Recycling to coordinate with the Maryland Environmental Service (MES) for studies and reporting related to recycling centers and programs.

The results of the recycling needs assessment and the recommendations of the Advisory Council must be reported to the Governor, and the executive branch oversees the implementation of the new producer responsibility program.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the statewide recycling needs assessment to evaluate opportunities in the recycling system for women and minority individuals and businesses.
The Comptroller is responsible for accounting for the State Recycling Trust Fund, which will receive new fees and penalties established by the bill.
The Treasurer is responsible for holding the State Recycling Trust Fund separately and investing the money within it as part of their management of state funds.
The OAG provides legal counsel on new regulations and enforcement actions under the newly created Subtitle 25, and the bill specifically addresses antitrust immunity for program participants.
The bill has a notable fiscal impact and requires the hiring of new contractual personnel within MDE, which involves DBM's oversight of state personnel and budgeting.
The recycling needs assessment must evaluate economic opportunities, business opportunities, and incentives for job growth within the state's recycling industry, which aligns with Commerce's mission.

The bill requires an evaluation of worker conditions, wages, and benefits at commingled recycling processing facilities, which relates to the Department of Labor's role in workplace safety and labor law enforcement.
The bill involves infrastructure evaluation and coordination with local jurisdictions regarding land use for recycling and organics infrastructure, which intersects with MDP's planning functions.
The procurement of the independent consultant to conduct the statewide needs assessment is a significant state contract that may require review and approval by the Board of Public Works.
The OLA is responsible for auditing state agencies and will eventually review the management of the new fees, penalties, and expenditures within the State Recycling Trust Fund.
The bill includes specific exemptions for packaging related to federally regulated drugs and medical devices, an area where MDH provides oversight and coordination.
GOPI is relevant due to the bill's reliance on data-driven assessments and performance goals for producers to improve the efficiency of state recycling services.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands existing child pornography laws to prohibit individuals from knowingly or intentionally accessing and viewing visual representations of children under the age of 16 engaged in sexual conduct, sadomasochistic abuse, or in a state of sexual excitement. It establishes that accessing and viewing these materials carries the same penalties as possession, including misdemeanor or felony charges depending on prior convictions.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Judiciary and the Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals accessing child pornography, law enforcement agencies, the state court system, and victims of child exploitation.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill results in a minimal increase in State and local general fund revenues and expenditures due to the expanded application of existing criminal penalties. First-time offenders are subject to a misdemeanor conviction with up to 5 years imprisonment and/or a $2,500 fine, while repeat offenders face a felony conviction with up to 10 years imprisonment and/or a $10,000 fine. Incarceration costs are estimated at $4,970 per month per inmate for State facilities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill expands the scope of criminal charges related to child pornography, which the judicial branch must adjudicate. The Administrative Office of the Courts is identified in the fiscal note as a source and will be responsible for the operational impact on the court system.

The bill is expected to have a minimal increase on general fund expenditures and revenues. As the principal fiscal agency, DBM monitors state expenditures related to incarceration costs and county reimbursements mentioned in the fiscal note.

DHS is the state's primary provider of child protective services. While this is a criminal law bill, investigations into child pornography often intersect with child abuse and neglect cases managed by local departments of social services under DHS.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill expands criminal penalties that may lead to increased incarceration in state facilities or increased supervision by the Division of Parole and Probation. The fiscal note explicitly mentions the impact on DPSCS expenditures.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies responsible for enforcing this law (MSP) and managing the resulting carceral impact (DPSCS). The Governor also signed the bill into law.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP serves as the state's coordinating body for public safety and criminal justice strategies. This bill aligns with its mission to reduce crime and manage public safety policy.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The OPD is responsible for providing legal representation to indigent defendants. The expansion of child pornography crimes will directly increase the caseload for OPD attorneys, as noted in the fiscal note.
As the primary state law enforcement agency, the Maryland State Police are responsible for investigating criminal violations of the state's child pornography laws.
The OAG represents the state in all criminal appeals. Expanding the definition of child pornography crimes may lead to increased litigation and appellate work for the office.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires that the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program include domestic partners of State employees and retirees. It mandates that terms such as 'spouse', 'family', 'immediate family', and 'dependent' be interpreted to include parties to a domestic partnership, effectively extending health, dental, and other welfare benefits to domestic partners and their dependents.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Budget and Management
qa_results.stakeholders: State employees, State retirees, and their domestic partners and dependents.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures for the Department of Budget and Management (DBM) will increase by an indeterminate amount starting in fiscal 2024 to provide health benefits to new enrollees and to manage administrative updates to eligibility and payroll systems. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DBM is the primary agency responsible for developing and administering the State Employee and Retiree Health and Welfare Benefits Program. The bill directly impacts DBM operations, requiring them to update eligibility rules, contribution tables, and systems of record for enrollees.

As the state's chief paymaster, the Comptroller must implement post-tax payroll deductions and calculate imputed income for domestic partners to comply with IRS W-2 reporting requirements as mentioned in the fiscal note.
The bill impacts the health benefits program for retirees. The SRA manages the records and benefits for state retirees and will need to coordinate with DBM regarding these changes for their members.

The OAG provides legal counsel to DBM and other state agencies. They will be responsible for interpreting the statutory changes and ensuring that regulations regarding domestic partnerships comply with state and federal law.

The bill explicitly includes the Judicial branch in the expanded health benefits program. The AOC, as the central support agency for the judiciary, will be responsible for coordinating these benefits for judicial employees.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and is responsible for the state budget. The bill will lead to an indeterminate increase in state expenditures for health benefits which must be accounted for in the annual budget.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies. They will be responsible for auditing DBM and the Comptroller to ensure that domestic partner benefits and associated tax withholdings are being administered correctly.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires a resident member of a pass-through entity (PTE) to add back to their Maryland adjusted gross income the amount of any credit claimed for income taxes paid by the PTE to another state. This ensures that out-of-state income taxes paid by PTEs are treated the same way as Maryland income taxes paid by PTEs for state income tax purposes.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Resident members of pass-through entities (PTEs), including shareholders of S corporations, partners in partnerships, and members of limited liability companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues and local income tax revenues are expected to increase starting in fiscal 2024, although the exact amount cannot be reliably estimated as it depends on tax elections and the treatment of PTEs in other states. There is no impact on state or local expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the state's principal tax collector, the Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for implementing the new income tax addition modification, administering the related tax credits for pass-through entities, and ensuring compliance through auditing and enforcement.

The Maryland Tax Court is the administrative agency responsible for hearing appeals from final decisions of the Comptroller; it would adjudicate any disputes regarding the application of the new addition modification and its impact on a resident's tax liability.

DBM is the state's principal fiscal agency responsible for estimating revenues; this bill is projected to increase general fund revenues, which DBM must integrate into the state's long-term fiscal planning and budget development.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and proposes the annual state budget; the changes to tax policy and the resulting increase in general fund revenue directly impact the administration's fiscal priorities and budget execution.

The Treasurer's Office acts as the chief financial agency responsible for receiving and managing state funds; it will handle the deposit and investment of the additional income tax revenues generated by this bill.

The OAG serves as the chief legal representative for the state and provides counsel to the Comptroller; it would be responsible for providing legal interpretations of the new tax laws and representing the state in any resulting litigation.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Comptroller to evaluate nonmonetary abandoned property to determine its commercial value within one year of delivery. If the property has no commercial value or if the cost of sale would exceed its estimated value, the Comptroller is authorized to return the property to the holder, destroy it, or otherwise dispose of it. Additionally, the bill updates the public notice requirement for the sale of abandoned property from specific newspaper publication to 'reasonable notice' to the public.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and holders of abandoned property, the Maryland Comptroller's Office, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to materially affect State finances or operations, although the Comptroller may realize cost efficiencies due to a reduction in storage and maintenance costs for property with no monetary value. There is no fiscal impact on local governments and minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller, as the Administrator of abandoned property in Maryland, to value, sell, or dispose of nonmonetary abandoned property, and was introduced at the agency's request.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies like the Comptroller and would be responsible for representing the State regarding the bill's immunity provisions for transactions related to abandoned property.
OLA is responsible for fiscal compliance audits of state agencies and will oversee the Comptroller's adherence to the new statutory procedures for valuing and disposing of abandoned property.

As the state's principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM oversees the Comptroller's budget and has an interest in the cost efficiencies gained through reduced storage and maintenance of non-valuable abandoned property.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, including the Comptroller, and the Governor is responsible for signing the legislation into law.
The Board, which includes the Comptroller, oversees the State's fiscal integrity and general policies regarding the acquisition, lease, or transfer of property.
GOPI's mission to enhance the efficiency of state government aligns with the bill's goal to eliminate the waste and cost associated with storing property that has no commercial value.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill makes a technical correction to the Maryland income tax law by updating an incorrect cross-reference to the federal Internal Revenue Code regarding the federal Work Opportunity Tax Credit. The update ensures that the state's reference points to Section 38 instead of Section 51 of the Internal Revenue Code.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Comptroller
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employers and not-for-profit entities that claim the federal Work Opportunity Tax Credit for hiring individuals from targeted groups with significant barriers to employment.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is technical in nature and has no state or local fiscal impact. Both the Office of the Comptroller and the Department of Legislative Services determined that the bill has minimal or no impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller's Office requested this bill and is the primary agency responsible for tax collection and the administration of the Maryland Work Opportunity Tax Credit.
The Department of Labor serves as the state workforce agency responsible for certifying that employees qualify for the targeted groups required for the Work Opportunity Tax Credit.
The OAG provides legal review and counsel for state agencies and the General Assembly to ensure tax legislation correctly cross-references the federal Internal Revenue Code.
As the principal fiscal agency, DBM monitors tax legislation for potential impacts on state revenues and long-term fiscal planning.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and is responsible for signing this departmental legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the eligibility requirements for the Maryland State child and dependent care tax credit by limiting the credit to Maryland residents only, thereby excluding non-resident taxpayers from claiming it on their state income tax returns.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland resident and non-resident taxpayers who claim expenses for child and dependent care.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund revenues are projected to increase by approximately $332,000 annually starting in fiscal 2024 because non-residents will no longer be eligible to claim the tax credit. The bill has no impact on state expenditures or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the state's chief tax collector and the agency responsible for administering the income tax laws. This bill, which was introduced at the request of the Comptroller, directly impacts the agency's operations by altering the eligibility criteria for the child and dependent care tax credit and limiting it to residents.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for revenue estimation and fiscal planning. This bill is projected to increase general fund revenues by approximately $332,000 annually starting in fiscal 2024, which directly affects the state's budget execution and long-term fiscal strategy managed by DBM.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and proposes the annual state budget. This bill affects general fund revenues and represents a policy change regarding tax support for families, which aligns with the Governor's role in coordinating policy initiatives and managing the state's fiscal health.

The GOC is tasked with promoting the well-being of children and families and reducing child poverty. Although this is a tax residency adjustment, the underlying credit is a significant policy tool for supporting families with child care costs, which is central to the GOC's mission.

The Maryland Department of Aging supports older adults and their caregivers. Because the tax credit applies not only to children but also to 'qualifying individuals' who are physically or mentally incapable of self-care (including seniors), changes to this credit's eligibility are relevant to the department's mission to support caregivers of older adults.

The Maryland Department of Disabilities coordinates services for residents with disabilities. The child and dependent care tax credit applies to dependents who are physically or mentally incapable of self-care, making the eligibility criteria for this credit relevant to the populations served by the department.

The Innovation Team is specifically charged with identifying and testing initiatives to reduce child poverty and enhance economic mobility. The child and dependent care tax credit is a key mechanism for supporting the economic mobility of working families, making alterations to its eligibility relevant to the team's policy focus.

DHS is the state's primary social service provider for residents in economic need. Tax credits for child and dependent care are essential financial supports for the vulnerable populations that DHS serves, helping them maintain employment and economic stability.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the mandated annual appropriation for the National Capital Strategic Economic Development Fund from $7 million to $12 million beginning in fiscal year 2025. It also permanently defines the geographic areas within Montgomery and Prince George’s counties where these funds must be used for community enhancement projects in sustainable communities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development
qa_results.stakeholders: Sustainable communities, local governments, housing authorities, community development organizations, and small businesses in Montgomery and Prince George's counties.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State expenditures increase by $5,000,000 annually starting in FY 2025 due to the increased mandated appropriation, bringing the total annual mandate to $12,000,000. This is funded through pay-as-you-go (PAYGO) general funds or general obligation (GO) bonds. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase commensurately. Local governments and small businesses in the targeted areas may see increased revenue and development activity.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development is the primary agency responsible for administering the National Capital Strategic Economic Development Fund and the associated program as defined in the Housing and Community Development Article of the Annotated Code of Maryland.

The bill mandates an increase in the annual appropriation for the fund to $12 million starting in FY 2025. DBM is the principal agency responsible for developing the state budget and ensuring these mandated appropriations are executed.
The Governor is explicitly required by the bill to include the specified $12 million appropriation in the annual operating or capital budget for the fund beginning in fiscal year 2025.

The fund is restricted to 'sustainable communities,' which are defined based on land-use designations and priority funding areas coordinated by the Maryland Department of Planning. The agency provides the planning data and analysis that underpin these geographic eligibility requirements.

The fiscal note indicates that the mandated appropriation may be satisfied using General Obligation (GO) bonds. The Treasurer's Office manages the issuance and distribution of these bonds and serves on the Board of Public Works which would approve associated expenditures.

The Board of Public Works oversees significant state expenditures, including capital projects and general obligation bond issuances that may be used to satisfy the bill's funding mandate for community enhancement projects.

This multi-agency initiative focuses on sustainable development and revitalizing communities. The bill’s focus on sustainable community projects in the national capital region directly aligns with the initiative's core mission and planning visions.

As the state's chief financial officer and a member of the Board of Public Works, the Comptroller oversees the fiscal integrity of state funds and approves the contracts and expenditures associated with the program.

The bill concerns strategic economic development in specific Maryland counties, which overlaps with the Department of Commerce's mission to stimulate the economy and support business expansion, even though DHCD is the primary administrator.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the Department of Housing and Community Development, and would be responsible for ensuring the fund's administration complies with the statutory changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes that a sheriff’s sale of real property extinguishes any subordinate liens or interests on the property. It requires judgment creditors to notify the record owner, subordinate interest holders, and occupants of the sale at least 20 days in advance and to file an affidavit of compliance with the court. Additionally, it allows sheriffs to use assessment records instead of appraisals for real property valuations and authorizes a one-time transfer of up to $12 million from the Judiciary's General Fund appropriation to the Circuit Court Real Property Records Improvement Fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: The Judiciary and Maryland Sheriffs
qa_results.stakeholders: Judgment creditors, property owners (debtors), occupants of real property subject to execution, subordinate lien holders (including mortgagees and homeowners associations), and local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues increase by up to $12 million in FY 2023, while general fund revenues decrease by the same amount due to an authorized transfer of funds that would otherwise have reverted to the general fund. The bill is not expected to materially affect local government operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the Judicial branch by authorizing the Judiciary to transfer up to $12 million to the Circuit Court Real Property Records Improvement Fund. It also modifies court procedures regarding sheriff's sales, requiring the Supreme Court of Maryland to adopt related rules and the Judiciary to manage notice and affidavit requirements.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact by authorizing a $12 million transfer from the General Fund (via the Judiciary's appropriation) to a special fund that does not revert. This affects state revenue planning and budget execution, which are core responsibilities of DBM.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides counsel on the interpretation of new property laws, including the extinguishment of subordinate liens and the procedural requirements for judgment creditors and sheriffs.

The Comptroller oversees state revenues and financial accounts. This bill involves a significant transfer between the General Fund and a Special Fund, and specifically addresses the preservation of tax liens in the context of sheriff's sales.

The bill modifies the legal framework for real property sales and the enforcement of liens, including local government liens for nuisance and maintenance violations. These changes affect property ownership and neighborhood stability, which align with DHCD's mission of community revitalization.
The bill involves a major budgetary transfer and changes to state property laws that require the Governor's approval and oversight of executive branch fiscal policy.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill expands the authority of the Independent Investigations Division (IID) within the Office of the Attorney General by granting it the power to prosecute criminal offenses discovered during its investigations into police-involved incidents. It expands the division's investigative jurisdiction to include incidents resulting in serious bodily injury if referred by a State's Attorney and mandates that the Attorney General has exclusive authority to prosecute such offenses unless they request a State's Attorney to do so. Additionally, the bill requires the IID to submit an annual report on its activities to the Governor and the General Assembly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Independent Investigations Division of the Office of the Attorney General
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland police officers, individuals involved in police-related incidents, State's Attorneys, and the Office of the Attorney General.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $548,900 in FY 2024 to cover the costs of hiring two attorneys, one investigator, and one paralegal, as well as associated operating expenses and equipment. These costs are projected to rise to $729,700 by FY 2028 due to annualization and inflation. The FY 2024 budget as passed included the initial funding contingent on the bill's passage. Local government finances are not expected to be materially affected as resources would be redirected from local State's Attorney's offices to other cases. There is no impact on State revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly expands the jurisdiction and authority of the Independent Investigations Division, which is housed within this office, and grants the Attorney General exclusive authority to prosecute certain police-involved incidents.

The bill explicitly allows the Independent Investigations Division within the OAG to detail police officers from the Department of State Police to assist in investigating alleged criminal offenses committed by police officers.
The Governor is the recipient of the Independent Investigations Division's new annual activity reports and is mandated by the bill to include sufficient funding for the division in the state budget.

As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for managing the state budget and personnel increases, including the $548,900 general fund expenditure and four new positions identified in the fiscal note for this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This office serves as the state's primary coordinating body for public safety and criminal justice strategy, which is directly impacted by the centralization of investigations and prosecutions of police-involved fatalities and injuries.
The bill expands the use of court-issued subpoenas and injunctive relief by the Attorney General, impacting judicial branch operations and support requirements managed by the AOC.

The bill's expansion of the Attorney General's prosecutorial mandate into police misconduct creates a specific jurisdictional boundary with the State Prosecutor's role in investigating and prosecuting offenses related to the integrity of state officials.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the terminology used in Maryland law by replacing the term "inmate" with "incarcerated individual" throughout the Annotated Code of Maryland and in all executive orders, rules, regulations, and official documents. It requires the publishers of the Annotated Code to update cross-references and terminology accordingly.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of Legislative Services and the publisher of the Annotated Code of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Incarcerated individuals and State and local correctional facilities
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as the changes are technical in nature and do not directly affect governmental finances or operations.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary agency overseeing Maryland's correctional facilities, this department is most significantly impacted by the bill's mandate to replace the term 'inmate' with 'incarcerated individual' in all policies, regulations, and documents.
This agency manages youth in detention and correctional facilities and will be required to update its internal policies and documentation to reflect the new terminology.
The bill explicitly requires that the new terminology be used in every executive order and document created by state officials, impacting the Governor's administrative and policy functions.
The terminology change affects the Courts and Judicial Proceedings Article of the Annotated Code, requiring the judicial branch to update court records and procedures.
As the state's chief legal officer, the OAG will need to ensure that legal advice, filings, and regulatory reviews comply with the new statutory language across all state agencies.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency provides legal representation for the individuals being renamed and will need to update its professional documents and legal communications.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the coordinator for public safety and criminal justice strategies, this office will need to incorporate the new terminology into its policy development and grant management operations.
The bill affects terminology in the Health-General Article, which governs medical and behavioral health services provided to individuals in correctional settings.
The terminology change applies to the Education Article of the Maryland Code, which covers educational programs provided to individuals in facilities.
The bill impacts the Labor and Employment Article, requiring updates to documents related to workforce programs or employment issues involving incarcerated individuals.
The fiscal note indicates the term 'inmate' is used in the State Personnel and Pensions Article, which this agency administers.
As the agency responsible for personnel policies and the State Personnel and Pensions Article, DBM must ensure state-wide compliance with the new terminology in administrative regulations.
The bill impacts the Public Safety Article, which governs many MSP operations, requiring the agency to update its reports and law enforcement protocols.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the County Commissioners of Carroll County to borrow up to $65,600,000 through the issuance and sale of general obligation bonds. The funds are designated for financing the acquisition, construction, improvement, or development of public facilities such as schools, roads, bridges, and water and sewer infrastructure, as well as providing loans to volunteer fire departments for equipment and facilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Commissioners of Carroll County
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of Carroll County, Carroll County Public Schools, Carroll Community College, volunteer fire departments, and agricultural landowners.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: Carroll County will receive up to $65.6 million in bond proceeds to fund capital projects. County debt service expenditures are projected to increase by approximately $4.4 million annually over a 20-year period, assuming a 2.97% interest rate. There is no fiscal impact on the State.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill provides that the authorized bonds, the interest payable on them, and any income derived from them are exempt from all Maryland State and local taxation, which falls under the Comptroller's jurisdiction as the chief financial officer and tax collector.

The bill authorizes borrowing for installment purchase obligations to acquire agricultural land preservation easements and provides funds for the Maryland Agricultural Land Preservation Program (MALPP), which the department supports.
The bond proceeds are authorized for the construction, improvement, and development of public school buildings and facilities, which are under the leadership and oversight of this department.

The bill authorizes Carroll County to finance loans for fire or emergency-related equipment, buildings, and facilities for volunteer fire departments, which aligns with the department's role in emergency response coordination.

The bill authorizes funding for water and sewer infrastructure, landfills, and watershed improvement projects, all of which are regulated by the department regarding environmental protection and restoration.
The bill identifies health service buildings and facilities as eligible public facilities for construction and improvement projects funded by the authorized bond proceeds.
The bill identifies social service buildings and facilities as eligible public facilities for construction and improvement projects funded by the authorized bond proceeds.

The bill authorizes funding for parks, recreation buildings, and the acquisition of woodland preservation easements, which relates to the department's mission to manage public lands and conserve natural resources.

The agency is relevant due to its role in promoting sustainable growth and land use, particularly regarding the bill's focus on agricultural and woodland preservation easements and local infrastructure development.

The bill authorizes debt to finance public works projects including roads, bridges, and storm drains, which are foundational components of the state's transportation network overseen by this department.

The bill authorizes the use of bond proceeds for the construction and development of Carroll Community College buildings and facilities, which fall under the commission's regulatory and coordinating oversight.
The IAC oversees public school construction and capital improvements; the bill authorizes over $21 million for Carroll County school projects, including HVAC and roof replacements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bond proceeds will finance a $21.7 million headquarters for the Sheriff's Office and loans for fire or emergency-related equipment, supporting the agency's mission regarding public safety strategies and law enforcement.

The bill identifies library buildings and facilities as authorized projects for construction and improvement funding, which relates to the agency's strategic leadership and coordination of public library systems.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill renames the Black Bear Damage Reimbursement Fund to the Black Bear Damage Prevention and Reimbursement Fund and expands its scope to include grants for projects that prevent damages caused by black bears and reduce human-bear conflicts through nonlethal methods. It increases the maximum annual reimbursement for individuals who suffer bear-related damage to agricultural products, livestock, or pets from $3,000 to $5,000, and allows the Governor to include an appropriation of at least $50,000 in the annual budget bill for the fund.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR)
qa_results.stakeholders: Farmers, landowners, local governments, parks and recreation departments, businesses, tribes, institutions of higher education, and nonprofit organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $145,600 in FY 2024, which includes a discretionary $50,000 appropriation to the fund and $95,637 for administrative costs, specifically to hire one natural resources technician. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase by $50,000 annually starting in FY 2024. Local governments may see an increase in grant revenues and expenditures for bear conflict mitigation projects. Small businesses, particularly farmers, may benefit from higher damage reimbursement limits and grant opportunities.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency responsible for administering the Black Bear Damage Prevention and Reimbursement Fund and the newly established grant program for bear damage prevention and conflict reduction.

The bill explicitly requires the University of Maryland Cooperative Extension Service (part of the University System of Maryland) to determine damage amounts for reimbursement eligibility. Additionally, USM institutions are eligible for grants under the fund.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for the state's budget and personnel; the bill authorizes a $50,000 annual appropriation and leads to the creation of a new Natural Resources Technician position to manage the program.
The bill statutorily requires the State Comptroller to account for the Black Bear Damage Prevention and Reimbursement Fund.
The bill statutorily requires the State Treasurer to hold the Black Bear Damage Prevention and Reimbursement Fund.
The Governor is authorized to include an appropriation of at least $50,000 in the annual budget bill for the fund and oversees the executive branch implementing the program.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as legal counsel to state agencies, including the Department of Natural Resources, which must adopt new regulations to implement the expanded fund and grant program.

As a public institution of higher education, Morgan State University is explicitly listed as an entity eligible to apply for and receive grants from the Black Bear Damage Prevention and Reimbursement Fund.
As a public institution of higher education, Saint Mary's College of Maryland is eligible to apply for and receive grants for bear damage prevention and conflict reduction projects.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows Class 4 limited winery license holders to prepare and serve a broader range of food, including sandwiches and light fare, by removing restrictions on prepackaged items. It extends the hours for on-premises consumption to 10:00 p.m. daily and eliminates the requirement for wineries to provide advance notice to the State before holding promotional events. Additionally, wineries that also hold a food establishment license are permitted to serve a full menu if they meet specific food-to-alcohol sales ratios.
qa_results.responsible_party: Alcohol and Tobacco Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Class 4 limited winery license holders, Maryland grape and fruit growers, and winery consumers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect State or local government finances. It is expected to have a meaningful positive economic impact on small businesses holding Class 4 limited winery licenses by increasing potential revenue through expanded food service and longer operating hours.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies regulatory functions assigned to the Comptroller, including the approval of segregated storage areas for winery products and the repeal of a requirement to file notices of promotional events with the Comptroller's office.

The bill explicitly empowers the Secretary of Agriculture to grant annual exemptions to limited wineries regarding Maryland-grown ingredient requirements and mandates the adoption of regulations for these exemptions.

The bill allows wineries to expand food service beyond light fare if they are licensed as food establishments under Title 21 of the Health - General Article, which falls under the regulatory purview of the Department of Health.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Secretary of Agriculture to consult with the Governor's Wine and Grape Advisory Commission when developing regulations for ingredient requirement exemptions.

The bill has a meaningful economic impact on small business wineries by expanding their operational hours and food service capabilities, which aligns with Commerce's mission to support business growth and tourism.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the state agencies and commissions involved in implementing the new regulatory standards for wineries and food safety.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies implementing the bill and coordinates policy initiatives related to the state's agriculture and hospitality sectors.
The OAH may be called upon to adjudicate administrative disputes or appeals arising from the enforcement of winery licenses or food establishment regulations mentioned in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes that the salary of the Washington County Sheriff is 90% of the salary of the State's Attorney of Washington County. It also repeals the requirement for the Washington County Salary Study Commission to study and issue recommendations regarding the Sheriff's salary. The salary adjustment takes effect at the beginning of the next term of office following the bill's effective date.
qa_results.responsible_party: County Commissioners of Washington County
qa_results.stakeholders: The Sheriff of Washington County and the taxpayers of Washington County.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State operations or finances. Washington County expenditures are estimated to increase by a minimum of $21,100 in FY 2027 and $36,200 annually thereafter, reflecting the mandated salary increase for the Sheriff beginning in the next term of office. There is no impact on local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the chief executive, the Governor signs the bill into law and oversees the administration of state laws.

The bill links the Sheriff's salary to the State's Attorney's salary, which in turn is pegged at 90% of a District Court judge's salary; the AOC supports the judicial branch and manages the data for these base salaries.
The Sheriff is a law enforcement officer whose pension benefits and contributions are administered by the SRA; altering the salary impacts these retirement data and benefit calculations.

The OAG provides legal counsel on the constitutionality of salary alterations, specifically regarding Article III, Section 35 of the Maryland Constitution, which is referenced in the bill's implementation and fiscal note.
The Secretary of State is the principal custodian of the state's official records and is responsible for processing and maintaining the laws passed by the General Assembly.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of General Services (DGS), in coordination with the Department of Information Technology (DoIT), to negotiate contracts with third-party vendors for the purchase and maintenance of body-worn cameras and related equipment on behalf of Maryland law enforcement agencies upon request. Additionally, DoIT must conduct a study on the cost and feasibility of a statewide system for storing and accessing data from these cameras.
qa_results.responsible_party: Department of General Services and Department of Information Technology
qa_results.stakeholders: State, county, and municipal law enforcement agencies; third-party technology vendors; and the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures are expected to increase by $200,000 to $400,000 in FY 2024 to fund the required feasibility study. DGS and DoIT can implement the contracting requirements with existing resources. State and local law enforcement agencies may experience administrative efficiencies or cost savings through centralized contract negotiations. There is no impact on state or local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly requires the Department of General Services to negotiate contracts for body-worn cameras and related technology for law enforcement agencies and to coordinate with DoIT on a feasibility study regarding data storage.

The bill tasks the Department of Information Technology with leading a study on the cost and feasibility of a statewide uniform storage and access system for body-worn camera data and coordinating with DGS on contract negotiations.

As a primary state law enforcement agency already required to use body-worn cameras, the Maryland State Police is a significant stakeholder in the unified procurement and data storage initiatives established by this bill.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This department oversees state correctional facilities and the Division of Parole and Probation, which employ personnel who qualify as law enforcement or security forces eligible for the procurement and technology programs in the bill.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact, requiring an estimated general fund expenditure of $200,000 to $400,000 for the mandated feasibility study, which falls under DBM's fiscal and budget execution oversight.

The Department of Natural Resources operates the Natural Resources Police, a law enforcement agency that would be impacted by the statewide procurement and data storage standards for body-worn cameras.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the primary coordinating body for public safety, this office advises on criminal justice strategies and previously commissioned a related feasibility study on body-worn camera costs.
The Maryland Transportation Authority maintains its own nationally accredited police force, which qualifies as a law enforcement agency that may utilize the BWC contracts negotiated under this bill.

Member institutions within the University System of Maryland operate their own police departments, which are law enforcement agencies eligible for the procurement and data storage initiatives outlined in the bill.
Morgan State University maintains its own police force and is a state agency that could benefit from the administrative efficiencies of the BWC contracts negotiated by DGS.

MDOT oversees several modal administrations that maintain law enforcement or security forces, such as the Maryland Transportation Authority and the Maryland Aviation Administration, which are impacted by the bill's provisions.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies responsible for implementing the bill and coordinates the policy initiatives related to public safety and law enforcement standards.
The MAA operates security and law enforcement functions at state airports, making it an eligible agency for the body-worn camera equipment and technology contracts addressed in the bill.

The agency operates secure residential facilities with security personnel who may utilize body-worn cameras, making the department potentially relevant to the unified procurement and data storage study.
As an independent state agency with its own security or law enforcement requirements, the college may utilize the contract negotiation services provided by DGS for body-worn camera technology.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the membership of the West North Avenue Development Authority by adding the Secretary of Commerce, the Executive Director of the Maryland Economic Development Corporation, and two members appointed by the chair. It also extends the deadline for the Authority's comprehensive neighborhood revitalization strategy report to December 15, 2023, and exempts the Authority from most State procurement laws while maintaining requirements for Minority Business Enterprise participation.
qa_results.responsible_party: West North Avenue Development Authority
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents and community groups in the target area and buffer zone of West North Avenue in Baltimore City, including several named neighborhood associations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local finances are not materially impacted. The Authority may use approximately $250,000 from existing funds for an expedited procurement of a revitalization strategy contract. The fiscal 2024 budget includes $11.4 million for the Authority's direct operations and projects.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the structure, membership, reporting requirements, and procurement procedures of the West North Avenue Development Authority, which is an entity that falls under this classification.
The President of Coppin State University, a member institution of the University System of Maryland, is designated as the chair of the Authority.
The bill adds the Secretary of Commerce, or their designee, as a new member of the Authority.
The bill adds the Executive Director of the Maryland Economic Development Corporation (MEDCO), or their designee, as a new member of the Authority.
The Secretary of Housing and Community Development is a member of the Authority, and the bill focuses on neighborhood revitalization which aligns with this department's mission.
The Secretary of Transportation is a member of the Authority, and the revitalization strategy includes transportation elements.
The Governor appoints a member of the Authority, receives its comprehensive reports, and oversees the executive branch departments that participate in the Authority.
By exempting the Authority from Division II of the State Finance and Procurement Article, the bill removes the Board of Public Works' standard oversight of the Authority's contracts.
As the state's central procurement authority, DGS is impacted by legislation that exempts a state-created authority from standard procurement laws.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly states that the Authority remains subject to Title 14, Subtitle 3 of the State Finance and Procurement Article, which pertains to the Minority Business Enterprise (MBE) program overseen by this office.
The Authority manages appropriated State funds, and DBM oversees budget execution and long-term fiscal planning for the state.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, boards, and commissions, including the Authority, and would be involved in interpreting the new procurement exemptions.
This office assists the Governor in fulfilling the responsibility to appoint a member to the Authority as specified in the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes formal procedures and a priority order for persons other than the designated beneficiary to open and manage a Maryland ABLE account for an eligible individual with a disability. It conforms Maryland law to federal IRS regulations regarding account establishment, distributions, and eligibility certification while prohibiting certain individuals, such as those with protective orders or history of financial exploitation, from opening accounts on behalf of others.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland 529 Board
qa_results.stakeholders: Eligible individuals with disabilities, their family members (spouses, parents, siblings, and grandparents), legal guardians, agents under power of attorney, and representative payees.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is expected to decrease State general fund and local revenues starting in fiscal 2024 because more individuals may claim income tax subtraction modifications for contributions to and distributions from new ABLE accounts. For every 1,000 additional filers claiming the modification, State revenues decrease by approximately $135,700 and local revenues by $88,400. Maryland 529 nonbudgeted revenues will increase from account fees, which may reduce the need for an existing $300,000 annual State grant.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the Maryland ABLE Program, which is managed and administered by Maryland 529. The agency is responsible for adopting the new procedures and regulations mandated by the bill.

The State Treasurer's Office oversees the Maryland 529 program and the Maryland ABLE program. Following the abolition of the Maryland 529 Board, the Treasurer's Office is responsible for the management and distribution of these funds.

The ABLE program is specifically designed for individuals with disabilities. The Department of Disabilities coordinates services for this population and is required by current law to consult on the establishment and administration of the Maryland ABLE Program.

The bill has a notable fiscal impact on state tax revenues due to subtraction modifications allowed for contributions to and distributions from ABLE accounts, which the Comptroller's Office administers and monitors.
The bill affects eligibility for means-tested programs like Medicaid (administered by the Department of Health) because ABLE account assets are generally excluded from asset limits for such programs.

The bill establishes a priority list for opening ABLE accounts that includes court-appointed roles such as conservators and legal guardians. It also references peace and protective orders issued by the courts.

The bill may have a fiscal impact on the state budget, specifically regarding a $300,000 annual grant to the ABLE program which may be reduced if the program becomes self-sufficient through increased fee revenue from new accounts.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and boards, including Maryland 529, and would be responsible for advising the program on the legal sufficiency of the new account establishment procedures and regulations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Affordable Life, Wills, and Estate Planning for Seniors Grant Program within the Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC). The program provides affordable civil legal services, such as drafting wills, powers of attorney, special needs trusts, advance health care directives, and life estate deeds, to eligible seniors aged 65 and older whose family income does not exceed 75% of the State median family income.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC)
qa_results.stakeholders: Seniors aged 65 and older with family income at or below 75% of the Maryland median family income, particularly those living in rural communities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill results in an annual increase in State general fund expenditures of $225,000 starting in fiscal 2024 to fund the grant program. Funding for fiscal 2024 is discretionary, but the bill establishes a mandated appropriation beginning in fiscal 2025. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include a $225,000 appropriation in the annual budget for the program and requires the Maryland Legal Services Corporation to report annually to the Governor on the program's implementation and utilization.

The grant program is specifically designed to provide legal services for last wills and testaments, powers of attorney, and life estate deeds, which are the primary legal documents administered, recorded, and probated by the Register of Wills offices.
The program targets seniors aged 65 and older with limited financial means, aligning with the department's mission to protect the rights and improve the quality of life for Maryland's older adults.
As the state's principal fiscal agency, it is responsible for supervising the mandated $225,000 annual general fund appropriation required by the bill.

The agency provides operational and legal support to the Maryland Judicial Branch, which oversees the legal framework for estates and trusts; additionally, the office was a primary information source for the bill's fiscal analysis.
As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG provides counsel to the executive branch and state entities regarding the legal requirements and implementation of state-funded grant programs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to apply to the federal Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA) for planning, development, and implementation grant funds for certified community behavioral health clinics (CCBHCs) for fiscal year 2025. Additionally, the Department must apply for inclusion in the state CCBHC demonstration program for fiscal year 2026. CCBHCs are nonprofit organizations that provide comprehensive community mental health and substance use treatment, including 24-hour crisis response, regardless of a patient's ability to pay.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with mental health needs or substance use disorders, military service members, veterans, and nonprofit behavioral health treatment organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Department of Health can apply for the required federal grant funds and demonstration program inclusion using existing budgeted resources. If federal planning grants are awarded, federal fund revenues will increase in fiscal 2025, supported by a 65% federal matching rate. No local government fiscal impact is expected. The fiscal note does not estimate the specific costs associated with future participation in the demonstration program.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates that the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) apply for federal planning grant funds and for inclusion in the state certified community behavioral health clinic demonstration program. MDH is the primary agency responsible for implementing and overseeing the clinics and payment systems described in the bill.

The bill defines a 'certified community behavioral health clinic' as an entity that must offer community-based mental health care for military service members and veterans. As the primary agency for assisting veterans, this bill directly impacts services available to their constituents.

As the agency responsible for developing the state's budget and supervising budget execution, DBM will be involved in managing the federal grant funds and long-term fiscal planning associated with the implementation of the CCBHC demonstration program.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including MDH. It would be involved in the legal aspects of applying for federal grants, submitting State plan amendments to federal authorities (CMS), and ensuring compliance with federal healthcare acts mentioned in the bill.

The MHCC is responsible for planning for the state's health system needs and improving access to care. The establishment of CCBHCs represents a significant shift in the delivery and accessibility of behavioral health services, which falls under their planning and access mandates.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and coordinates policy initiatives. The bill requires executive action from a cabinet-level department (MDH) to implement a federally-aligned behavioral health strategy, which aligns with the Governor's role in overseeing state health policy and the annual budget.

DHS is the state's primary social service provider. The CCBHC model includes targeted case management, peer support, and family supports, which are services that often overlap with or support the populations served by DHS, such as vulnerable children and adults.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill amends the definition of 'commercial use' for Baltimore City zoning purposes to include multifamily residential developments, provided they are located within a waterfront commercial zoning district and within a 0.5-mile radius of a commuter rail station.
qa_results.responsible_party: Mayor and City Council of Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Real estate developers, residents of Baltimore City, and businesses located in waterfront commercial zoning districts near transit hubs.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not anticipated to directly affect State or local government operations or finances, and it has no small business effect.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's preamble explicitly states that the redevelopment of Baltimore's waterfront is a major driver of Central Maryland's economy and will ensure increased tourism spending and new jobs, which aligns with the Department's mission of economic development and job creation.

The bill defines 'commercial use' to include multifamily residential development in specific zones. The Department of Housing and Community Development is responsible for supporting homeownership and rental housing, making this change in land use definition highly relevant to their work.
The bill's preamble highlights the importance of Baltimore's waterfront to the sustainability of the Chesapeake Bay, an area managed and conserved by the DNR.

The Maryland Department of Planning provides data analysis and policy guidance for land use and sustainable growth. As this bill amends the Land Use Article regarding Baltimore City zoning, MDP is a primary stakeholder in technical oversight.

The bill applies its new definition based on a 0.50-mile radius of a commuter rail station. MDOT oversees the Maryland Transit Administration, which operates the commuter rail stations (MARC) mentioned in the bill's criteria.
The preamble links the waterfront redevelopment to the environmental sustainability of the Chesapeake Bay, and MDE is the primary agency for environmental protection and restoration.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Council on the Chesapeake Bay
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill's preamble emphasizes the environmental health of Baltimore's waterfront as a feeder to the sustainability of the Chesapeake Bay, which is the primary advisory focus of this council.

MEDCO's mission is to assist in real estate development and promote economic prosperity in Maryland. The bill's intent to revitalize Baltimore's waterfront and create jobs falls within their scope of advisory and financing services.
The preamble specifically notes that redevelopment will ensure increased tourism spending, which is the core mission of this office.

The bill's preamble explicitly mentions the health of the Port of Baltimore as critical to the State and a major driver of the economy, placing the redevelopment projects within the context of maritime economic interest.

The bill uses proximity to 'commuter rail stations' as a qualifying factor for the new definition. As the operator of the MARC Train and other transit networks, MTA is directly relevant to the geographic application of this law.
This multi-agency initiative promotes sustainable development and community revitalization. The bill's focus on density near transit and waterfront redevelopment aligns with the initiative's goals.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Board of Physicians to establish an emeritus status for licensed physicians who are retired and meet specific criteria, such as having practiced in the state for at least 10 years and having no history of disciplinary action. It exempts licensees on emeritus or inactive status from continuing medical education requirements and the standard three-year license expiration, while prohibiting them from practicing medicine or delegating medical tasks. It also allows emeritus physicians to continue using professional titles like 'Dr.' or 'M.D.' provided they do not represent themselves as authorized to practice.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Board of Physicians
qa_results.stakeholders: Physicians licensed in Maryland, specifically those who are retired or seeking inactive status.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Maryland Board of Physicians can handle the bill's requirements with existing budgeted resources. There is an anticipated minimal net impact on special fund revenues from fees associated with emeritus or inactive status licenses. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Board of Physicians, which is the primary entity affected by this bill, operates within the Maryland Department of Health. The department is responsible for regulating health care professionals and will oversee the implementation of the new emeritus license status and changes to inactive status procedures.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies, including the Maryland Board of Physicians and the Department of Health. They may be required to advise on the implementation of these new licensing regulations and represent the Board in any related legal matters.

The Office of Administrative Hearings adjudicates contested cases for state agencies. If a physician disputes a decision made by the Board regarding their eligibility for emeritus status or faces disciplinary action for practicing without authorization under these statuses, the OAH would likely conduct the hearing.

As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM monitors the revenues and expenditures of state boards. This bill may have a minimal impact on the special fund revenues collected from license fees for emeritus and inactive status.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill limits the circumstances under which workers' compensation benefits for public-sector employees are offset by other government benefits. Offsets are only allowed if the workers' compensation and the other public benefit (such as disability retirement) are based on the same injury or occupational disease involving the same body part. The bill reverses the legal precedent set in Spevak v. Montgomery County to prevent duplicative offsets for different injuries. Additionally, the Maryland Association of Counties and the Professional Fire Fighters of Maryland must jointly study and report on the bill's impacts by December 1, 2024.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Association of Counties, Professional Fire Fighters of Maryland, and the Maryland Workers' Compensation Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Public-sector employees of Maryland governmental units and quasi-public corporations, local governments, and the Professional Fire Fighters of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State government finances are not affected. Local government expenditures are expected to increase because the bill restricts the ability to offset workers' compensation benefits, leading to higher costs. Chesapeake Employers' Insurance Company expects an increase in both expenditures for benefits and premium revenue from local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Commission is the primary regulatory and adjudicatory body responsible for administering the workers' compensation law. The bill directly alters the statutory criteria for determining benefit offsets and awards, which the Commission must implement in its hearings and decisions.

Now operating as Chesapeake Employers' Insurance Company, this entity is the third-party administrator for State of Maryland workers' compensation claims and the insurer for many local governments. The bill's limitation on benefit offsets will likely increase benefit payouts and liability for their clients.

The bill explicitly mentions the Subsequent Injury Fund (SIF) in Section 9-610, stating that employer benefit payments only satisfy SIF liability under specific conditions related to the 'same body part.' This directly impacts the Fund's fiscal obligations in claims involving pre-existing conditions.

The benefit offsets addressed in the bill primarily occur when an employee receives disability retirement benefits from the State Retirement and Pension System. Changes to how these benefits interact with workers' compensation awards are relevant to the administration of retiree and disability benefits.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the state agencies involved (WCC, SIF, and DBM) and represents the state in workers' compensation appeals. The bill's intent to abrogate specific Supreme Court of Maryland case law directly involves the OAG's legal and appellate functions.

As the central personnel agency for the state, DBM oversees employee benefits and policies. While the fiscal note suggests the state government may not be directly impacted by the specific court case being abrogated, any changes to the Labor and Employment Article regarding state employee benefits are relevant to DBM.

The bill reenacts Section 9-610(b), which specifically addresses how federal benefits for employees of the Military Department offset state workers' compensation benefits. As the head of the Military Department, the Adjutant General has oversight of these personnel matters.
