agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Maryland Corps Program Advisory Board, a permanent body tasked with advising the department and providing oversight for the design, implementation, and expansion of the program.

The Department of Service and Civic Innovation is required to consult with the Maryland Higher Education Commission regarding the feasibility of awarding academic credit to corps participants for their service.

The department must consult with the Maryland Department of Labor regarding the alignment of service opportunities with registered apprenticeships and awarding credit for prior learning toward trade or vocational certification.

The bill explicitly includes the expansion of the Maryland Conservation Corps and the Chesapeake Conservation Corps, both managed or coordinated with DNR, as part of the department's mission and fund usage.
Program completion awards for participants of the Maryland Corps Program may be deposited into tax-exempt Maryland 529 accounts as one of the specified award options.
The Office of Legislative Audits is specifically required to conduct periodic audits of the newly established Young Adult and Maryland Service Year Option Pathway Funds.
The bill establishes focus areas for service placements in climate and environmental projects, including the creation of a Maryland Civilian Climate Corps.
The bill authorizes the creation of a Maryland Historic Trades Corps intended to place young veterans in regionally based work crews for the rehabilitation of state historic resources.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes the Tricare Premium Reimbursement Program within the Maryland Military Department. It authorizes the department to provide grants of up to $60 per month to members of the Maryland National Guard to reimburse them for premiums paid for health and dental insurance coverage under the TRICARE Reserve Select and TRICARE Dental programs for themselves and their immediate families.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Military Department
qa_results.stakeholders: Members of the Maryland National Guard and their immediate families
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $1,000,000 in FY 2024, representing contingent funding provided in the state budget for program implementation. These costs include approximately $280,600 for three new administrative positions and the remainder for grant awards. Annual expenditures for FY 2025 through FY 2028 are estimated between $871,300 and $909,200. The bill has no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Adjutant General serves as the head of the Maryland Military Department, which is the agency specifically tasked with establishing and administering the Tricare Premium Reimbursement Program and adopting necessary regulations.
Members of the Maryland National Guard are the primary beneficiaries of the bill, as the program provides them with financial grants to reimburse health and dental care premiums.
The bill has a significant fiscal impact of approximately $1 million annually and requires the creation of three new state positions, necessitating budget and personnel oversight from DBM.
As an Administration bill, this initiative is a policy priority for the Governor's Office, which oversees the Executive Branch and the Military Department.
As the state's principal financial officer and paymaster, the Comptroller's office will be responsible for processing the reimbursement payments to eligible National Guard members.
The agency is responsible for assisting military families in securing state benefits and may play a role in advocating for or communicating this new benefit to National Guard members.
The fiscal note suggests that some National Guard members currently utilizing the state's health insurance marketplace may transition to Tricare coverage due to the new subsidy.
The OAG will provide legal counsel to the Military Department to ensure that the program regulations and grant award processes comply with state law.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Fair Wage Act of 2023 accelerates the scheduled increase of the State minimum wage to $15.00 per hour for all employers beginning January 1, 2024. It also repeals the authority of the Board of Public Works to suspend these increases and repeals previously mandated provider rate increases for fiscal years 2025 and 2026.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employees earning less than $15 per hour, all Maryland employers including small businesses and governmental units, and community-based healthcare service providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $109.1 million in FY 2024 and 2025 for provider reimbursements, with a matching $97.6 million increase in federal funds. Local government expenditures increase for employee wages. The bill eliminates mandated appropriations for FY 2025 and 2026, though the FY 2024 budget includes $206.7 million contingent on the bill's enactment.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor's Commissioner of Labor and Industry is explicitly tasked with determining and announcing the annual minimum wage rate increases based on the Consumer Price Index (CPI) starting in 2025. The agency is also responsible for enforcing the Wage and Hour Law amended by this bill.

The bill substantially amends the Health - General Article, affecting reimbursement rates for community providers serving individuals with developmental disabilities and behavioral health needs, as well as nursing homes and medical day care providers. The Department of Health oversees these programs and their funding.

DBM is responsible for state personnel and the annual budget process. The bill repeals several mandated provider rate increases that the Governor must include in the budget and impacts the state's role as an employer for any remaining workers below the new threshold.
The bill repeals the specific statutory authority of the Board of Public Works to temporarily suspend scheduled minimum wage increases based on economic conditions.
The bill modifies the requirements for the Governor's proposed annual budget regarding mandatory provider rate increases and sets the executive branch's policy for the state minimum wage.
As a large state employer, USM is impacted by the acceleration of the minimum wage to $15.00, particularly regarding student workers and certain exempt employees as noted in the fiscal note.
As an independent state university, Morgan State is impacted by the minimum wage acceleration for its hourly and student workforce.
The college is an employer in the state system and faces fiscal impacts from the accelerated minimum wage requirements for its staff and student workers.

The Comptroller monitors the fiscal performance of state revenues, and the bill has implications for personal income tax and sales tax revenues due to changes in worker purchasing power and business payroll expenses.
The bill impacts providers of home- and community-based services and nursing homes, which are critical components of the network overseen and supported by the Department of Aging.
The changes to provider reimbursement rates for community-based services directly affect the organizations that provide care for Marylanders with disabilities.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the agencies implementing these changes and may be involved in legal interpretations of the amended Labor and Employment and Health-General statutes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Recovery Residence Grant Program within the Maryland Department of Health. The program's purpose is to award competitive grants to nonprofit recovery residences that provide alcohol-free and drug-free housing for individuals with substance-related or addictive disorders. To qualify, residences must be certified as a Level I, II, or III recovery residence and provide peer support services.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit recovery residences, individuals in recovery from substance-related or addictive disorders, and peer support service providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $500,000 annually from FY 2024 through FY 2027 due to a mandated appropriation. Funding is assumed to continue as discretionary in FY 2028 and beyond. These funds cover both the grant awards and the administrative costs of one program administrator within the Maryland Department of Health. There is no impact on local government revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the Maryland Department of Health to submit an annual report on the Recovery Residence Grant Program to the Governor. Additionally, the Governor oversees the executive branch agencies involved and proposes the state budget which must include the mandated appropriation.

The bill mandates an annual appropriation of $500,000 for the program from FY 2024 through FY 2027. As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM is responsible for supervising the budget execution and managing the new personnel positions required to administer the grant program.

The Maryland Department of Health is the primary agency responsible for establishing, administering, and reporting on the Recovery Residence Grant Program. It must establish application procedures, prioritize grants, and consult with credentialing entities.

While the program is housed in the Department of Health, recovery residences are a form of specialized housing. DHCD's mission includes ensuring access to safe and secure housing, creating a policy intersection with recovery housing initiatives.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Maryland Department of Health and would likely be involved in drafting the regulations for the new grant program and reviewing grant contracts.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: GOCPP coordinates public safety and criminal justice strategies, which often involve policy development related to substance abuse recovery and recidivism reduction, making the establishment of a recovery residence grant program relevant to their policy scope.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the required annual state appropriation for the Maryland Meals for Achievement In-Classroom Breakfast Program from $7,550,000 to $12,050,000 to provide funding for schools to make in-classroom breakfasts available to all students.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland students, local school systems, and eligible nonpublic schools
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $4.5 million annually beginning in FY 2024. Local school systems receive the majority of this additional funding, and federal matching funds for school meals are expected to increase by up to $10 million annually.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the primary agency responsible for the administration and leadership of the Maryland Meals for Achievement In-Classroom Breakfast Program. The bill directly increases the mandatory appropriation that MSDE will manage and distribute to local school systems.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for developing the state's budget and supervising budget execution. This bill creates a mandated general fund appropriation of $12,050,000 annually, which DBM must incorporate into the Governor's budget proposal.

The Governor's Office is responsible for proposing the annual state budget. This bill explicitly mandates that the Governor include a specific increased appropriation of $12,050,000 for the program in the annual budget bill.

The Governor's Office for Children is tasked with reducing child poverty and food insecurity. The expansion of the In-Classroom Breakfast Program directly aligns with the agency's mission to improve access to health services and nutrition for Maryland's children.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill updates the name of the recipient of a previously mandated annual appropriation of $500,000 for fiscal years 2024 and 2025 from the Goodwill Excel Center to the Goodwill Industries of Chesapeake Excel Center in Baltimore City.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Goodwill Industries of Chesapeake Excel Center and adult students age 21 and older in Baltimore City.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal impact as it is clarifying in nature and does not change the amount of funding or the actual recipient. Current law requires the Governor to include a $500,000 appropriation for the center in the fiscal 2024 and 2025 budget bills, which is managed under the Maryland State Department of Education's Aid to Education program.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note explicitly states that the mandated appropriation for the Excel Center is included in the Maryland State Department of Education’s (MSDE) Aid to Education program budget. MSDE is the primary agency responsible for overseeing the funding and educational standards associated with this program.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for developing the state budget and supervising budget execution. As this bill involves a mandated appropriation that must be included in the annual budget bill, DBM is directly involved in ensuring the technical name change is reflected in fiscal planning.

The bill requires the Governor to include a specific mandated appropriation in the annual budget bill. As the head of the executive branch and the entity responsible for proposing the state budget, the Governor's Office is directly responsible for implementing the funding mandate clarified by this name change.

The Maryland Department of Labor oversees adult learning and workforce development programs. Since the Excel Center is a planned adult high school designed to provide individuals age 21 and over with a high school diploma and industry certifications, the agency has significant functional and thematic relevance to the recipient's mission.

As the state's chief financial officer and the official responsible for paying state bills, the Comptroller must ensure that payments and appropriations are issued to the correctly named legal entity. A statutory name change for a grant recipient directly impacts the agency's disbursement and auditing processes.

The board is the chief policy-making body for the state's workforce system. The Excel Center's mission to provide adult education and workforce pathways aligns with the board's strategic goals of aligning education with Maryland's economic needs.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits service agreements related to the maintenance, purchase, or sale of residential property from lasting longer than one year, purporting to run with the land or bind future owners, creating a lien or security interest, or being assigned without notice and consent. Violations are categorized as unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practices, and the bill establishes criminal penalties for recording such prohibited agreements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the Attorney General, Consumer Protection Division; Clerks of the Circuit Courts
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential property owners, service providers for property maintenance or real estate transactions, real estate brokers, and subsequent property purchasers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's impact on state and local finances is expected to be minimal. The Office of the Attorney General, Consumer Protection Division, can handle enforcement within existing resources. While the bill establishes new criminal and civil penalties under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act, including a misdemeanor for recording prohibited agreements, these are not expected to materially affect state or local revenues or expenditures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly states that a violation of the service agreement prohibitions constitutes an unfair, abusive, or deceptive trade practice under the Maryland Consumer Protection Act (MCPA). The Office of the Attorney General is the primary agency responsible for enforcing consumer protection laws and investigating violations of the MCPA.

The bill directly impacts the operations of the Clerks of the Circuit Court, who are part of the Judicial Branch and managed by the AOC. The Clerks are authorized to deny the recordation of prohibited service agreements and are tasked with ensuring such documents do not provide constructive notice of liens. The bill also establishes specific civil actions that must be brought in Circuit Court.

The bill regulates service agreements for the 'maintenance, purchase, or sale of residential property.' The Department of Labor oversees the State Real Estate Commission and various professional licensing boards for contractors; these licensees are the primary 'service providers' whose contracts are restricted by this legislation.

The Department of Housing and Community Development is tasked with ensuring safe, secure, and affordable housing for Marylanders. This bill protects homeowners from predatory long-term service agreements that create liens on residential property, which directly aligns with the department's mission to support secure homeownership.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill establishes the Behavioral Health Care Coordination Value-Based Purchasing Pilot Program within the Maryland Department of Health. The program's purpose is to implement an intensive care coordination model for at least 500 adults at risk of hospital emergency department utilization or inpatient psychiatric hospital admission, using value-based purchasing to financially incentivize providers who meet specified outcome measures over a three-year operational period.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Adults with behavioral health conditions at risk of emergency department or inpatient hospital admission, and specialty behavioral health care providers.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $276,600 in FY 2024 for contractual staff and a consultant. The bill mandates an annual appropriation of $600,000 for FY 2025 through FY 2027 to support pilot program operations and provider reimbursements. Final expenditures of $59,400 are expected in FY 2028 to complete reporting requirements. There is no impact on State revenues or local government finances, though small business behavioral health providers may benefit from increased reimbursement.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include an annual appropriation of $600,000 in the budget for the pilot program from FY 2025 through 2027 and requires the Department of Health to report its findings and recommendations to the Governor.
As the agency responsible for budget development and execution, DBM oversees the $600,000 mandated annual appropriation for the pilot program specified in the bill.

Individuals with chronic behavioral health conditions often qualify as having disabilities; the department coordinates with other state agencies like MDH to ensure services are provided in integrated settings.
MDH is the primary agency responsible for establishing, administering, and evaluating the Behavioral Health Care Coordination Value-Based Purchasing Pilot Program.
The pilot program is specifically focused on using data-driven outcome measures and value-based purchasing to improve state service efficiency and responsiveness, which aligns with GOPI's mission.

The pilot program specifically aims to reduce hospital emergency department utilization and inpatient psychiatric admissions, which has a direct impact on the hospital revenues and expenditures regulated by the commission.
The MHCC oversees the state-designated Health Information Exchange (HIE), which is a required data exchange partner for providers participating in the pilot program.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDH and would be involved in reviewing any required Section 1115 HealthChoice demonstration waiver amendments or provider contracts related to the pilot program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the duties of the Parkinson’s Disease Registry Advisory Committee, requiring it to meet at least quarterly and submit recommendations for establishing a fully functional State Parkinson’s Disease Registry by July 1, 2024. It also requires the Maryland Department of Health, in collaboration with the State-designated health information exchange, to establish and maintain a publicly accessible website containing data on the incidence of Parkinson’s disease in Maryland, disaggregated by factors such as age, gender, race, and county.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Individuals with Parkinson’s disease and related parkinsonisms, healthcare providers (including neurologists and movement disorder specialists), health researchers, and the Maryland Department of Health.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $129,663 in FY 2024 to hire two part-time staff (a health policy analyst and an epidemiologist) to support the Advisory Committee and maintain the website. Costs are estimated to be $93,100 in FY 2025, gradually increasing to $106,500 by FY 2028. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDH is the primary agency responsible for establishing the Parkinson's disease website, collaborating with the health information exchange, and staffing the Parkinson's Disease Registry Advisory Committee.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly modifies the mandate, meeting frequency, and reporting requirements of the Parkinson's Disease Registry Advisory Committee.

The fiscal note indicates a need for new general fund expenditures and the hiring of 1.0 full-time equivalent personnel (split between a policy analyst and an epidemiologist), which falls under DBM's oversight of state personnel and budgeting.
The bill mandates the establishment of a publicly accessible website with downloadable health data, which relates to DoIT's role in coordinating state digital services and IT strategy.
The Governor oversees the executive branch departments involved and the advisory committee reports to the Secretary of Health, who is a gubernatorial appointee.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDH and the advisory committee, specifically regarding the privacy and confidentiality standards required for the disease registry data and website.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the application of the prohibition on noncompete and conflict of interest provisions in employment contracts. It increases the earnings threshold below which such provisions are considered null and void from a fixed amount to 150% of the Maryland State minimum wage rate.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland employees earning up to 150% of the state minimum wage and their employers, including small businesses.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State or local government finances or operations. Small businesses may experience minimal operational impacts to ensure compliance with the higher earnings threshold for noncompete prohibitions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Labor and Employment Article of the Maryland Code, which is the primary regulatory domain of the Maryland Department of Labor. The department oversees workforce development and enforces labor laws, making it the primary agency responsible for the bill's subject matter.

As the state's primary economic development agency, the Department of Commerce is concerned with the regulatory environment for businesses. The bill's restrictions on noncompete and conflict of interest provisions impact business operations, employee mobility, and the general competitive landscape for Maryland employers.

The bill establishes that certain employment contract provisions are null and void as a matter of public policy. This change in statutory law directly impacts the adjudication of civil disputes and contract litigation handled by the Maryland judicial system.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the chief legal representative for the state and provide counsel to state agencies. They would be responsible for advising executive departments on the enforcement and legal implications of the altered noncompete standards.

As the central personnel agency for the State of Maryland, the Department of Budget and Management must ensure that state employment policies and any applicable service contracts comply with the updated statutory prohibitions regarding noncompete and conflict of interest clauses for lower-wage earners.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Small, Minority & Women Business Affairs
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The fiscal note specifically identifies an operational impact on small businesses that must comply with the higher wage threshold for noncompete prohibitions. This office acts as a liaison to the small business community and would be responsible for outreach regarding these regulatory changes.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Department of State Police to submit an annual report to the Governor and the General Assembly regarding the acquisition of equipment by law enforcement agencies through federal surplus military equipment programs. It also requires the Department of State Police to maintain a link on its public website to the federal Defense Logistics Agency's report on property transfers to law enforcement agencies.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland law enforcement agencies, the Governor, the Maryland General Assembly, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The Department of State Police can implement the bill's reporting and website requirements using existing resources. There is no impact on state revenues or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates the Department of State Police (Maryland State Police) to compile and submit an annual report regarding surplus military equipment acquired by all law enforcement agencies in Maryland. The agency is also required to maintain a link to the federal Defense Logistics Agency's report on its public website.

The Governor's Office is the designated recipient of the annual report required by the bill. The data provided in the report informs the Governor's oversight of executive branch law enforcement agencies and policy initiatives regarding public safety.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As Maryland's primary coordinating body for public safety and criminal justice strategy, this office has a notable policy interest in the data collected regarding law enforcement equipment. The report on surplus military equipment supports their role in advising the Governor on criminal justice strategies and policy development.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes comprehensive requirements for virtual education in Maryland public schools. It mandates virtual instruction training for teachers, allows schools to use virtual learning days during severe weather, and sets operational and accountability standards for virtual schools. It also requires school boards to create plans for long-term emergencies and directs the Maryland State Department of Education to upgrade its cybersecurity infrastructure.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland public school students, teachers, parents, and local school systems
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by at least $100,000 in FY 2024 and $500,000 in FY 2025 to expand computer and internet security infrastructure. Local school systems are expected to implement the bill's requirements using existing resources, with no material impact on local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland State Department of Education (MSDE) is the primary agency responsible for implementing the bill's provisions, including establishing training standards for virtual education, expanding computer and Internet security infrastructure, approving virtual schools, and submitting multiple reports to the General Assembly.

The fiscal note indicates that MSDE must collaborate with the Department of Information Technology to improve and expand the state's computer and Internet security infrastructure to support simultaneous users in a virtual education environment.

The bill carries a notable fiscal impact, with general fund expenditures estimated at $600,000 over two fiscal years for MSDE to enhance IT security infrastructure, which falls under the fiscal and budgetary oversight of DBM.

The bill includes specific provisions regarding collective bargaining for public school employees assigned to virtual schools, including the ability to negotiate preparation time and synchronous instruction start times. The PERB oversees labor relations for local public school system personnel.
USM institutions operate teacher preparation programs that are required by the bill to include training in the skills and techniques for teaching effectively in a virtual learning environment.
Morgan State University operates a teacher preparation program that must incorporate training on virtual learning environments as a component of instruction per the bill's requirements.
As a state agency providing a Master of Arts in Teaching, St. Mary's College must update its teacher preparation program to include virtual education training skills and techniques.

The Commission coordinates policies for colleges and universities, including teacher preparation programs and for-profit career schools that are impacted by the bill's new instructional requirements for educators.

The bill references Medicaid and the Maryland Children's Health Program (MCHP) for defining student aid eligibility and requires schools to develop behavioral health plans that may include telehealth services regulated by the Department of Health.

The bill requires local boards to establish learning centers during prolonged states of emergency in suitable unoccupied buildings, specifically identifying unused State buildings which are managed by the Department of General Services.

The bill requires the collection and disaggregation of significant student data related to virtual education, attendance, and engagement, which may be linked and analyzed by the MLDS Center to evaluate educational outcomes.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the State Board of Education and MSDE as they develop new regulations for virtual schools and navigate legal aspects of collective bargaining and emergency education plans.

The bill addresses the operation of public schools during a 'prolonged state of emergency' declared by the Governor and requires the State Superintendent to report on the study of virtual education to the Governor.
The bill uses eligibility for programs administered by DHS, such as SNAP and TANF, to define 'students eligible for aid' for the purposes of educational support and resource allocation.

The bill references the U.S. Department of Agriculture Community Eligibility Provision and the provision of free meals during emergency virtual education, which overlaps with MDA's role in food quality and supporting nutritional infrastructure.
MDEM coordinates the state's response to disasters and emergencies; the bill's provisions for virtual education plans are triggered by prolonged states of emergency managed by this agency.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Lottery and Gaming Control Commission to license independent evaluators to evaluate and rate sports wagering content provided by experts, influencers, and content partners. It also authorizes the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission and the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission to consider requests to change the proposed location for certain Class B-2 sports wagering facility license applications submitted by December 31, 2023.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Lottery and Gaming Control Commission and the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Sports wagering licensees, sports wagering operators, sports wagering experts and influencers, content partners, and independent evaluators.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency administrative costs may increase beginning in fiscal 2024 to manage the licensing of independent evaluators, though a precise estimate of these expenditures is not yet available. There is no local fiscal impact.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland State Lottery & Gaming Control Agency
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly mandates the State Lottery and Gaming Control Commission (the regulatory body of this agency) to license independent evaluators, establish qualifications, and adopt regulations for sports wagering content. The fiscal note indicates that the agency will incur increased administrative costs to implement these new licensing requirements.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill specifically empowers the Sports Wagering Application Review Commission (SWARC), which falls under this category, to consider requests to amend Class B-2 sports wagering facility license applications for location changes.

As the chief legal officer for state agencies, the OAG will provide legal counsel to both the SLGCC and SWARC regarding the drafting of new regulations and the legal framework for licensing independent evaluators.

DBM is responsible for state budget development and personnel management. Since the fiscal note identifies an increase in administrative and operational costs for the State Lottery and Gaming Control Agency, DBM will be involved in managing those budget adjustments.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies involved and is responsible for appointing members to the commissions (SLGCC and SWARC) that are tasked with the bill's implementation and the awarding of licenses.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires that the seven members of the Health Services Cost Review Commission (HSCRC) be appointed by the Governor with the advice and consent of the Senate of Maryland.
qa_results.responsible_party: Governor of Maryland and the Maryland Senate
qa_results.stakeholders: Members and future appointees of the Health Services Cost Review Commission, the Governor, and the Maryland Senate.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no State or local fiscal impact because the change is procedural in nature and does not directly affect governmental finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the appointment process for the members of this Commission, requiring them to be appointed with the advice and consent of the Senate.
The Governor is the appointing authority for the Commission. This bill changes the Governor's appointment procedure by requiring Senate confirmation for these specific positions.

This office assists the Governor in the recruitment and vetting of candidates for boards and commissions. It will be responsible for managing the updated appointment process and coordinating Senate confirmation for HSCRC members.
The Health Services Cost Review Commission is an independent regulatory agency located within the Maryland Department of Health.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Governor and state commissions regarding the legal and constitutional requirements for appointments and Senate confirmations.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Historic St. Mary's City Commission Reform Act of 2023 alters the governance and membership of the Historic St. Mary's City Commission. It revises the composition of the commission to include a representative from the Native American community, changes the status of certain ex officio members, and mandates the creation of written operating policies for administrative functions such as procurement and human resources. Additionally, it establishes a formal framework for collaborating with affiliated nonprofit organizations and requires progress reports on previous audit concerns.
qa_results.responsible_party: Historic St. Mary’s City Commission
qa_results.stakeholders: Historic St. Mary's City Commission members, the Historic St. Mary's City Foundation, St. Mary’s College of Maryland, the Maryland Native American community, and the general public.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to materially affect Maryland State or local government finances or operations. Small business impacts are described as minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill is the primary governing legislation for this agency, altering its membership, officers, meeting requirements, and duties, including the mandate to develop specific operating and maintenance policies.
The bill requires the Attorney General to review and approve the Commission's operating agreements and collaboration policies for form and legal sufficiency.

The bill tasks the State Ethics Commission with reviewing and approving conflict-of-interest policies regarding officials serving on affiliated nonprofit boards and requires the Commission to submit annual reports on joint service.
The bill explicitly subjects the Historic St. Mary’s City Fund to audits by the Office of Legislative Audits.
The bill governs the relationship and collaborative agreements between the Commission and the College, and the College's Board Chair serves as an ex officio member of the Commission.
The bill alters the composition and appointment process for several members of the Commission, which the Office of Appointments manages for the Governor.
The Governor is responsible for appointing the majority of the Commission members and receives the Commission's annual reports as well as specific reports on nonprofit collaboration.
The bill requires the appointment of a Native American representative in consultation with the Maryland Commission on Indian Affairs, which is housed within this office.
The bill mandates the Commission to develop internal policies for human resources, payroll, and procurement, areas typically overseen or standardized by DBM for state agencies.
The bill requires the Commission to develop policies for fleet and property management, which falls under the broader administrative oversight of DGS.
The bill's requirements for procurement and property management policies intersect with the Board of Public Works' role in overseeing state contracts and property transfers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows law enforcement officers of the City of Bowie Police Department hired between January 1, 2007, and December 31, 2015, to transfer or purchase service credit within the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS). The bill specifically targets individuals who were not provided with accurate information regarding their eligibility to transfer service credit at the time of their hiring.
qa_results.responsible_party: Board of Trustees for the State Retirement and Pension System
qa_results.stakeholders: Law enforcement officers of the City of Bowie Police Department hired between 2007 and 2015 and Participating Governmental Units (PGUs) within the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State revenues or expenditures. Locally, the bill is expected to result in a minimal increase in pension liabilities for Participating Governmental Units (PGUs) that participate in the Law Enforcement Officers' Pension System, but it is unlikely to have a discernible effect on PGU employer contribution rates. There is no effect on local revenues.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the administrative body for the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), including the Law Enforcement Officers’ Pension System (LEOPS), this agency is responsible for implementing the bill's provisions, including processing service credit transfers and purchases for eligible City of Bowie police officers.
As the state's central personnel and fiscal agency, DBM manages employee benefits and policies, including the oversight and fiscal planning of state-administered retirement systems like LEOPS.

As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller is involved in the fiscal management and oversight of state revenues and serves on boards that govern state expenditures, including pension-related matters.
The Treasurer's Office manages state funds and serves as the custodian of state securities and investments, including those within the state's retirement and pension portfolios.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies responsible for implementing this bill, including the Maryland State Retirement Agency, and the Governor is responsible for signing the legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires health care providers and facilities to provide local maternal mortality review teams with prompt access to relevant medical records for cases under review by the Maternal Mortality Review Program without undue delay. It also specifies that state laws regarding the confidentiality of medical records do not apply to disclosures made to these local review teams.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and local health officers
qa_results.stakeholders: Health care providers, health care facilities, local maternal mortality review teams, and the Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact, as the changes are procedural in nature and do not materially affect governmental finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) oversees the Maternal Mortality Review Program and the local health officers who are responsible for convening the local review teams. The bill directly impacts MDH's protocols for data access and the management of maternal death case reviews.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The local maternal mortality review teams are multidisciplinary, multi-agency bodies established to address a specific public health issue. This bill directly regulates the powers of these teams, specifically their right to prompt access to medical records.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to MDH and state boards regarding the interpretation of medical record confidentiality laws (Health-General Title 4, Subtitle 3), which are specifically referenced and modified in their application to this program by the bill.

The Commission is responsible for health system planning and improving health service quality. The bill involves health care facilities defined under Title 19, which falls under the regulatory and planning interest of the Commission, particularly regarding outcomes and accountability in maternal health.

As noted in the fiscal note, the Department of Human Services is a key stakeholder and information source for the multi-agency maternal mortality review teams, providing records related to social services as part of the broader review process.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The agency is identified as an information source for maternal mortality review teams, as these teams often require access to parole and probation records to conduct comprehensive reviews of deceased individuals' circumstances.
The Maryland State Police is a stakeholder in the maternal mortality review process, as local teams are authorized to access law enforcement investigative information to carry out their duties.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes nursing homes to direct electronic health network (EHN) or electronic medical record (EMR) vendors to release patient medical records and electronic health care transactions to a business associate of the nursing home. The bill requires these records to be released in a specific electronic format, in a timely manner, and prohibits vendors from charging fees or restricting access to these records.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Nursing home residents and their representatives, nursing home facilities, electronic health network vendors, and electronic medical record vendors.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not directly affect State or local government operations or finances. The impact on small businesses is estimated to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Health Care Commission (MHCC) is the primary regulatory body that certifies Electronic Health Networks (EHNs) and designates the statewide Health Information Exchange (HIE). The bill directly impacts EHN regulations and requires the HIE to approve certain fees and technical standards for the release of nursing home records.

The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) regulates nursing homes and is responsible for setting health facility policy. The bill specifically amends the Health - General Article regarding nursing home data sharing and mandates that clinical information be submitted to the state-designated HIE which MDH uses for public health monitoring.

The Office of the Attorney General (OAG) provides legal counsel to MDH and MHCC regarding the interpretation and enforcement of state health laws. This bill requires coordination with the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA), necessitating legal guidance from the OAG on compliance and record-release protocols.

The Department of Aging is dedicated to protecting the rights and quality of life for older adults in nursing homes. While not the primary implementer of electronic record standards, the agency has a significant interest in policies that affect the management and release of health information for residents in long-term care facilities.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the State Disaster Recovery Fund (SDRF) as a special, nonlapsing fund to provide disaster-related assistance to individuals, families, local governments, businesses, and nonprofits, primarily when federal disaster aid is unavailable. Administered by the Maryland Department of Emergency Management (MDEM), the fund provides grants and low-interest loans. The bill also allows local governments to receive funding directly from the existing Catastrophic Event Account.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Emergency Management
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents, individuals, families, local government units, businesses, and nonprofits impacted by disasters.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: General fund expenditures increase by $10,000,000 in FY 2024 to capitalize the fund. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase accordingly as funds are appropriated and disbursed for disaster aid. Administrative costs for the Maryland Department of Emergency Management are estimated at $344,442 in FY 2024, rising to $473,915 by FY 2028. Local governments will see increased revenues and expenditures when they receive disaster recovery assistance. Federal fund revenues may increase through reimbursements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: MDEM is the primary agency responsible for administering the State Disaster Recovery Fund, establishing its eligibility criteria and policies, and submitting annual reports on the fund's status and expenditures.

The Governor is responsible for declaring the states of emergency that trigger fund use, including fund appropriations in the annual budget, and authorizing the transfer of funds to state units via budget amendments.
DBM oversees the state budget process for the fund and administers the Catastrophic Event Account, which the bill modifies to allow direct funding to units of local government.
The bill specifically mandates that the State Treasurer invest the money in the State Disaster Recovery Fund and credit interest earnings back to the fund.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the State Disaster Recovery Fund and handle the fiscal tracking of expenditures and interest accruals.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDEM and the Governor's office regarding the development of regulations, eligibility criteria, and potential loan agreements for disaster recovery assistance.
The fund provides low-interest or no-interest loans to businesses for disaster recovery assistance, which aligns with the Department of Commerce's mission to support and retain Maryland businesses.
The fund provides assistance for the repair and replacement of public facilities and individual recovery, which may overlap with DHCD's role in community revitalization and infrastructure support.

DHS is the state's primary social service provider for individuals in need; the fund's provision for disaster-related assistance to families and individuals for unmet needs makes DHS a likely consulting partner for MDEM.
Natural disasters often severely impact the agricultural sector; the fund provides a secondary source of assistance for farming businesses and rural local governments.
DGS manages and maintains state-owned facilities; as the fund provides for the repair and replacement of public facilities damaged in disasters, DGS may be involved in implementing these projects.
MDOT manages significant public infrastructure, such as highways and bridges, that are classified as public facilities and may require repair or replacement funding following a disaster.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill authorizes MDEM to establish formal advisory bodies to assist in the administration and oversight of the State Disaster Recovery Fund.
GOHS coordinates statewide disaster preparedness and response strategies, which directly intersects with the allocation of recovery funds during state-level emergencies.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill, known as the Anthony Moorman Act, establishes specific procedures for the distribution of trust money (earnest money deposits) when a residential real estate contract is terminated under a contingency clause. It mandates that a real estate broker or escrow agent must return the trust money to the purchaser if the seller fails to provide proof of a filed court complaint or mediation request within 10 days of the purchaser's request. The bill also provides liability protection for trust money holders who distribute funds in good faith according to these procedures and allows aggrieved parties to file actions in District Court.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Real Estate Commission and the Maryland Judiciary
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential real estate purchasers, sellers, licensed real estate brokers, and escrow agents in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill is not expected to have a material impact on Maryland state or local finances. State and local revenues and expenditures are anticipated to remain unchanged, and the bill's effect on small businesses is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor oversees the State Real Estate Commission, which is responsible for licensing and regulating real estate brokers and salespersons. This bill directly amends the Business Occupations and Professions Article (Title 17) which governs these professionals and their handling of trust money.

The bill explicitly authorizes claimants aggrieved by trust money distributions to file actions in the District Court. It also establishes a procedural requirement for sellers to provide copies of court complaints to escrow agents to halt the distribution of funds.

The Office of the Attorney General's Consumer Protection Division is cited in the fiscal note and often investigates disputes related to real estate practices and consumer contracts. This bill impacts the legal rights and remedies available to residential property purchasers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This annual corrective bill makes technical changes to the Annotated Code of Maryland by fixing errors or omissions, clarifying language, updating obsolete references, and reorganizing certain sections. The bill is intended only to correct technical issues and does not substantively change existing laws.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland State government agencies, legal professionals, and the general public who utilize the Annotated Code of Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact as it is technical in nature and does not affect governmental operations or finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the head of the executive branch, the Governor's Office oversees the administrative support and implementation of the state budget and laws. This bill is an emergency measure signed by the Governor to correct technical errors across the Annotated Code of Maryland, which affects the administration of the executive branch.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies and is frequently cited in the bill's Drafter's Notes as the source for suggested technical corrections and legal clarifications.

The bill contains extensive technical corrections to the Maryland Code of Military Justice, including provisions on courts-martial, nonjudicial punishment, and the authority of the Adjutant General over the Maryland National Guard.

The bill makes numerous corrections to the Health-General and Health Occupations Articles, including updates to the State-Designated Health Information Exchange, regulatory authority for controlled substances, and dental assistant certifications.

A significant portion of the bill is dedicated to correcting errors in the Education Article, including provisions related to school health programs, teacher career ladders, and financial aid programs.

The bill updates references from 'Director' to 'Secretary' of Emergency Management throughout the Public Safety Article, specifically regarding the Maryland Food System Resiliency Council and mutual aid agreements.
The bill corrects technical errors and cross-references in the Natural Resources Article, affecting Program Open Space, the Chesapeake Bay Critical Area Commission, and regulated shooting grounds.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill clarifies the name and role of the Maryland Police Training and Standards Commission and corrects several references within the Public Safety Article regarding firearms and correctional personnel.

The bill corrects grammatical and stylistic errors in the Environment Article, including provisions related to lead poisoning prevention and the definitions of persons and residential dwellings in environmental regulations.
The bill corrects references to tax collection, video lottery terminal proceeds, and the transfer of tobacco regulatory oversight from the Comptroller to the Alcohol and Tobacco Commission.

The bill corrects cross-references and language in the Education Article specifically related to the commission's regulations on school facility maintenance and alternative financing for Prince George’s County schools.
The bill includes technical corrections to the Human Services Article regarding vocational education reporting for welfare recipients and departmental implementation of recommendations.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill classifies the short-term use of residential property features—such as swimming pools or backyards, but excluding sleeping quarters—as a 'home amenity rental' subject to the state sales and use tax. It defines home amenity rental intermediaries and platforms and grants Maryland counties and municipalities the authority to impose local taxes on these rentals at specified maximum rates.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Residential property owners offering amenities for rent, home amenity rental platforms and intermediaries, consumers who rent home amenities, and Maryland county and municipal governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund and special fund revenues are expected to increase beginning in FY 2025 based on rental volume; every $100,000 in taxable rentals generates $6,000 in state revenue. Local revenues for counties and municipalities will also increase if they choose to impose the newly authorized local home amenity rental taxes. Both state and local governments may incur additional administrative expenditures to manage and collect these taxes.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the state's chief tax collector and is responsible for collecting and enforcing the sales and use tax, which this bill expands to include home amenity rentals.
The Maryland Tax Court is the highest level of administrative review for tax disputes; it will adjudicate appeals related to the assessment and collection of the new home amenity rental taxes.
DBM is responsible for revenue estimation and long-term fiscal planning. This bill impacts the state's General Fund and the Blueprint for Maryland's Future Fund through new sales tax revenues.
The OAG provides legal counsel to the Comptroller and would represent the state in civil litigation or enforcement actions related to the new tax provisions.
The Treasurer's Office manages and protects state funds and receives the revenue collected from state taxes, including the sales and use tax.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and proposes the annual state budget, which will be affected by the additional revenue generated by this tax.
A specific percentage of sales and use tax revenue is distributed to the Blueprint for Maryland's Future Fund, which MSDE uses to fund public education programs.

OLA conducts fiscal compliance audits of state agencies, including the Comptroller; the implementation of a new tax category increases the scope of their auditing responsibilities regarding state revenue.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources (DNR) to exchange State-owned real property of five acres or less for adjacent privately owned real property without following standard statutory disposal procedures. The exchange is permitted if the private property owner pays all associated costs, and the DNR provides written notification to adjacent property owners, local General Assembly members, and the county governing body, with final approval required from the Board of Public Works.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Private property owners with land adjacent to State-owned natural resources property, the Maryland Department of Natural Resources, the Board of Public Works, and local county governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no direct effect on State operations or finances as it is authorizing in nature. Private owners requesting an exchange are required to pay all associated costs, including legal fees, surveying, engineering, and recordation costs. There is minimal or no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly authorizes the Department of Natural Resources to exchange real property under its use for private land, bypassing standard disposal procedures.
The bill requires that any proposed property exchange by the Department of Natural Resources be referred to the Board of Public Works for final disposition.

The bill allows certain land exchanges to bypass the standard excess real property procedures overseen by the Department of Planning, such as the requirement for the agency to study the disposition and notify other units of government.

The bill exempts specific land exchanges from standard state procurement and property disposal laws that usually require the Department of General Services to provide independent appraisals or oversee the transfer.
The Governor sits on the Board of Public Works, which is responsible for the final approval of any land exchanges conducted under this bill.
The Comptroller is a member of the Board of Public Works, which is the final authority for approving the real property exchanges authorized by this bill.
The State Treasurer is a member of the Board of Public Works, which must approve any property exchanges initiated by the Department of Natural Resources.
The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies and the Board of Public Works, and would be involved in the legal review of any property exchange agreements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill allows members or former members of the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS) to receive service credit for time spent attending a United States service academy. Eligible individuals can receive credit at the rate of four months for each full year of attendance, up to a maximum of 16 months, regardless of whether the attendance preceded or interrupted their employment.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Retirement Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Members and former members of the State Retirement and Pension System who attended a United States service academy; State and local retirement systems; Maryland State government; local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal effect until FY 2026. A reliable estimate of the total cost is not feasible because the number of members who attended service academies is unknown. However, the average employer cost for a member to claim the maximum 16 months of credit ranges from $1,200 to $3,600 depending on the specific pension plan. Costs are expected to be funded by 60% general funds, 20% special funds, and 20% federal and other funds. Local government impacts are expected to be limited.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the administrative body for the State Retirement and Pension System (SRPS), this agency is the primary entity responsible for implementing the bill, processing member applications for academy service credit, and managing the resulting impact on the system's liabilities.

As the principal personnel and fiscal agency, DBM manages state employee benefits and the state budget. The bill has a direct fiscal impact on the state's retirement contributions and relates to the benefits package provided to state employees.

The bill and fiscal note specifically identify the State Police Retirement System as an affected plan. Members of this agency who attended a service academy would be eligible for increased service credit.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill and fiscal note specifically identify the Correctional Officers Retirement System as an affected plan. Members of this agency are primary participants in this system and would be impacted by the expanded credit eligibility.

The bill and fiscal note specifically identify the Judges' Retirement System as an affected plan. The AOC provides operational and financial support to the judiciary, which is impacted by changes to this pension plan.
The Teachers' Retirement and Pension Systems, which are overseen and led by MSDE, represent a significant portion of the fiscal impact and membership affected by this bill.
The agency is responsible for assisting veterans and military families in securing benefits. This bill expands a state benefit specifically for individuals with military service academy backgrounds.
The bill specifically amends sections of the State Personnel and Pensions Article that govern service credit for members of the Maryland National Guard.

As the senior military advisor to the Governor and head of the Military Department, the Adjutant General oversees the personnel who are directly named in the sections of law being amended by this bill.

The OAG provides legal counsel to all state agencies, including the State Retirement Agency, and would be responsible for advising on the interpretation and legal implementation of these pension changes.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and proposes the annual state budget, which will be impacted by the increased employer pension contributions required by this bill starting in FY 2026.

The Comptroller, as the state's chief financial officer, is responsible for paying state employees and serves as a key member of boards overseeing state fiscal policy, including the financial health of the pension system.

The Treasurer's Office manages state funds and anticipates monetary needs. Changes to the state's long-term pension liabilities impact the financial management duties and fiscal planning overseen by the Treasurer.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Motor Vehicle Administration from charging a fee for a new certificate of title issued to a surviving spouse upon the death of a sole vehicle owner, provided the transfer follows specific legal procedures. This aligns the fee structure for sole owners with the existing exemption for joint owners who are surviving spouses.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Surviving spouses of deceased sole vehicle owners in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund revenues are projected to decrease by approximately $375,000 in FY 2024 and by $500,000 annually thereafter due to the elimination of the $100 titling fee for an estimated 5,000 surviving spouses each year. The bill has no material effect on state expenditures or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The MVA is the primary agency implementing this bill as it is specifically prohibited from charging the $100 title fee to surviving spouses and must manage the administrative process for these transfers.

As the parent agency of the MVA, MDOT oversees the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), which will see an annual revenue decrease of approximately $500,000 due to the fee exemption established by this bill.

The Register of Wills manages the probate process and issues the legal documentation, such as letters testamentary, required to prove a spouse's right to a vehicle title transfer under this legislation.
DBM is responsible for state budget development and revenue estimation; it must account for the reduction in Transportation Trust Fund revenues resulting from this bill.
The judicial branch oversees the Orphans' Courts and the probate processes that generate the legal certificates required by the MVA to verify ownership transfers for surviving spouses.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive agencies involved (MDOT and MVA) and provided the final approval for this departmental legislation intended to ease financial burdens on residents.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires deputy State fire marshals to remain in probationary status for two years following their appointment and establishes specific pay entitlements for these employees upon promotion. This effectively aligns the probationary period and promotional pay structure for deputy State fire marshals with those of other police employees within the Department of State Police.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of State Police and the Office of the State Fire Marshal
qa_results.stakeholders: Deputy State fire marshals and the Department of State Police
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no fiscal impact on state or local finances as it codifies existing administrative practices for deputy State fire marshals.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly concerns the personnel policies, probationary periods, and promotional pay scales for Deputy State Fire Marshals, who are employees within the Department of State Police's Office of the State Fire Marshal. The Department of State Police also requested the bill.

As the principal personnel and fiscal agency for the state, the Department of Budget and Management is responsible for overseeing state employee policies and is explicitly required by the bill to approve the pay plans developed for these employees.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and the bill requires the Governor's final approval for the pay plans to take effect, subject to available funding in the state budget.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to conduct State and national criminal history records checks for individuals seeking to become youth camp owners, operators, employees, or volunteers. MDH is required to provide a written determination to the camp operator within three business days regarding whether an applicant's criminal history prohibits their employment. The bill also repeals provisions that allowed 'youth development organizations or programs' to request similar hiring determinations from MDH.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Youth camp owners, operators, employees, volunteers, and children who attend youth camps.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $172,030 in FY 2024 to support the hiring of one full-time administrator and eight temporary contractual staff to process background checks. Expenditures are estimated to increase annually, reaching $207,200 by FY 2028. General fund revenues will increase by an indeterminate amount because MDH is authorized to collect fees to offset the costs of the records checks. There is no anticipated fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Health is the primary implementing agency for the bill; it is responsible for applying for criminal history records checks for youth camp applicants and issuing written determinations regarding their employment eligibility within three business days.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill explicitly mandates that the Criminal Justice Information System (CJIS) Central Repository, which is housed within this department, process both state and national criminal history records checks for thousands of youth camp applicants annually.

The fiscal note indicates a significant expenditure increase and the need for new regular and contractual personnel positions at the Department of Health, which requires oversight and approval from the Department of Budget and Management.

As the chief legal officer for the state, the Office of the Attorney General will provide legal guidance to the Department of Health on the implementation of these new regulatory requirements and the legal criteria used to prohibit employment based on criminal records.

The Comptroller oversees the collection of state revenues; the bill authorizes the Department of Health to set and collect fees to cover the costs of processing criminal history records checks, which impacts state general fund revenues.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments involved in implementing the bill and is responsible for proposing the annual state budget, which must accommodate the fiscal impacts identified in the bill's fiscal note.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the duration of a commercial driver's instructional permit from 180 days to one year and exempts commercial driver's license (CDL) holders from the requirement to pass a vision test during license renewal if they have a current certificate of physical examination on file with the Motor Vehicle Administration.
qa_results.responsible_party: Motor Vehicle Administration
qa_results.stakeholders: Commercial driver's license (CDL) holders and instructional permit applicants
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State Transportation Trust Fund revenues are expected to decrease by approximately $263,300 in FY 2024 and $351,000 annually thereafter because fewer individuals will need to pay for and obtain a second instructional permit. Expenditures are not materially affected, though the Motor Vehicle Administration may experience operational efficiencies due to reduced testing requirements.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration and manager of the Transportation Trust Fund, MDOT is directly impacted by the reduction in fee revenue and the administrative changes to licensing procedures.
The MVA is the primary implementing agency responsible for issuing commercial instructional permits, managing driver records, and updating renewal requirements for commercial driver's licenses.
DBM is responsible for state revenue estimation and long-term fiscal planning, and must account for the projected $351,000 annual decrease in Transportation Trust Fund revenue.
DoIT manages the state's IT strategy and may be involved in updating the MVA's software systems to handle new expiration dates and vision test exemption logic.
The bill aims to ease the shortage of qualified CDL drivers, which directly supports the department's mission of workforce development and supporting state businesses.
The board develops innovative workforce solutions, and addressing the shortage of CDL drivers aligns with the state's economic and talent pipeline goals.
As the primary enforcer of motor vehicle laws, the State Police must be aware of the updated expiration periods for commercial instructional permits during traffic stops and inspections.
The OAG provides legal counsel to MDOT and MVA regarding the implementation of statutory changes and compliance with federal motor carrier safety regulations.
The bill is expected to create operational efficiencies for the MVA by reducing the volume of permit retesting, aligning with GOPI's mission to enhance government efficiency.
As a major employer of bus drivers requiring CDLs, the MTA is impacted by policies that ease the process for obtaining and maintaining commercial driver's licenses.
SHA relies on CDL-licensed drivers for highway maintenance and snow removal operations, and is impacted by efforts to address the state's commercial driver shortage.
MDTA maintains its own police force and facility maintenance staff requiring CDLs, and is impacted by changes to enforcement standards and driver availability.
MAA requires commercial drivers for various airport operations and is impacted by the broader policy goals of increasing the pool of qualified CDL holders.
The efficiency of waterborne commerce depends on the availability of CDL-licensed truck drivers, making the bill's intent to ease driver shortages relevant to MPA's mission.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board of Architects within the Maryland Department of Labor by five years, from July 1, 2023, to July 1, 2028, ensuring the continued regulation and licensing of architects in the state.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Architects, Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Licensed architects, businesses practicing architecture, and individuals seeking architectural licensure in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State special fund revenues and expenditures for the board are maintained from fiscal 2024 through 2028. There is no impact on local government finances and minimal or no impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of Labor is the primary agency affected by the bill, as the State Board of Architects is a regulatory unit within this department. The bill was also introduced as a departmental bill by Labor.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Board of Architects is an ongoing regulatory body that fits the description of the boards and commissions included in this collective entity.
The Governor oversees the executive branch departments, including Labor, and is responsible for signing the legislation that extends the Board's termination date.
The OAG provides legal counsel to state boards and commissions, including the State Board of Architects, regarding regulatory and disciplinary matters.
DBM oversees the state's personnel and budget execution; the bill maintains special fund revenues and expenditures for the Board through 2028.
The OAH handles contested cases and licensing disputes resulting from the regulatory and enforcement actions of the State Board of Architects.
OLA is responsible for periodic fiscal compliance and performance audits of executive branch entities like the Board of Architects.
The Office of Appointments assists the Governor in fulfilling the statutory duty to appoint qualified members to the State Board of Architects.
The Comptroller's Office is responsible for collecting and accounting for state revenues, including the fees collected by professional licensing boards.
The Treasurer manages the state's funds, including the receipt and distribution of the special funds used to operate the Board of Architects.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date and regulatory authority of the State Board of Certified Interior Designers within the Maryland Department of Labor by 10 years, from July 1, 2024, to July 1, 2034.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor
qa_results.stakeholders: Certified interior designers in Maryland and the Maryland Department of Labor.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill maintains special fund revenues and expenditures for the State Board of Certified Interior Designers from fiscal 2025 through 2034. There is no fiscal impact on local governments.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Labor is the primary agency for this bill as it directly oversees the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, which is being extended by this legislation.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and the Governor signed the bill extending the board's termination date.
The OAG serves as the legal counsel for all state boards, including the State Board of Certified Interior Designers, and is impacted by its continued existence.
The Office of Appointments is responsible for recruiting and vetting members for state boards; extending this board's life ensures the office's ongoing role in managing its membership.
DBM oversees the budget and personnel management for the Department of Labor and its constituent boards, ensuring fiscal alignment for maintained special funds.
