agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The department employs a significant number of law enforcement officers, including correctional and parole officers, who would be eligible for the State park pass discount under the bill's provisions.
The department coordinates Maryland's preparedness and response efforts and works closely with the first responder community, whose members are eligible for the park pass discount.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Institute for Emergency Medical Services Systems
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: This agency oversees the state's emergency medical services network; the EMS personnel within this network are defined as first responders and are thus eligible for the pass discount.

The fiscal note highlights that members of the Maryland National Guard currently receive similar park fee waivers, providing a relevant comparison and operational context for the expansion of benefits to other law enforcement and first responders.

qa_results.bill_summary: The bill requires the Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and the Maryland Department of Health (MDH) to conduct two specific studies. The first study examines staffing needs for environmental health specialists in local health departments, focusing on education, licensing, and wage competitiveness. The second study evaluates the delegation of MDE's well and septic system permitting authority to MDH, including its benefits, challenges, and potential organizational improvements.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) and Maryland Department of Health (MDH)
qa_results.stakeholders: Environmental health specialists, local health departments, and applicants for well and septic system permits.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State and local finances are not materially affected. MDE and MDH are expected to implement the bill using existing budgeted resources. Local approving authorities can provide necessary data and information within existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Department of the Environment (MDE) is one of the two primary lead agencies responsible for conducting both studies mandated by the bill. MDE must lead the study on environmental health specialist staffing needs and the study on the delegation of well and septic system permitting authority, which is currently their own delegated power.

The Maryland Department of Health (MDH) is a primary lead agency for the study on staffing needs for environmental health specialists. Additionally, MDH is the recipient of the delegated authority for well and septic permitting which is the subject of the second study.

The bill explicitly requires the study on well and septic permitting to be conducted in consultation with the University of Maryland Agriculture and Food Systems Extension Program, which is a component of the University System of Maryland.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Board of Environmental Health Specialists is specifically required by the bill to work 'in conjunction with' MDE and MDH to conduct the study on staffing needs, recruitment, and licensing requirements.
The bill requires the findings and recommendations from both mandated studies to be submitted to the Governor by the reporting deadlines.

The studies mandated by the bill require an analysis of wage competitiveness and staffing needs for state-regulated positions, which directly falls under DBM's role as the central personnel and fiscal agency for the state.

As the chief legal officer for state agencies, the OAG will likely provide counsel on the legal implications of the 'delegation of authority' study, which examines the administrative structure and accountability of permitting powers.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Protecting Against Hate Crimes Grant Fund as a special, nonlapsing fund to provide grants to nonprofit and faith-based organizations for security enhancements. The fund is administered by the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services, which is required to establish grant procedures and set aside at least $1 million annually specifically for faith-based institutions. The bill authorizes the Governor to include an annual appropriation of $5 million for the fund starting in fiscal year 2025.
qa_results.responsible_party: Executive Director of the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Nonprofit and faith-based organizations in Maryland
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $5,000,000 annually starting in FY 2025 to capitalize the fund. Special fund revenues and expenditures increase by $5,000,000 in FY 2024 and $10,000,000 annually thereafter, assuming existing program funds and the new authorized appropriation flow through the special fund. No local fiscal impact is expected.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of Crime Prevention and Policy
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Executive Director of this office (referred to in the bill as the Governor's Office of Crime Prevention, Youth, and Victim Services) is the primary administrator of the Protecting Against Hate Crimes Grant Fund, responsible for establishing grant procedures, distributing funds to nonprofits, and reporting annually to the General Assembly.
The bill authorizes the Governor to include a $5 million annual appropriation in the budget to capitalize the fund and assigns implementation to a sub-unit within the Executive Department.
As the principal fiscal and personnel agency, DBM is responsible for overseeing the budget process and the $5 million annual general fund expenditure authorized by the bill.
The bill specifically requires the State Treasurer to hold the Protecting Against Hate Crimes Grant Fund separately and to invest the money in the fund.
The bill explicitly requires the Comptroller to account for the Protecting Against Hate Crimes Grant Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Governor to include a $500,000 annual appropriation in the state budget for the Maryland State Department of Education to provide grants to local school systems. These grants are dedicated to covering expenses for student field trips to 'museums of cultural import,' which include the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, the National Museum of African American History and Culture, the Jewish Museum of Maryland, and the Reginald F. Lewis Museum of Maryland African American History and Culture.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland State Department of Education
qa_results.stakeholders: Local school systems and Maryland public school students.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $500,000 annually beginning in FY 2025 due to the mandated appropriation. Local school systems receive $500,000 in annual grant funding statewide starting in FY 2025, with expenditures increasing accordingly to facilitate the field trips. The Maryland State Department of Education can administer the grant program using existing resources.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates that the Governor include a $500,000 appropriation in the annual budget bill for student field trip grants, directly involving the Governor's primary constitutional and statutory duty to propose the state budget.

The Maryland State Department of Education is the primary agency responsible for administering the $500,000 grant program for local school systems and submitting the mandated annual report to the General Assembly.

The Department of Budget and Management is responsible for developing the state's annual budget and must ensure the $500,000 mandated appropriation for field trip grants is properly included and managed.

The bill explicitly designates the Reginald F. Lewis Museum of Maryland African American History and Culture, which is managed by this agency, as a "Museum of Cultural Import." The agency is directly impacted by the bill's intent to increase student access and field trip funding to its facility.

The Office of the Attorney General serves as the primary legal counsel to the Governor and the State Department of Education, and will provide legal guidance on the implementation of the new grant program and budget mandate.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the privacy protections for library circulation records by specifying that public, school, college, or university libraries may only permit the inspection, use, or disclosure of an individual's record if it is necessary for the library's reasonable operation, if the individual provides written consent, or if required by a subpoena or court order.
qa_results.responsible_party: Public, school, college, and university libraries; Maryland State Library Agency
qa_results.stakeholders: Library patrons and users of public, school, and academic libraries in Maryland.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect Maryland State or local government finances or operations.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: As the agency responsible for providing leadership and coordination for Maryland's public library systems, the Maryland State Library is the primary entity impacted by changes to the laws governing the confidentiality and disclosure of library circulation records.

MSDE oversees the state's public education system, including K-12 school libraries, which are specifically named in the bill as entities that must adhere to the new circulation record disclosure requirements.

The Commission establishes statewide policies for public and private colleges and universities; the bill directly affects the administrative policies regarding circulation records at these postsecondary institutions.

The University System of Maryland operates 12 public institutions with campus libraries that will be required to update their policies and procedures to comply with the bill's requirements for record disclosure.
As a public university, Morgan State operates a library that is subject to the provisions of the bill regarding the protection and disclosure of student and patron circulation records.
As a public honors college, St. Mary's operates a library system that must comply with the bill's updated regulations on the inspection and use of library patron data.
The Maryland School for the Deaf operates school libraries for its students and will be required to ensure its record-keeping practices align with the new statutory requirements.

The bill explicitly includes disclosure via subpoena or court order as a valid circumstance for releasing records, involving the judicial process and court administration in the enforcement of these provisions.

The OAG provides legal counsel to state agencies, including public libraries and higher education institutions, regarding the interpretation of the bill's provisions, such as what constitutes the 'reasonable operation' of a library.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill establishes the Statewide Rental Assistance Voucher Program within the Department of Housing and Community Development to provide rental assistance vouchers and housing payments to low-income families who are currently on waitlists for the federal Housing Choice Voucher Program.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Housing and Community Development (DHCD)
qa_results.stakeholders: Low-income families on federal housing waitlists, public housing agencies (PHAs), and Maryland landlords.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $255,400 in FY 2024 for DHCD administrative startup costs. Between FY 2025 and FY 2027, expenditures increase to approximately $10.3 million annually, reflecting a $10 million mandated appropriation and ongoing administrative costs. For FY 2028, expenditures are estimated at $10.6 million. Local governments and public housing agencies will see increased revenue and expenditures, with 6% of program funding allocated to offset local administrative staffing expenses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Statewide Rental Assistance Voucher Program within this department. The agency is responsible for administering the program, issuing vouchers, conducting inspections, and adopting implementing regulations.

The bill contains a mandated appropriation of $10 million annually for fiscal years 2025 through 2027 and requires future budgets to sustain the program. As the state's principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for managing these budgetary requirements.
The Governor must include the program's mandated funding in the annual budget bill. Additionally, the department must report annually to the Governor on the program's outcomes and demographics.
The Innovation Team is charged with developing evidence-based strategies to reduce child poverty and enhance economic mobility, which are primary objectives of this statewide housing voucher program.

The program prioritizes families experiencing homelessness and foster children aged 18 to 24, both of which are key populations served by the Department of Human Services' social service and foster care programs.
The bill explicitly lists military veterans as a priority group for receiving vouchers and housing assistance payments under the new program.

The bill prioritizes elderly individuals (at least 62 years old) for assistance and includes specific provisions regarding the continuation or termination of benefits upon the death of an elderly family member.
The bill prioritizes disabled individuals for housing vouchers and requires the department to reasonably modify policies to allow live-in aides as an accommodation for persons with disabilities.
The program's mission to reduce child poverty and prioritize families with children aligns with GOC's mandate to coordinate supports for underinvested communities and vulnerable youth.

The OAG will provide legal counsel to the Department of Housing and Community Development regarding the establishment of program guidelines, regulations, and the legal aspects of housing assistance contracts.
The bill grants applicants and participants the right to an informal hearing to contest the denial or termination of assistance, which may involve the OAH as the state's central adjudicative body.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes Baltimore City to implement a judicial in rem foreclosure process for properties identified as vacant or nuisance properties that have delinquent taxes. It outlines specific legal procedures for the city to file a complaint in circuit court, notify interested parties, and obtain a judgment to transfer ownership to the city. Additionally, it establishes rules for selling or retaining these properties, distributing surplus proceeds to interested parties when properties have value, and the conditions under which foreclosure judgments may be reopened.
qa_results.responsible_party: Baltimore City government and the Circuit Court for Baltimore City
qa_results.stakeholders: Owners and lienholders of vacant or nuisance properties in Baltimore City, the Baltimore City government, and residents of Baltimore City impacted by property vacancy and blight.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures may increase for the Baltimore City Circuit Court to handle foreclosure filings. State property tax revenues for the Annuity Bond Fund may be affected depending on the timing of tax collections. Baltimore City finances will be affected by administrative costs for the foreclosure process and potential costs for property maintenance or development, which may be offset by future property sales or increased tax revenue. The total fiscal impact cannot be reliably estimated at this time.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes a specific judicial in rem foreclosure process for Baltimore City in the Circuit Court, requiring the Administrative Office of the Courts to support new court proceedings, clerk filings, and judicial hearings.

The bill focuses on the foreclosure and revitalization of vacant or nuisance properties, which directly impacts the agency's mission regarding community revitalization, affordable housing, and urban development.
The bill requires property appraisals to be performed by licensed real estate appraisers, a profession regulated and licensed by the Maryland Department of Labor.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies and protects consumer rights; foreclosure proceedings have significant legal implications for property owners and interested parties.
As the state's chief financial officer, the Comptroller is responsible for revenue collection, and the bill may impact State property tax revenues collected for the Annuity Bond Fund.
The bill may increase general fund expenditures for the Judicial Branch to handle increased filings and proceedings, which falls under the fiscal oversight of the Department of Budget and Management.
Administrative appeals regarding the initial classification of a property as vacant or a nuisance may involve the Office of Administrative Hearings before the judicial foreclosure process begins.
The Treasurer manages the state's Annuity Bond Fund, which is supported by property tax revenues that could be impacted by changes in foreclosure timing and property disposition in Baltimore City.
The Governor's Office coordinates policy initiatives and oversees the executive branch; this bill aligns with state-level priorities regarding housing, urban stability, and economic mobility.
The Department of Planning provides land use policy guidance and promotes sustainable growth; the revitalization of vacant urban lots is a key component of state planning and resource management.

qa_results.bill_summary: Known as Jaelynn's Law, this bill strengthens firearm storage requirements to prevent access by unsupervised minors and individuals prohibited from possessing firearms. It mandates that the Deputy Secretary for Public Health Services develop a youth suicide prevention and firearm safe storage guide and requires the state to provide grants to local organizations for safe storage education. Additionally, the bill establishes criminal penalties for storage violations and restricts firearm possession for those convicted of such violations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Deputy Secretary for Public Health Services (Maryland Department of Health)
qa_results.stakeholders: Firearm owners, minors under age 18, prohibited persons, local school systems, local health departments, and nonprofit agencies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $50,000 in FY 2024 for the development of a safe storage guide. Starting in FY 2025, the bill mandates an annual appropriation of $1,000,000 for the guide and education grants. General fund revenues may increase minimally from criminal fines. Local impacts include potential increases in revenues from state grants and expenditures related to incarceration and educational programs.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill mandates the Deputy Secretary for Public Health Services within MDH to develop the Youth Suicide Prevention and Firearm Safe Storage Guide, chair a stakeholder advisory committee, and administer a $1,000,000 grant program for safe storage education.

As the primary agency for firearm regulation, MSP enforces the bill's changes to regulated firearm possession laws. The bill also requires MDH to distribute the safety guide to firearm safety training instructors certified by MSP.
The bill mandates that the Governor include a $1,000,000 annual appropriation in the state budget starting in fiscal year 2025 to fund the suicide prevention guide and related grants.
MSDE is specifically named as a recipient of the electronic safety guide, and local school systems under its oversight are eligible to receive grants from MDH to support safe storage education.

DJS is explicitly listed as a recipient of the safety guide for distribution to families and behavioral health programs, and the bill addresses safety risks (suicide and accidental discharge) involving minors.
The judicial branch will be responsible for adjudicating the expanded criminal prohibitions and modified misdemeanor penalties related to the storage of firearms and access by minors.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill requires the establishment of a stakeholder advisory committee to make recommendations regarding the development of the youth suicide prevention and firearm safe storage guide.
DNR's firearm and hunter safety certificate is cited as a specific statutory exception allowing certain minors to access rifles or shotguns for lawful activities.
OAG provides legal counsel to the primary implementing agencies (MDH and MSP) regarding the new regulatory requirements, grant programs, and enforcement of firearm laws.
DBM is responsible for state budget development and will manage the fiscal execution of the bill's mandated $1,000,000 annual appropriation.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: DPSCS may be impacted by potential increases in incarceration resulting from the bill's establishment of higher-degree misdemeanor penalties for unsafe firearm storage that results in harm.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Office of the Public Defender
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: OPD will provide legal representation for indigent individuals charged with the newly expanded or modified criminal violations related to firearm storage.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the requirements for the removal of the State Administrator of Elections. It mandates that, provided the State Board of Elections is fully constituted with five members, the administrator may be removed by an affirmative vote of four members. The bill eliminates the previous requirements for cause (such as incompetence or misconduct), the need for written charges and a hearing, and the provision allowing the administrator to remain in office until a successor is confirmed.
qa_results.responsible_party: State Board of Elections
qa_results.stakeholders: State Administrator of Elections, State Board of Elections, and the Maryland Senate
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State finances, and there is no impact on local government finances or small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly impacts the State Board of Elections by altering the criteria and procedures for removing its chief executive, the State Administrator of Elections.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the State Board of Elections and would be responsible for advising on the legalities of removing a state official under the new statutory requirements.
The Governor oversees the executive branch, including the State Board of Elections, and is responsible for appointing the board members who would exercise this removal power.

As the state's central personnel and budget agency, DBM was consulted as an information source and manages the administrative and fiscal parameters associated with executive branch leadership positions.
The removal of the State Administrator would create a vacancy that requires the Governor to appoint a successor; this office assists the Governor in recruiting and vetting such candidates.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill extends the termination date for the State Board of Social Work Examiners to July 1, 2025, and requires the Board to notify license applicants within 15 business days regarding the completeness of their applications. It also creates a Workgroup on Social Worker Requirements for Licensure to examine examination requirements, potential bias in licensure qualifications, and alternative assessment methods.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health and the State Board of Social Work Examiners
qa_results.stakeholders: Social workers, social work license applicants, social work academic programs, and social service organizations.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $75,000 in FY 2024 and $15,400 in FY 2025 for contractual staff. Board special fund revenues and expenditures are maintained through FY 2025 due to the sunset extension. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly concerns the State Board of Social Work Examiners, which is located within the Department of Health. Additionally, the Department is responsible for staffing the Workgroup on Social Worker Requirements for Licensure, and the Secretary of Health (or a designee) is a member of that workgroup. The fiscal note also specifies a general fund expenditure increase for the Department to support these activities.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill establishes the Workgroup on Social Worker Requirements for Licensure, a temporary body composed of appointed public servants and private citizens tasked with studying licensure requirements and providing recommendations to the General Assembly.

The Governor is responsible for appointing several members of the Workgroup, including social work deans, regional representatives, and impacted individuals. The Governor also designates the chair of the Workgroup.

The Secretary of Human Services (or a designee) is a named member of the Workgroup on Social Worker Requirements for Licensure, reflecting the department's role as a major employer and stakeholder in the social work profession.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Governor's Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Director of the Office of the Deaf and Hard of Hearing (or a designee) is a named member of the Workgroup. The bill specifically includes provisions for a social worker who is deaf or hard of hearing to participate and addresses barriers to licensure for this population.

The fiscal note indicates a need for general fund expenditures and the hiring of contractual personnel to staff the Workgroup. DBM oversees the state's budget execution and personnel management for executive agencies.

qa_results.bill_summary: The Annual Curative Bill is a technical measure designed to correct previous Acts of the General Assembly that may have had 'title defects' (procedural errors in how the bill's purpose was described). This bill repeals and reenacts specific sections of the Real Property and Transportation articles without making substantive changes, thereby validating the existing law regarding the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund and prohibitions against fraudulent conduct during driver's license examinations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Legal Services Corporation (MLSC) and the Department of Legislative Services
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland residents, particularly those involved in eviction proceedings and individuals applying for or renewing driver's licenses or moped permits.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: There is no state or local fiscal impact. The bill is technical in nature and has no effect on governmental finances, as it only cures potential legal defects in previously enacted legislation.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill reenacts provisions in the Transportation Article regarding fraudulent conduct during driver's license examinations and testing, which is a core regulatory and operational function of the MVA.
As the parent agency of the Motor Vehicle Administration, MDOT oversees the enforcement of the Transportation Article, including the driver's license testing regulations mentioned in the bill.

The bill reenacts Section 8-909 of the Real Property Article, which designates the State Treasurer as the custodian of the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund and mandates the Treasurer to invest the fund's money.
The bill reenacts Section 8-909 of the Real Property Article, which requires the Comptroller to account for the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund.

The bill reenacts provisions specifying that the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund consists of money received by the OAG's Division of Consumer Protection from certain settlements related to the Maryland Consumer Protection Act.
The bill reenacts a mandate requiring the Governor to include a specific appropriation ($14,000,000) for the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund in the annual budget bill.
As the agency responsible for developing the state budget, DBM is relevant to the bill's reenactment of the mandated appropriation for the Access to Counsel in Evictions Special Fund.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the definition of a 'therapy horse' under the Maryland Veterans Service Animal Program. It removes the requirement that a stable licensed by the State must be a 'premier accredited' member center of the Professional Association of Therapeutic Horsemanship, International (PATH, Intl.) to provide services, thereby allowing any PATH, Intl. member center or stable with Equine Assisted Growth and Learning Association (EAGALA) certified professionals to participate in the program.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Veterans Affairs
qa_results.stakeholders: Maryland veterans and nonprofit equine therapy organizations and stables
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no impact on State or local government finances as the change is technical in nature. Small business impact is expected to be minimal.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Veterans Service Animal Program is administered by this department. The bill directly alters the definition of a 'therapy horse' used within their program for veteran referrals and support.

The bill's definition of a 'therapy horse' requires the horse to be associated with a 'stable licensed by the State.' The Department of Agriculture, through the Maryland Horse Industry Board, is the agency responsible for the licensing and regulation of stables.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch departments involved in this program and coordinates policy initiatives related to the veteran support and suicide reduction goals of the program.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill authorizes the Maryland Department of Natural Resources to issue annual fishing license and stamp exemptions to governmental entities and nonprofit organizations that provide fishing clinics and instructional opportunities to specific groups. These groups include active-duty military and veterans, participants in wellness or special needs outdoor events, individuals with scientific collection permits, and underserved residents. The bill also updates reporting requirements for these organizations and allows the Department to adopt related regulations.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Natural Resources
qa_results.stakeholders: Veterans and active-duty military members, individuals participating in wellness or special needs outdoor events, underserved residents, scientific collection permit holders, and nonprofit or governmental organizations providing fishing instruction.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no material fiscal effect in FY 2023. Beginning in FY 2024, State special fund revenues for the Fisheries Management and Protection Fund and the Fisheries Research and Development Fund may increase if clinic participants subsequently purchase their own fishing licenses or stamps. There are no projected impacts on State expenditures or local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Natural Resources is the primary agency responsible for issuing fishing license exemptions, managing the related reporting requirements for participating organizations, and adopting new regulations to define eligibility for underserved residents.

The bill establishes specific fishing license exemptions for patients and residents in State-approved mental health and developmental disability facilities, which are regulated or operated by the Department of Health.

The bill authorizes fishing license exemptions specifically for active-duty service members and veterans participating in fishing clinics and wellness events, directly aligning with the Department's mission to provide advocacy and support for military families.

The bill provides license exemptions for individuals with physical or mental disabilities participating in special needs or wellness outdoor events, supporting the Department's goal of improving service delivery and community inclusion.

The bill includes license exemptions for individuals acting under scientific collection permits, which are frequently used by researchers and students within the University System of Maryland for fisheries studies.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Department of Natural Resources and will be involved in drafting and reviewing the legality of the new regulations and exemption forms authorized by the bill.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill increases the mandatory annual appropriation for the Maryland Construction Education and Innovation Fund from $250,000 to $625,000 for fiscal years 2025 through 2029. The funds are designated to support the operation of the Maryland Center for Construction Education and Innovation (MCCEI). The bill also terminates the mandated funding requirement after fiscal year 2029.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Labor and the Governor
qa_results.stakeholders: The Maryland Center for Construction Education and Innovation (MCCEI), construction industry workers and employers, and small businesses in the construction sector.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $375,000 annually from fiscal 2025 through 2029, reflecting the difference between the current $250,000 mandate and the new $625,000 requirement. Special fund revenues and expenditures for the Maryland Construction Education and Innovation Fund increase by corresponding amounts during this period. The mandated appropriation is eliminated starting in fiscal 2030, which will result in a decrease in expenditures and revenues at that time.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Construction Education and Innovation Fund is established under the Labor and Employment Article of the Maryland Code, and the Department of Labor is the primary agency responsible for workforce development programs and provided information for the fiscal analysis of the bill.

As the principal fiscal agency, DBM is responsible for developing the state's budget and supervising the execution of mandated appropriations, including the $625,000 annual appropriation required by this bill for the Construction Education and Innovation Fund.

The bill mandates that the Governor include a specific appropriation of $625,000 in the annual budget bill for the Maryland Construction Education and Innovation Fund for fiscal years 2025 through 2029.

The Maryland Center for Construction Education and Innovation resulted from the work of this board's industry initiatives, and the center's mission to develop innovative workforce solutions for the construction industry aligns with the board's statewide strategic responsibilities.
The Maryland Center for Construction Education and Innovation, which receives support from the fund, is located at Towson University, a member institution of the University System of Maryland.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill prohibits the Maryland Insurance Commissioner from removing specific reciprocal jurisdictions from the state's list of approved jurisdictions for reinsurance. These jurisdictions include those outside the United States subject to covered agreements (such as the European Union and United Kingdom) and accredited jurisdictions within the United States. The measure ensures that insurers from these regions can operate in Maryland without needing to post collateral, aligning state law with federal standards and avoiding potential federal preemption.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Insurance Commissioner
qa_results.stakeholders: Insurers and reinsurers operating in Maryland, particularly those domiciled in the European Union, the United Kingdom, and accredited U.S. jurisdictions.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill does not materially affect State operations or finances. There is no impact on local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill directly amends the Insurance Article and restricts the authority of the Maryland Insurance Commissioner regarding the maintenance of the reciprocal jurisdictions list for reinsurance credits, which is a central regulatory function of the agency.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Maryland Insurance Administration and would be involved in ensuring that the agency's regulatory actions and the adoption of new standards comply with this legislation and federal preemption requirements.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires the Maryland Historical Trust to terminate or extinguish a specific preservation easement it holds on the Warner Manor property, also known as the Brainard Warner House and Circle Manor, in the Town of Kensington, Montgomery County, and to complete all necessary filings to finalize this action by July 1, 2023.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Historical Trust
qa_results.stakeholders: The Maryland Historical Trust, Montgomery County, and the residents of the Town of Kensington.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no state or local fiscal impact. The Maryland Historical Trust can implement the termination of the easement using existing resources, and the bill does not directly affect local government finances.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Maryland Historical Trust (MHT), which is explicitly directed by the bill to extinguish the easement and complete legal filings, is a unit within the Department of Planning.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to state agencies and would likely be responsible for overseeing the legal process of terminating the easement and ensuring proper recordings and filings are completed.

The Board of Public Works oversees the acquisition and transfer of State property interests; the termination of a State-held preservation easement represents a disposition of a State property interest.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch agencies responsible for implementing the bill and the Governor signed the legislation into law.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill reforms the Maryland 529 Program by abolishing the Maryland 529 Board and transferring the administration of its programs—including the Maryland Prepaid College Trust (MPCT), the College Investment Plan (MCIP), and the ABLE Program—to the Office of the State Treasurer. It phases out the MPCT by prohibiting new accounts or contract upgrades after June 1, 2023, and establishes a formal process for account holders to file claims related to the trust's administration and specific 2021 disclosure terms.
qa_results.responsible_party: Office of the State Treasurer
qa_results.stakeholders: Current and prospective Maryland 529 account holders and beneficiaries, specifically those enrolled in the Prepaid College Trust, College Investment Plan, or ABLE Program; employees of the Maryland 529 Program transferred to the Treasurer's Office; and the Office of the State Treasurer.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund expenditures increase by $6.7 million in FY 2024 for the Office of the State Treasurer to implement the transition, including adding eight new positions and establishing a claims resolution process. Approximately $17 million in nonbudgeted, special, and reimbursable funds shift from the abolished Maryland 529 Board to the State Treasurer's Office annually. Claims settlements are paid from existing MPCT assets and are exempt from State and local taxes. Local revenues may see a minimal increase from the reduction in MPCT income tax deductions.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill designates the State Treasurer as the successor to the Maryland 529 Board, transferring full administrative and fiduciary responsibility for the Maryland 529 Program, including the Prepaid College Trust and ABLE Program, to this office.
The bill abolishes the Maryland 529 Board and reforms the entire program, transferring its assets, staff, and management to the State Treasurer.

The State Treasurer is required to work in consultation with the Department of Disabilities to administer and promote the Maryland ABLE Program. Additionally, the Secretary of Disabilities is added to the Financial Education and Capability Commission.
The Secretary of Higher Education was a member of the Maryland 529 Board, and the agency's budget currently handles general fund appropriations for the program which are impacted by the transfer.
The bill involves the transfer of state employees and the shifting of appropriations from nonbudgeted to special and reimbursable funds, requiring oversight of personnel and fiscal execution.

The Comptroller was a member of the Maryland 529 Board and is involved in the Financial Education and Capability Commission. The agency also manages the tax implications for program participants and claim settlements.
The bill explicitly requires the Legislative Auditor to audit the Prepaid College Trust.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Executive Commissions, Committees, Task Forces, and Advisory Boards
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The bill abolishes the Maryland 529 Board and alters the membership of the Financial Education and Capability Commission.
The Governor oversees the executive branch reorganization and receives reports from the State Treasurer concerning the operation of the trust and marketing plans.
The State Superintendent of Schools was a member of the now-abolished Maryland 529 Board.
The Chancellor was a member of the now-abolished Maryland 529 Board.

agency_relevance.agency_name: Maryland Teachers & State Employees Supplemental Retirement Plans
agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The State Treasurer is required to coordinate with the Board of Trustees of the Maryland Teachers and State Employees Supplemental Retirement Plans to increase participation in 529 programs.
As the chief legal officer for the state, the OAG would be involved in providing counsel for the claims resolution process and the significant transfer of administrative authority and assets.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill modifies the residency requirements for individuals applying for alcoholic beverages licenses in Anne Arundel County on behalf of partnerships, corporations, clubs, or limited liability companies. It allows these applicants to be residents of the State of Maryland instead of specifically requiring residency within the county or municipality, provided the applicant remains a State resident for the duration of the license's validity.
qa_results.responsible_party: Anne Arundel County Board of License Commissioners
qa_results.stakeholders: Alcoholic beverage license applicants in Anne Arundel County, specifically those applying on behalf of partnerships, corporations, clubs, or limited liability companies.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill has no effect on State finances and is not anticipated to materially affect Anne Arundel County operations or finances. There is a minimal impact on small businesses.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller of Maryland is the primary state agency responsible for regulating the alcohol industry and enforcing related laws. The bill specifically references the requirement for application forms prescribed by the Comptroller and modifies licensing residency requirements that fall under the Comptroller's regulatory oversight.

The Office of the Attorney General provides legal counsel to the Comptroller and various state licensing boards. It may be required to provide guidance on the implementation of these residency requirements and ensure they comply with broader state and constitutional law.

The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch, enforces state laws, and coordinates policy initiatives. The Governor signed this legislation into law, and the office maintains oversight of the agencies responsible for its administration.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill alters the definition of a captive real estate investment trust (REIT) under Maryland income tax laws. It excludes certain corporations, trusts, or associations owned or controlled by qualified foreign entities or specific Australian property trusts from being classified as a captive REIT, which effectively allows these entities to claim a federal dividends paid deduction rather than adding it back to their Maryland modified income.
qa_results.responsible_party: Comptroller of Maryland
qa_results.stakeholders: Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), specifically those with foreign or Australian property trust ownership, and Maryland state and local governments.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: State general fund, Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF), and Transportation Trust Fund (TTF) revenues may decrease by an indeterminate amount starting in FY 2024 due to fewer REITs being subject to the addition modification. Local highway user revenues and corresponding TTF expenditures may also decrease. A precise estimate cannot be determined without a detailed examination of individual corporate structures.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Comptroller is the primary agency responsible for tax administration, collection, and regulation. The bill directly modifies Maryland income tax law and specifically empowers the Comptroller to adopt regulations concerning the definition of captive REITs.

The fiscal note indicates that revenues for the Transportation Trust Fund (TTF), which funds MDOT operations and local highway grants, may decrease as a result of the bill's changes to the corporate income tax.

DBM is responsible for state revenue estimation and long-term fiscal planning. This bill impacts state revenues (General Fund, HEIF, and TTF), which directly affects the budget development process overseen by the department.

As the agency responsible for adjudicating cases involving income tax and making factual determinations on tax-related disputes, the Maryland Tax Court would likely oversee appeals regarding the new legal definitions for captive REITs.
The Governor's Office oversees the executive branch and proposes the state budget; changes to tax revenue and fiscal policy impact the Governor's budgetary priorities.
The Treasurer's Office manages the state's financial assets and anticipates monetary needs. Changes to revenue streams from income taxes impact the management and distribution of state funds.

The OAG provides legal counsel to the Comptroller and the General Assembly regarding the implementation of tax laws and would represent the state in any civil appeals resulting from tax disputes related to this legislation.
The fiscal note mentions a potential decrease in revenues for the Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF), which is a key funding source for the University System of Maryland.
The fiscal note mentions a potential decrease in revenues for the Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF), which provides funding to Morgan State University as a state public university.

As a public honors college that receives state funding, Saint Mary's College of Maryland may be indirectly impacted by the decrease in revenues to the Higher Education Investment Fund (HEIF) mentioned in the fiscal note.

qa_results.bill_summary: This bill requires contractors operating State-owned nursing homes to provide prompt notice of any deficiencies or enforcement actions to the Governor, the overseeing State agency, and relevant committees and members of the General Assembly. Within 30 days of receiving a citation or fine, the contractor must also submit a statement of deficiencies, a plan of correction, and all related survey communications. Additionally, the Maryland Department of Health is required to submit an annual report on survey activities and enforcement actions at these facilities.
qa_results.responsible_party: Maryland Department of Health
qa_results.stakeholders: Residents of State-owned nursing homes, particularly veterans and their spouses at facilities such as the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, and the private contractors hired to operate these facilities.
qa_results.fiscal_impact_summary: The bill's requirements are expected to be handled with existing budgeted resources. There is no impact on State or local revenues, and no additional expenditures are mandated for the Maryland Department of Health or other state agencies.

agency_relevance.relevance_explanation: The Department of Health is the primary agency impacted by this bill. Its Office of Health Care Quality (OHCQ) is specifically designated as a 'monitoring agency' responsible for survey and enforcement activities. Additionally, the Department is mandated to produce an annual report for the Governor and General Assembly regarding survey activities and enforcement actions at State-owned nursing homes operated by contractors.

The Department of Veterans & Military Families (formerly the Department of Veterans Affairs) oversees the Charlotte Hall Veterans Home, which is currently the State-owned nursing home operated by a private contractor. The bill requires the contractor to promptly notify the overseeing State agency (DVMF) of any deficiencies, citations, or enforcement actions.

The Governor's Office is a primary recipient of information under this bill. Contractors must provide the Governor with notice of deficiencies and enforcement actions, as well as statements of deficiencies and plans of correction. Furthermore, the Department of Health is required to submit its annual report on these facilities to the Governor.

The OAG serves as the chief legal representative for the State and provides legal counsel to the Department of Health and the Department of Veterans & Military Families. The OAG would likely be involved in interpreting contractor reporting requirements, addressing enforcement actions, or managing legal issues arising from nursing home deficiencies.

The Department of Aging oversees programs and advocacy for older adults in nursing homes. While not the primary reporting or monitoring agency named in the bill, it has a significant policy interest in the transparency and quality of care within State-owned nursing facilities.

DBM is the principal personnel and fiscal agency for the State. It oversees State contracts and budget execution; therefore, it has an interest in the performance and reporting compliance of contractors operating State-owned facilities, as deficiencies and enforcement actions can impact contract viability and fiscal obligations.
